PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Australia is one nation which comprises people from many different racial and cultural backgrounds;
That a Treaty with one of these peoples-the Aborigines-would be divisive and would be equivalent to the setting up of a separate nation;
That a Treaty could lead to the introduction of a national system of land rights;
That we are totally opposed to the signing of a Treaty with the Aboriginal people.
As in duty bound, your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That it be recognised the proposed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill is a public, legal acknowledgement that Australians who are non-aboriginal do not have sovereignty in their own country.

2. That the Australian people are opposed to the idea of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Australian people who are non-aboriginal and those who are aboriginal, and the Government has no mandate or authority to pursue it.
3. That the proposed legislation and treaty
will damage Australia's position under international law and in any conflict,
will cause distrust and conflict between our aboriginal population (1%) and the non-aboriginal population (99%),
will extend aboriginal land rights, contrary to the wishes of the Australian people,
will not be acceptable to the aboriginal people themselves,
will solve none of the problems of aboriginal people who need housing, health services, education and employment.

That therefore, the Senate reject absolutely the announced proposals for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, and the negotiation of a treaty, compact or makarrata between the Commonwealth and aboriginal people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions and Fringe Benefits Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision is made to protect savings against inflation.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Sandy Region: World Heritage Listing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-
The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows: That Fraser Island and the other parts of the Great Sandy Region qualify for World Heritage Listing because of outstanding values:
GEOLOGICAL-The World's greatest sand mass and the oldest age sequence of giant coastal dunes; perched dune lakes; barrage dune lakes unknown elsewhere.

BIOLOGICAL-Coastal heathlands, freshwater swamps, mangroves, the World's only rain-forest growing on high coastal dunes, ancient paperbarks; 750 species of flowering plants and ferns; wallum; wide diversity of marine, terrestrial and avian fauna, some of which is rare or endemic.

AESTHETIC-40 kilometres of coloured sand cliff faces, volcanic outcrops, over 40 perched dune lakes, the majestic Noosa river, wildflower-strewn heathlands, vast surfaces of loose mobile sand, rainforests, crystal-clear fresh-water streams.

CULTURAL-Evidence of large populations of Aborigines in the region-middens, bora rings, canoe trees, implements and other artifacts; historical artifacts from the last 150 years-2 operating lighthouses, shipwrecks.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth Government take action to place Fraser Island and the other parts of the Great Sandy Region on the World Heritage List to ensure proper recognition of the region's international importance and to ensure appropriate management to preserve its unique qualities.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are:
1. Opposed to the Government's decision to cut funding to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in real terms for the sixth year in succession;
2. Greatly concerned with the ramifications of these funding cuts in terms of reductions in staff numbers and research capacity;

3. Greatly concerned with the ramifications of these cuts on rural research in Queensland and on the long term economic well being of the rural sector, which makes a significant contribution to Australia's export income.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Joint Select Committee on Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification;

We call upon the Senate to request the Government immediately to introduce substantive legislation to ban X-rated video material (and its R-rated equivalent) and to refuse classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Joint Select Committee on Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
X-rated video material contravenes Christian moral beliefs in that,
1. the status of both women and men are degraded by the material,
2. children could gain access to the material, much to the detriment of their moral development,
3. the material often promotes and encourages criminal acts

Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to put pressure on the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X-rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution: Proposed Changes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.

Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in parliament assembled, should support the Constitutional Alteration (Electors Initiative) 1987 Bill to alter the constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Sporting, Cultural and Community Groups: Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat,-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

That we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 2JJJ: Broadcast to the Canberra Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President, and members of the Senate, in the Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully support the demand:

That the ABC radio station 2JJJ signal be relayed and broadcast to the Canberra region, on stereo FM, round the clock, commencing as soon as possible. (there is currently no existing FM radio station in Canberra, offering alternative commercial-free stereo music.)

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we strongly object to the contents of the film ``The Last Temptation of Christ'' on the grounds that it is blasphemous, offensive and obnoxious.

It is deplorable that the Commonwealth Films Board of Review downgraded the film's classification to ``M'', mature audiences. This rating will permit children of any age to view a film which is grossly offensive to many Christians and contains both profane and historically inaccurate depictions of the life of Christ.
Your petitioners strongly urge the Senate to take action to both prevent this film from receiving unrestricted exhibition and similar instances occurring in the future.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General and Recreational Aircraft: Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, we, the users of Archerfield Airport and Electors in this Senate, humbly petition and respectfully request:

(1) That the F.A.C. be restrained from imposing the proposed charges against General Aviation and Recreational Aircraft at certain Secondary Airports and that the existing levy on Aviation Fuel be used to finance any shortfall between F.A.Cs. expenditure and income. The following facts show why that restraint should be imposed on F.A.C.
(2) Total cost recovery as outlined in the Bosch Report, was to be achieved over a period of Ten Years, this cost recovery has already been achieved and exceeded at this stage.

(3) The levy on Aviation Fuel was, after consultation and agreement by G.A., implemented to take the place of A.N.Cs., which covered landing fees, parking, etc., for which F.A.C. now proposes to make a charge.

(4) D.o.T.C., C.A.A. and F.A.C. provide services and maintenance that, largely, is neither required nor wanted by the majority of Secondary Airport Users, rationalisation of these services and maintenance would allow portion of the fuel levy, now paid toward this overservicing, to be allocated to F.A.C.

(5) The exaggerated proposed expenditure figures as presented by Mr. Barry Thompson of F.A.C. to meetings of Airport users are clearly not based on fact; An honest assessment would show greatly reduced figures which would more closely approach the current income that F.A.C. now obtains, without the need for any additional charges.

(6) Implementation of further charges against G.A. Aircraft at Secondary Airports will inevitably effect the viability of business operating at these Airports, as aircraft will be removed to satellite Aerodromes. (eg) Maintenance organisations and flying schools

(7) If Secondary Airports were to have charges almost comparable to Primary Airports, then certainly, congestion at Primary Airports would increase; Therefore some form of cross subsidisation from Primary to Secondary Airports, is both warranted and desirable.
As in duty bound, your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Graduate Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament the petition of the undersigned shows that we oppose the introduction of the graduate tax, recognising it as a discriminatory piece of legislation which will, in particular, greatly disadvantage women, that it will act as a disincentive to women's participation in Tertiary Education and set back women's battle for equal opportunity, that Women Graduates are lower paid and therefore will suffer this flat rate fee disproportionately, and that the whole economic approach of the green and white papers and the Graduate Tax will discourage the development of those areas of study where women are now concentrated, which are of such great cultural and social value. Your Petitioners therefore ask that you reject the proposals contained in the white paper and specifically, that you reject the introduction of the graduate tax.
And your petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the House of Representatives on 22 November 1988 in respect of the agreements between this country and the United States of America on the spy bases at Pine Gap and Nurrungar;

(b) notes with outrage that the arrangements for the operation of the facilities have been extended for a further 10 years and that the arrangements for the termination of this agreement have been extended from one year's notice to 3 years' notice on either side;

(c) takes cognizance of the fact that, while Mr Hawke says that the bases are for verification purposes, it has been clearly established that they play an essential part in the USA first strike capability;

(d) condemns these moves by the Government which, instead of serving the interests of ourselves and our partners as the Prime Minister would have us believe, effectively tie Australia to the vagaries of the USA foreign policy for another 10 years and ensure that Australia remains a Soviet military target for that time and, therefore, do not represent Australia's interests at all;

(e) expresses its dismay that the Government has seen fit to continue to maintain a veil of secrecy around the joint facilities and that it has cynically pre-empted the wishes of the Australian people, expressed in recent public opinion polls, for a full public inquiry into the bases;

(f) condemns, further, the Prime Minister's statement that nobody seriously committed to peace could argue for the closure of the bases, and expresses concern at these attempts to undermine and denigrate the work of the Australian peace movement and its success in bringing the public's attention to the real functions of the defence facilities; and

(g) urges the Government, if it is seriously committed to peace and to serving the interests of Australia, to close the bases or, as an acceptable alternative, to open them up completely for international verification and staff them with the many experienced and highly trained scientists in this country who are skilled in the science of verification so that Australian may truly contribute to the diminishing of nuclear weaponry in this world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Casino Control Ordinance 1988, as contained in Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance No. 4 of 1988 and made under the Christmas Island Act 1958, be disallowed.

The Christmas Island that we are concerned with is the one near Indonesia, 360 kilometres from Java Head, and is not its namesake, which has been used for nuclear testing. It is a volcanic island which rises out of the ocean. There are cliffs, rich topsoil and a rather depleted area of unique rainforest. Until the mid-1970s the island was simply a source of cheap phosphates for fertilisers. This changes because of two things: the decline in international phosphate prices and the unionisation of the Christmas Island work force.

The story of the Union of Christmas Island Workers deserves to be told and is relevant, as said the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. Indeed, this story has been told. The quotation from the Prime Minister comes from the dust jacket of a book by Les Waters, lecturer at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology:

This is the story of how a small union in a remote and little-known Australian territory changed the status of its members from that of indentured labourers on Asian rates of pay to employees enjoying permanent residency and mainland pay and conditions.
This revolution was not achieved easily. In the end, however, solidarity, resolution and intelligent campaigning over a long period and a tough, competent and committed leadership won through.
The Union of Christmas Island Workers story deserves to be told.
R. J. HAWKE.

That is from a book which was published in 1983 and which relates the whole complex story of the Christmas Island phosphates mine: how it was closed by the Government, how the workers set up a fund to reopen it, and how it was adopted as a speculative enterprise by one of our beer barons-not even a Western Australian beer baron but a multinational and Victorian beer baron.

It is necessary to bear this story in mind when we look at the question of a casino on Christmas Island. The people of Christmas Island, just like the people of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), once had a form of elected self-government in traditional Australian style; that is, they had an assembly which was elected by Senate-style proportional representation, which, of course, is what the Australian Democrats and most people of political goodwill would argue is the most appropriate for the ACT. However, the Assembly on Christmas Island bucked the Government and protested loud and long-in the first place about `Australian labour at Asian rates'. It protested about the running of the island by the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Ltd for the benefit of the company. The Assembly's members asserted their rights as Australians, and they objected in particular to the exploitation of particularly sensitive areas of rainforest on the island. It was for this dangerous display of independent thinking that the Christmas Island Assembly was duly dissolved.

This meant that the people of the island now have no elected voice. There is no way they can currently express their opinion through their elected representatives. I would like to quote from newspaper articles written in 1986, more than two years ago. The first is from the Canberra Times of 22 April 1986:
Christmas Islanders have voted overwhelmingly in favour of a $30 million casino resort.
In a referendum at the weekend, 93 per cent voted Yes to the proposal, which would provide about 350 jobs directly and another 200 in secondary services.
The island's Assembly called the referendum after islanders signed a petition to the Federal Government.
But the 1,000 islanders are optimistic that a casino can make their homeland a tourist attraction, if it is included in a package tour including perhaps the Cocos Islands . . . and Bali or Singapore.
Again, in the Australian Financial Review of 24 April 1986, it was stated:
Christmas islanders are becoming increasingly incensed over what they see as delays in approving new projects for the island.

The chairman of the island's governing body, Mr Gordon Bennett, said on his way to Canberra yesterday that the Federal Government's apathy smacked of racism-`if a European community was involved, action would have been taken long ago'.
The islanders want approval for a $30 million casino and tourist complex that they hope will reduce unemployment, when phosphate production is cut by half at the end of this year.
Without a new venture, 300 of the island's mostly Chinese population of 2,500, will be unemployed.
He-
that is, Mr Bennett-
was critical of long delays in the Department of Territories, over several major development applications for the island.
In the past five years, the Federal Government had conducted three inquiries in the island's future; All had advocated tourism.
Finally, in the Australian Financial Review of 18 June 1986, it was stated:
The Federal Government is expected to approve a $30 million casino-hotel complex for Christmas Island next week.
The island, long a major source of phosphate for the Australian farming industry, faces economic ruin as this resource is exhausted in the next few years.
The proposal to build the complex has been approved by a Cabinet sub-committee under the chairmanship of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke.
According to Canberra sources it will be considered by Cabinet on Monday.
The casino, a 262-room hotel, and a small marina will be built by a Perth company, F. P. Woodmore Pty Ltd, funded through the Benwood Property Trust, and operated by Federal Pacific Hotels Ltd.

We are looking at a history of events dating back two years. We are now two years down the track. This proposal has not been set up. And there is no longer an assembly of elected representatives for the people of Christmas Island. It seems that the Government has embarked on a deliberate policy to depopulate the island while at the same time seeking to maintain a presence on the island. The contradiction can be overcome only by removing the present permanent residents and replacing them with selected mainland employees. There is some hard evidence to the effect that former Minister Brown regarded this somewhat inhuman policy as desirable. I will quote from a departmental memo dated June 1988:
Former Minister Brown agreed to an extension of time to commence and complete construction of the hotel-casino on the basis of:
the upheaval on Christmas Island with the abolition of the Christmas Island Assembly and the closure of the phosphate mine; and
the Department's wish to slow down development to ensure that the existing population could be persuaded to leave earlier rather than later.

Let me remind honourable senators that these people are Australian citizens on Australian soil, however remote from the comfortable suburban gardens of Canberra. I wish to quote as well from a letter I received not too many days ago from a social worker on Christmas Island who said:
I ask that you support us in requesting the Government continues to provide English language classes for the majority of non-English speaking, long term residents of Christmas Island.

She went on to explain that the English language program was introduced in 1986 and was run by the technical and further education sector. She said that now the program is being discontinued because the Islanders are being told that funds are no longer forthcoming. So I ask: Is this too part of the plan to depopulate the island, or at least remove the old employees of the phosphate mine with their troublesome union and independent-minded Assembly and replace them with a more biddable group of hotel or casino employees?

The citizens of Canberra are indignant because they feel, and quite rightly so, that the Federal Government is attempting to impose a casino on them before they have their elections for their own assembly-which we all hope will be early next year. The citizens of Christmas Island are similarly indignant. We in the Australian Democrats do not contest the need for Australia to maintain a presence on this far-flung outpost of our empire. However, we contest most strongly the bringing forward of the Territory of Christmas Island Ordinance at a time when there are no elected representatives of the people of Christmas Island to monitor the setting up of any potential casino development.

There is an alternative to the casino proposal which I wish to put before the Senate. Christmas Island is a beautiful tropical island. Geographically, it is a part of Asia. The people there are of Chinese and Malay origins and some are of European origin. The Muslim Malays, incidentally, are strongly and traditionally opposed to casino gambling for religious and cultural reasons. They have exotic customs and eat exotic food, but they are all Australians. One does not need a passport to go there, there are no international hassles, there is no need for travellers cheques and there is no need for international incidents. It is, in fact, one more Australian territory. I have had quite a few conversations-and they were very courteous-with Mr Frank Woodmore, the proposed developer. When I quoted a paragraph in his proposed development brochure back to him recently he said that the paragraph was written for the sole purpose of encouraging would-be investors. If he could stretch the truth to would-be investors, can we not believe that the facts are so? We in this place are concerned not just with the future of developers but with the future of an island and its population. I quote from Mr Woodmore's brochure:

. . . even without a casino licence, Christmas Island Casino Resort would be an attractive proposition. The potential for general tourism is great. The visitor will discover many fascinating features on Christmas Island which cannot be found elsewhere. As a resort, the project is financially attractive.

What future do we advocate for the island? Clearly, in the first instance, the Islanders themselves must be consulted. The Christmas Island Assembly, which was dissolved by the Federal Government, through the Minister, should be re-established. As with the current spate of referendum proposals for Canberra, it is no use having polls or elections if the voters are kept uninformed. It is the view of the Democrats that no new mining should take place on the island but that the mine tailings should be worked out until they are of no further value, at the same time as a serious program of rehabilitation over the previously mined areas takes place. The national park area of the island must be extended to include all the known habitat and especially the nesting sites of the endangered species on the island-that is, the frigatebirds, the boobies and hawk-owls. We are sure that, in the long term, sensitive tourist development will enable Australia to maintain a presence on the island, enable the endangered species once again to flourish, and provide work in the industry and ancillary services for the residents of the island.

If there is to be a casino on the island, it is not appropriate for the Senate to impose that on the people while they do not have their elected representatives to monitor it. As I pointed out in my speech on the proposed ACT casino, the one small business which has come to flourish in my home city of Perth since the establishment of the casino there is that of the pawnbroker. The drugs, prostitution and street crime are accepted by independent and searching inquiries such as the Connor Board of Inquiry into Casinos to be par for the course. On Christmas Island we could perhaps delete the street crime and add fauna smuggling. Christmas Island, like the Australian Capital Territory, is at a turning point. In both cases that turning point has been brought about by a government which refuses to listen to its own electors. A duly elected Assembly was dissolved and the people were denied any representation. In both cases I believe that the Government, with supreme arrogance, is attempting to foist a casino on a people which in one case is unwilling and in the other has no currently elected Assembly to speak for it. In the case of Christmas island there has been neither an environmental impact study nor a social impact study.

Any consideration of any development, whether it be tourism, with or without a casino, whether it be military-and I believe that there possibly is a case for some kind of low scale Australian presence there-or whether it be continued mining, must take into account the fate of the birds I mentioned previously: the boobies, the frigatebirds and the hawk owls. I hope that we are sufficiently enlightened in 1988-even our chemical spraying coalition colleagues-to realise that we do not have the right to cause the extinction of another species. We share this world and, indeed, I would say that we borrow it from the future. On the face of it, I guess the island could benefit from no human presence at all from that point of view and the web of life, which we have torn and tattered, could repair a little corner of itself.

But Christmas Island is populated, it is part of Australia and the people on it are Australians. It would be possible, I guess, for us to pass legislation forbidding human presence on the island, but we are not proposing that at all. It does seem that the Australian Government wishes to maintain a presence on the island and this presence for a long while, as I said before, took the form of a phosphate mine-even long after the mine ceased to be economic. There has been the suggestion, at least, that the island has an increasingly important military purpose. It was part of Project Flowerless, according to Des Ball, which was an ocean bed surveillance system designed to spy on South East Asia, especially Indonesia. Certainly, as I said before, the island has an obvious strategic importance in terms of the major sea lanes which pass near it on the way to Australian ports. A newspaper cartoonist expressed the point nicely quite recently. The clip to the cartoon said, `Trouble on Christmas Island? Send in a Casino!'.

Whether we maintain our presence through a casino, a phosphate mine or an out-and-out military base, why does it have an overriding importance? It is because our presence on the island gives us a toehold in South East Asia, a forward listening post, or is it because our presence above the waterline enormously increases our legal access to the seabed, with its huge reserves of oil and gas? So what do we do to maintain our presence at this outpost of our civilisation? Do we need to send in a casino?

During the recent debate on the subject of a casino in this beautiful city of Canberra, I did raise many objections to casinos as such. Honourable senators will be happy to know that I do not propose to go through them again. But I do note that during that debate there was little attempt to refute points which I made about the social effects of casino gambling. Clearly the situation on Christmas Island is different from that in Canberra. One of the most telling arguments against a casino in Canberra is simply that it is this nation's capital, a place of dignity and some beauty, that a gambling casino is simply inappropriate and that tacky commercialism would be an unhappy graft on the precincts of our Parliament. But would a casino be appropriate for Christmas Island? The proponents of the casino do point out that a casino already exists on the island, the Poon Saan Club, which has provided an outlet for the alleged urge to gamble amongst members of the Chinese community. It is asserted that this gambling club has no social consequences; indeed, it has been pointed out to me that the Chinese residents on the island use gambling in a sense to launder money because they believe that some percentage of their income is always derived from the misfortune of another and that if they use this money to gamble and then win, the unluckiness of that money has been washed away. That is quite interesting anthropological material, but I am not convinced that a Chinese gambling club, however effective in bringing good luck, is a relevant precedent to a hotel casino.

During the debate on the proposed casino for the Australian Capital Territory, much mention was made of the almost certain connection between casinos and organised crime. Casino proponents denied this suggestion or claimed that with adequate surveillance there would be no problem. It has also been stated that on Christmas Island surveillance is easier because, as access to the island is only by air, it is that much easier to monitor who comes in. However, a recent article in the Age of 11 November, under the headline `Casino tours attracting criminals, say police,' stated:
Overseas organised crime figures were trying to use casino tours to enter and operate in Australia, a senior police officer said in New Zealand yesterday.

An assistant commissioner of the Western Australian Police, Mr Max Marshall, told the Australasian Crime Conference in Wellington that a group of Thai criminals had sought entry to Western Australia as gambling-tour operators.
The group had links with heroin trafficking, illegal immigration, prostitution and social security fraud. Two tour operators were believed to be involved in two murders in Thailand.
Mr Marshall said that while people applying to become casino tour operators were checked by police, the controls were not `totally effective'.

I remind honourable senators firstly, that, this was a police survey of casino tour operators, not casino operators; and, secondly, that this survey uncovered only those operators, probably only the tiniest tip of the iceberg, who were actually caught with their fingers in the till. Most of the criminal figures, as we all know, would not go anywhere near the sort of petty crime which this survey indicates. I with to quote the shadow Minister for the environment, David Connolly, as reported in Hansard for 12 March 1986:

. . . the trade in wildlife is a particularly lucrative business. It has been said that it is now as lucrative as drug trafficking. In fact, both operations tend to go hand in hand, with the same Asian routes being used to smuggle birds and other wildlife out of Australia, and to bring in drugs on the return journey.
The then Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, said:
There is strong evidence that the rich rewards available to wildlife traffickers have led to the involvement of internationally organised criminals.

I believe that these arguments have not been refuted. I believe that casinos and organised crime go together, hand in glove. I believe that, as far as the situation on Christmas Island is concerned, because of the wildlife and fauna there, this matter is something to be particularly cautious about. Finally, I wish to quote a letter written to the editor of the Australian by Mr R. J. Ellicott, QC, a former Minister for the Australian Capital Territory and a judge of the New South Wales courts. The letter, which appeared on 26 February 1988, was headed: `SOS for Christmas Island'. He said:
As an Australian and a former minister responsible for the administration of Christmas Island I would like to protest at the treatment now being meted out to our people there.

Although under a generally benevolent administration since the 1950s the fact is that the people of Christmas Island have been exploited over the years for the benefit of the rest of us. A great injustice is now being done to them.

I refuse to believe that this island, situated where it is, a stone's throw from Asia, with tourist, postal and other earning potential, cannot provide a future in work and relative prosperity for its people.
The trouble is we have not applied our best minds and efforts to the task and we are taking the easy way out.

I hope the Senate will not take the easy way out. I hope that we can be involved in reinstating the elected assembly to speak on behalf of the local Christmas Islanders and that they can address this issue for themselves and set up, in the way that they think fit, the best format of tourism operation for their island.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that Senator Jenkins's hope is going to be a forlorn one, because the Opposition will be joining the Government to allow the Christmas Island casino to become a fact. We will do that for a number of reasons. The basic reason is that we want to offer a future and job prospects for the 1,000 islanders remaining on Christmas Island. Over the last two years the population has decreased from about 4,000 to a little under 1,000. The people who left did not want to get off the island. They were forced off it because there were no jobs, there was no future for their children, and there were no prospects. They were virtually taking in each other's washing and living on the dole. There were only a few service jobs on the island. There was massive unemployment for the remaining islanders. This side of the chamber cannot and will not tolerate that if there is another option open. A number of people have strong opinions against casinos; there would be a number in this Parliament. But the fact remains that in a referendum held on 19 April 1986 Christmas Islanders were asked to cast a vote on the following question:

SPEECH.PARA: Do you approve of the hotel/casino proposal for Christmas Island?

That question was asked in English, Chinese, and Malay. At the time there were 1,298 eligible voters; 1,172 were on the island on polling day and the number who voted was 955. Ninety-three per cent of those 955 people cast their vote for a casino as their only opportunity of sustaining their way of life and not living on hand outs, sit-down money or the dole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought Senator Jenkins said they did not want it.

—Senator Jenkins said they did not want it, but, of course, that is so incorrect. Ninety-three per cent of the people wanted it. We may have our views on this but surely the overriding democracy dictates that the will of the people has been established when 93 per cent of an island population casts a vote for a casino. Not only did 93 per cent of the people cast their vote for it; when the Assembly was still sitting, it passed a unanimous decision that a Christmas Island casino be established.
—Where is the Assembly now?
—It does not matter where the Assembly is now. It has nothing to do with it.
—It does to the Christmas Islanders.

—Senator Jenkins is trying to draw red herrings across the argument. Ninety-three per cent of the people wanted the Christmas Island casino. When the Assembly was sitting, it was a unanimous vote of the elected representatives of the people that they wanted a casino. Senator Jenkins comes into the Senate and tries to impose her will and the will of her party over the 93 per cent of the Christmas Islanders. The Democrats then had the audacity to stand up and propose a citizens' initiative referendum and fly right in the face of what the people want. I made a promise to myself that I would not be mean to the Democrats, that I would keep right away from that. But I cannot for the life of me understand how they can stand up in the Senate and say, `We want a citizens' initiative referendum' and in the next breath say, `We are not going to take cognisance of 93 per cent of the people on Christmas Island'. It is an absolute nonsense. I see Senator Robert Ray laughing and I can see the joke of it too because they have been caught out of bounds.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go into some other reasons why there is a need for a casino. Three inquiries have been called to map out a future for Christmas Island. Expressions of interest were called for and I understand that the only person who put his name forward was a Mr Woodmore, who has initiated a wonderful proposal. I have a picture of it here. It will certainly add to the island. It will give tourism a great boost up there. Christmas Island is only half an hour from Jakarta and, I think, only an hour from Singapore. Planes will fly from Western Australia into Christmas Island and then across to Singapore, bringing back a significant number of tourists, which will boost the Western Australian economy and open up a very significant tourist route from South East Asia. It is important for the Australian economy that our tourist industry is sustained and made grow. This development on Christmas Island will be another catalyst to promote the tourist industry predominantly in Western Australia. I hope that tourists will also come to my own State of Queensland. I hope they do, because they will always be welcome there.

The back of the brochure for the proposed Christmas Island casino outlines two unit developments offering cheaper backpacker-type accommodation to be opened up if the Christmas Island casino project goes ahead. We have received information that two other tourist ventures will start immediately if the Casino Control Ordinance is disallowed and the casino is allowed to be built on Christmas Island. Only the other day a book launch was held in Parliament House. I do not know whether Senator Jenkins was invited or whether she was too embarrassed to come. I did not see her there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't know about it.

—I am sorry that she was not there. I would have arranged an invitation for her because if she had been able to attend she would have been able to meet some expatriate Christmas Islanders. The book was launched by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). The 60 or 70 expatriate Christmas Islanders at the launch overwhelmingly said, as one voice, `The only thing that we have left is a casino. Please give it to us, and please give it to us as quickly as possible'. Senator Jenkins and the Australian Democrats have ignored their plea.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Woodmore is going to spend $2m as part of the proposal to develop the airstrip on Christmas Island. At present the airstrip has a black star rating, which means that people are allowed to fly in only on charter aircraft. The expenditure of $2m to upgrade the airport will allow Christmas Islanders and people who wish to visit the island to fly in in relative safety. This is something that they are not able to do at the moment. That is another area that this proposal will straighten out-a decent airport for Christmas Islanders.

I find it very difficult even to follow the argument of the Democrats. I am quite happy to support Senator Richardson. It is not with any great joy that we join hands across the chamber but I think that on occasions such as this we have to provide some future for the Islanders. I understand that the casino will employ 185 to 200 people. A great number of spin-off jobs will be created. One of the companies that are interested in mining on Christmas Island was very enthusiastic about the prospect of getting a decent airstrip which would allow it to fly in personnel and equipment. I was very happy to know that in a couple of weeks the green light would be given on this work. Other jobs will be created too. People will be needed to perform such jobs as mowing the airstrip. There will be additional jobs for people on the wharves. Fishermen will be needed to supply seafood to the patrons of the casino. There will be a great multiplier effect. In fact, I believe that with the casino and the restarting of the mine, albeit in a fairly limited way and only for an expected life span of five or six years, all unemployment will be mopped up on Christmas Island.

I believe that a great number of Christmas Islanders who have come to Australia are now finding that they want to return to the island. They want to go back to the place where they were born, to their home, and that is only natural. I believe that all of us want to do that. I think we will find that many of those people will re-establish their homes on Christmas Island once they are able to get meaningful work on the island. I am sorry, on behalf of the coalition, that I cannot support the disallowance motion of Senator Jenkins and the Democrats. I am quite happy to say on behalf of the coalition that we will provide those jobs and job opportunities for all those Christmas Islanders.

In closing, I point out that Mr Woodmore is providing the $28m. Not a cent is coming from the Australian Government in the way of subsidy. Mr Woodmore has made a commercial decision to spend that money. Whether he wins or loses, it is a commercial venture, the success of which only the market and his expertise will determine. We on this side of the Senate applaud that venture. It will create jobs, and such ventures are what make the Australian economy go round. We wish him all the best in his venture, which we hope is successful, profitable and will provide a future for all Islanders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —For at least a decade now various Federal Governments and Ministers, let alone Christmas Islanders themselves, have been pondering the future of Christmas Island. They have been trying to determine how best these people can live out their lives on the island of their choice. Of course, that is not easy when one sees the phosphate industry in decline and with obviously a very limited future. Given that that one single industry has provided the island with virtually all of its employment and its infrastructure, its decline means that an alternative must be sought. In seeking that alternative I do not believe that anyone has come up with a better idea than attempting to establish a viable tourist industry on Christmas Island. If we are to establish a viable tourist industry on Christmas Island, a resort-casino complex must be a central and integral part of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that there has been mention of Frank Woodmore, the developer. I think we should go back and look at the poll that was conducted with respect to his proposed development. On 19 April 1986 the Christmas Island Assembly, an advisory body, conducted a poll of island residents. All persons over 18 years and resident for at least three months were entitled to vote. Voting was by secret ballot. Of the 1,298 eligible voters, 1,172 were present on the island on the day of the poll and 955 voted. The results of the poll were that 896 voted `Yes' and 49 `No', with 10 informal votes. That result indicates resounding support in every way. I do not know how many referendum proposals could ever attract that sort of support. Voting was not compulsory yet 81 per cent of those registered actually voted, and 93 per cent of that 81 per cent voted in favour. So obviously on the island itself, there is very strong support for this development. In the end, one wonders how clever governments are in telling people what is good for them. Occasionally, perhaps, one must give the people a say and listen to their comments. I think the Christmas Islanders have made it very clear to the Government that they overwhelmingly support the going ahead of this proposal.

If one goes back to the original draft proposal and the way that the Government acted thereafter, contrary to Senator Jenkins's claims the proposal was subjected to an environmental impact assessment. It went through the rigours of Commonwealth legislation. In December 1986 the Government agreed that the proposal could proceed, and on 4 June 1987 the Commonwealth signed an agreement with the developer and his guarantors setting out the formal terms and conditions upon which the development could proceed. That agreement was tabled in Parliament on 7 October last year. We are told by the honourable senator that the Australian Democrats are concerned about the effects on the fauna on the island if the proposal proceeds. The Government has demonstrated time and time again that it shares a concern for flora and fauna and the natural environment.

The environmental impact assessment to which I just referred was conducted under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. The assessment included scrutiny by officers of both the then Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. That assessment concluded that, if a range of measures were put in place to protect the environment and in particular to protect the fauna on the island, the project could proceed. As a result of that, detailed environment protection measures were developed. The developer has agreed to implement those measures, and of course they were incorporated as formal requirements in the agreement of 4 June 1987. On the basis of the developer undertaking to protect the environment by fulfilling his obligations with these new protection measures, the then Minister for the Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, determined that the requirements of the Act had been met and that the project could go ahead.

It must be remembered that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has a conservator on the island full time. That person and the staff of the Service have been involved in every step of the development of this project. They will ensure that all these environment protection measures are met and fulfilled. Obviously Christmas Island is well known as the habitat and the breeding ground of a number of rare and endangered species. The Abbott's Booby bird is probably the most widely known of those species. We have recognised the particular importance of this area as a breeding ground for endangered species by declaring the Christmas Island National Park. It occupies 17 per cent of the land area of Christmas Island. However, I had discussions with my colleague the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) only a fortnight ago and as a result of those discussions there will be major extensions to the Christmas Island National Park. It will shortly encompass about 70 per cent of the land area of the island. The national park as extended will include all of the areas on the island that were identified in 1985 by an independent consultant as being habitats of national and international importance. Also included will be all areas of high conservation value and areas of high landscape value. The site for the resort and casino will not be within the proposed extended park boundaries.

For this development to take place and for a viable tourist industry to follow, obviously there will need to be significant improvements in the island's infrastructure. The agreement between the Commonwealth and the resort casino developer requires that a great many things be done, and I will mention a few. The developer must maintain, upgrade and operate the airport to an acceptable standard. He is required to provide his own water, his own sewerage works and his own electricity, all at his own cost. He must develop an international standard resort including the usual tourist facilities plus a casino and, importantly, he must pay a minimum of $1m a year as a licence fee or 10 per cent of the gross casino profit, whichever is greater.

The development is expected to employ between 200 and 300 people. It will create its own demand for tourist facilities, for shops, restaurants and other leisure activities, all of which will generate more employment. Potential developers have indicated that additional accommodation would be viable if the resort casino goes ahead. When one looks at the island one wonders just what else could be done to generate 200 or 300 new jobs. I do not know of any other proposal that could provide that sort of employment or a future for those islanders who wish to remain on Christmas Island.

A view has been expressed that the establishment of a casino in any community adds unacceptably to potential avenues for gambling. Legal casino-style gambling is already established on Christmas Island. It is part of the local community's culture. Obviously, the community does not believe that this new development will place any strain on its social or cultural values or system. Concerns has been expressed that casino gambling attracts organised crime. The Government obviously is mindful of those concerns. In addressing that issue, the arrangements for Government supervision of the Christmas Island casino are equal to, if not tougher than, any other jurisdiction in Australia, or for that matter in the world. One wonders what more the Government could be expected to do.

The Christmas Island Casino Control Ordinance has been drafted to include the most effective gaming controls implemented in other Australian jurisdictions. The Ordinance provides for a casino controller and inspectors to be appointed by the Minister to ensure the casino is operated in accordance with the Ordinance. In addition, the Ordinance creates an independent casino surveillance authority to advise the Minister on all aspects of the operation of the casino. These plans have been subjected to very close scrutiny by the Australian Federal Police, the Attorney-General's Department and other security organisations. The arrangements set out in the Christmas Island Casino Control Ordinance have been agreed to by all those authorities. The legislation has been developed to the requirements of the participating law enforcement agencies and those agencies will, of course, monitor the enforcement and effectiveness of all those arrangements.

The Christmas Island community has indicated, by secret ballot, its overwhelming support for the proposal. There is no other possibility for employment growth and security on Christmas Island. If this disallowance motion were successful, we would only doom the people left on Christmas Island to having no future at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Very briefly, what we are exhorting the Senate to do is hold elections for the people on Christmas Island to replace their elected Assembly and, at the request of the people, for that elected Assembly to monitor any tourism development which may or may not contain a casino. If that elected Assembly were there we would not be moving this disallowance motion at this stage. It is fully known in the Senate that if the disallowance motion proceeds at this stage, the matter can be brought on again within a few months.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have already spoken on this matter; I am not speaking in continuation. There is some question as to whether this matter should be deferred for a week to be dealt with next Wednesday. Perhaps the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) is in a position to indicate whether he wishes to continue now, in which case I would be perfectly happy to do so. However, if the Minister is agreeable to an adjournment, we could formally resolve to stand this matter over until Wednesday of next week.

—If I were in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in my old role as a union advocate, I would ask that we now go off the record and have a discussion between ourselves. Senator Puplick, Senator Coulter and I were just talking about whether this matter should be adjourned for a week. We are at sixes and sevens as to who wants to adjourn the discussion. The Government is happy to accommodate the adjournment of the matter. We are ready to proceed with the matter if there is a desire, on the part of the parties, that we dispose of it this morning. In terms of adjourning this matter, I acknowledge that in the past it has suited the Government to have it adjourned and the Opposition has accommodated us. We are prepared to accommodate any call from either side for an adjournment this morning. I guess I am just batting the ball back in trying to get something sorted out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be adjourned until Wednesday, 30 November.

I indicate that the primary reason for seeking a further adjournment is that this matter is still being argued today before the Federal Court. I believe that the court proceedings will conclude today. There is some dispute as to when the court will deliver judgment in the matter, but regardless of the court's timetable I certainly give the assurance that we will be in a position to deal with this on Wednesday of next week.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the adjournment of the matter. We understand that while there is some doubt as to whether judgment will be given before the Senate has to decide this matter of disallowance formally, there is at least an outside chance that that judgment might be given in time. Therefore, it would be appropriate for this matter to be dealt with when there has been an opportunity for that to occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, before you call the motion for voting, I should indicate that we will also agree to the adjournment. I acknowledge that the parties have been very helpful in sorting out a time when this debate can best be held. I accept the reason put forward by Senator Puplick.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to my contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Jenkins moving a motion to provide for the consideration of the Government Bills together with the following private Senator's Bills:

That Order of the Day relating to the following private Senator's Bills:

Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill 1988, clause 15 to end;
Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988;
Australian Capital Territory (Establishment and Amendment of new Constitution) Bill 1988;
Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill 1988;
Australian Capital Territory (Open Government, Probity and Citizen's Rights) Bill 1988; and
A.C.T. Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure of the Government's view on this matter but the Opposition's view is that the Bills should be debated cognately. It seems to me that it would be the most expeditious way of dealing with the matters. I am concerned about the proposed order of dealing with the Bills at the committee stage. As I understand it, the Australian Democrats are seeking to intersperse their Bills not only between various Government Bills but also within the Government Bills. This matter could become complex. I feel that the proposal will unfortunately have that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that I understand the reason why the Democrats are seeking to do this. They believe that their Bills relate to particular matters that exist within the Government Bills. However, as one who tries to make life as simple as possible, I would have thought that the best course of action would be to dispose of the package of the four Government Bills and then to move on and deal with the Democrats' three Bills. During the course of the second reading debate, and no doubt during parts of the debate in committee on the Government Bills, it will become apparent whether or not the Democrats' committee amendments in their Bills are going to serve any purpose at all. Certainly, my suggestion is that a cognate debate take place but that in committee the Bills be dealt with in the order of the four Government Bills and then the three Australian Democrats Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill, if you are of that view, you will have to move an amendment to leave out the final part of Senator Jenkins's motion.
—We might first get the Government's view on this, to see whether or not that course of action is worth while.

—I think the view expressed by Senator Hill coincides with the Government's perception of what is the best way of dealing with this matter. I think it is true that after a cognate debate it will become clear what the fate of this legislation is likely to be. For the sake of good management, clean housekeeping and a fair go for all, it is probably better to deal with the matter in the way in which Senator Hill has suggested.
—Senator Hill, will you now move that Senator Jenkins's motion be amended to leave out all reference to discussion of the Bills in committee?
—I can move a motion in such terms or, alternatively, I can invite the Democrats to perhaps delete the latter part of their amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, in fact, I intend to support my motion. We suggested this order of dealing with the Bills during the committee stage simply to avoid what Senator Hill has said he wants to avoid-that is, we want to make life less complex and easier for all of us concerned here. We have a number of complex Bills and literally buckets of amendments, and I think that, if they are to be dealt with logically and we are to avoid going around in ever-decreasing circles, the order that I have proposed for debate of the Bills in committee is a logical and rational order which I ask the Senate to support.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (by Senator Hill) agreed to:
Leave out all words after `separately'.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate commences, I table the revised explanatory memoranda relating to the Government Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a series of Bills relating to the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), including four Government Bills that are intended to introduce a system of self-government into the ACT and obviously provide a framework in which it would operate. In addition, the Senate is now also debating three Australian Democrats' Bills that are also relevant to the subject of self-government and the structure under which it would operate.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess that there is an element of history in all legislation that passes through this chamber, but that must be accentuated in the situation of legislation that establishes any new form of self-government in our country. That, as I have indicated, is the purpose of these Bills, and I think we are all conscious of that element of history. There has gone before a long process of development of legislation to this day, a process with which I have not had a close association for more than the past couple of months, but both within and without the chamber there are those in the ACT and politicians in this Parliament who have been closely associated with this process of development towards self-government.

As to my position in this matter, I would like to put on record that the negotiating process has, in my view, been simplified, in part because the Opposition parties, the Liberal and National parties, together with the Government and the Australian Democrats, have approached this development, at least in recent times, on the basis that we want to achieve self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. With that common objective, the challenge has therefore been simply to find a form in which that can operate and which has the approval certainly of the major parties and, hopefully, of all parties concerned.

Also, at this stage I want to put on record my appreciation for the way in which the office of Minister for the Arts and Territories, as well as the Minister's staff and officials of the ACT Administration, have negotiated with me. It has been a positive and constructive process of development. Also, I must say that in my dealings Senator Jenkins and the Australian Democrats have also been positive and constructive. This makes what could be an enormously complex task considerably easier.

In view of the history to which I referred a moment ago, I also want to pay a tribute to my predecessor in this position as Opposition spokesman on the ACT, Senator Amanda Vanstone, whose mark is also on this legislative package. I also pay tribute to my colleague Senator Margaret Reid, who has been associated over many years with the development of what we will regard as a good system of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. On our side, we regard Senator Reid as our local member for the ACT and have to lean upon her extensively. In our view, she plays a very significant role within our parties and in this Parliament to the benefit of the people of the ACT.

We have advocated self-government for the Australian Capital Territory for a number of reasons. The first is that it will allow direct democratic input into the functions of government that effect the everyday lives of citizens of the Territory-whether they be in health, education, transport, or any of the other areas of government that are so relevant to the lifestyle of individuals. Unfortunately, to date, the citizens of the ACT have not had that direct input in the way that is open to citizens of the States of Australia and also, of recent years, to citizens of the Northern Territory.

I think the result has been some frustration. All of us who live in Canberra or who come to Canberra every week know of criticisms of a number of aspects of the provision of government services in the Territory. As I have just indicated, there has not been the same potential for the community to act in a democratic way to resolve these problems as applies in the States of Australia. Following self-government, that opportunity will be open to the citizens of the ACT. If citizens are unhappy with the health service, they will have their own representatives in their own self-governing body to whom they can make representations, apply pressure and, hopefully, produce the results that they are seeking.

Secondly, we are supporting self-government because it seems obvious to us, and I think it should be obvious to anybody, that we are entering a time of much greater financial constraint within the ACT. The Commonwealth Grants Commission, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, has recently put down reports that deal with the ACT. The 1986-87 figures would appear to indicate that after the Commonwealth paying for normal Commonwealth functions and for the operation of this Parliament, and on top of local taxes, there is a shortfall figure, which at the moment is made up by the Commonwealth, of approximately $80m. We have received representations from concerned individuals in the ACT that there are deficiencies in those assessments. The Grants Commission certainly acknowledges that there are shortcomings in those figures relative to a lack of certain basic information.

The important point I want to make is that up till now there has been no independent body that can argue the case on behalf of the ACT community in that regard, either as to why the Grants Commission might be in error in making those assessments or as to why perhaps the Commonwealth on those figures may not be meeting its full responsibility. It seems to me that as we move into this period of greater financial constraint, an independent body on behalf of the ACT that can properly represent the citizens of the Territory in negotiations with the Commonwealth, in the same way as each of the State governments can do in relation to their citizens, is going to be critically important for the people of the Territory. That is the second reason why I think self-government is going to be vitally important for the Territory in the future.

The third reason, I have to say with some regret, is that unfortunately there is a neglect in deliberations and concerns on local matters that affect the ACT within this Parliament. I guess that is not surprising because most of us come here with particular interests in national and Commonwealth matters. But it is absolutely clear that local, domestic concerns do not receive anything like the same level of attention and treatment that they receive in the States or in the Northern Territory. As I indicated when I paid tribute to Senator Reid a moment ago-and I look across the chamber and see Senator McMullan-an enormous weight is therefore placed upon the very few representatives of the ACT in this Parliament and, of course, they can do only so much. Those local issues that I have mentioned-health, education, transport, et cetera-tend not to be debated in this Parliament, but if they do get debated, the debates-are superficial by nature of the other preoccupations of this place. It therefore seems to me that better service through proper accountability and direct representation must follow from self-government.

I have to admit that I was staggered when I learnt a couple of months ago that there is a staff of some 17,000 in the ACT Administration. That struck me as a very large bureaucracy and clearly it is a bureaucracy that has been neglected by this Parliament. Under a self-governing body, directly concerned with the provision of its own services, there will be much greater accountability in that regard. That will be good for the staff members who will no doubt feel that their contributions are being better acknowledged and rewarded, and it will be better for the local community, through the principles of accountability in democratic government. With a staff of 17,000 and a budget of over $1 billion, we are actually looking at large numbers of people and a large amount of money. That is the third reason why we on this side of the chamber came to the firm view that the time for self-government had come.

I recognise that a great deal of work has been done in the last few years to facilitate the process of self-government in the ACT. The consolidation of functions into one administration and into one budget has made it much easier for us to properly appreciate what will be transferred from the Commonwealth to the new State administration. I acknowledge the work that has been done in that regard. For our benefit and for the benefit of the people of the ACT the whole picture is much clearer than it perhaps was a few years ago. So in many ways these Bills today are the culmination of many years of work by many people, whether they are in the administration, in the political process or in the political parties. I guess that is all part of the history of today's debate.

What I propose to do, relatively briefly, is to run through the more significant pro- visions of the four Government Bills, and particularly those that have been the subject of debate and those that are are being amended as a result of matters that we have pressed upon the Government. I am pleased to be able to say that most matters that we have pressed upon the Government, it has now accepted either fully or in a compromised form. So we will in fact be able to support all of the Government's amendments. There will be only a couple of extra amendments that we will seek, but many of those Government amendments that we will be supporting in fact are as a result of long discussions that have taken place between the parties and compromises which we believe will be in the best interests of the ACT.

The first of the Bills, the critical one, is the Australian Capital Territory (Self- Government) Bill, which will establish a Legislative Assembly of 17 members. The number has been the subject of argument. We think it is an appropriate size for the ACT. If it were much smaller we would not get a fair representation of different views. If it were much larger it would, at this stage, look like overgovernment. There is no perfect number and it therefore seems to us to be a reasonable compromise. Similarly, an Executive of four Ministers seems to us to be an appropriate number to adequately conduct the responsibility of the Executive for the ACT. The Chief Minister will be elected by the Assembly. The indication from that is that we ultimately decided against pressing what we thought at one stage might be the best course, and that was to have a Chief Minister elected at large. We determined in the end that it would be better if the Chief Minister was elected from those who are in turn elected directly by the people of the ACT.

The Assembly may be dissolved by the Governor-General in certain circumstances. I guess this was the first of the controversial issues, because it gave the Governor-General power to dissolve the Assembly if he determines or, in other words, if the Government of the Commonwealth determines, that `the Assembly is incapable of effectively performing its functions, or is conducting its affairs in a grossly improper manner'. Some within the ACT regard that as somewhat paternalistic. We determined in the end, and our approach has been consistently cautious, that that safeguard should be retained, at least for the time being. It might be that, after a period of satisfactory operation of the new form of self-government, we on this side of the chamber would look to deleting such safeguards which certainly do not exist in relation to a State. But we have adopted a step by step approach and therefore we have accepted that that safeguard be continued for the time being.

The Governor-General also retains a power to make ordinances. We were concerned about that. It seemed too simple a process for the Executive of this Government to make ordinances that overrode the local Assembly's enactments. We therefore negotiated with the Government and the Government has agreed that the ordinance making power of the Commonwealth will be limited to its national functions and will not apply in relation to Territory functions. We think that that is a satisfactory compromise with regard to the second of those controversial issues.

There will be a fixed term of government. We have supported a fixed term in this instance, although some might say that is moving away from the position we have adopted in the past. However, we believed in the unique circumstances of this body, with its local connotations which, in some ways, make it similar to local government elsewhere-of course, it is a blend of what we might see elsewhere as a local government or State government-that a fixed term is the most appropriate. However, we argued-I think this comes under the provisions of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill-that the term of government should be reduced from four years to three; that if we were to have a fixed term three years was a satisfactory period. The Government has agreed to that.

We were concerned, as were many people within the Territory, by the provisions that dealt with a new form of bureaucrat, to be titled the Head of Administration, who seemed to have functions and capacities that went beyond the normal Westminster system of accountability between a Minister and a head of department. I am pleased to say that as a result of that the Government has agreed to amendments that will restrict the functions of that person, basically either to those given by the new Legislative Assembly or in accordance with the operation of the public service of the new Assembly. We regard that as a satisfactory resolution.

The last amendment to the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill, which we will be pressing, which the Government does not concede, not because it does not accept the amendment's merits but because it believes that the matter is adequately covered elsewhere in law, concerns the excluding of this Parliament from local domestic laws passed by the Territory Assembly because of the unusual circumstances in which we operate-our unusual hours and, perhaps, the unusual obligations that we place on staff of this place, which might well run counter to domestic industrial laws, for example. It obviously remains a major responsibility of ours to ensure the proper functioning of this Parliament. We will be moving an amendment to ensure that there is no ambiguity in that regard. As I said, I understand that the Government accepts the principle of what we state; it simply believes that it is adequately covered elsewhere.

The second Bill, the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988, sets up the electoral system. I guess this Bill has been the subject of most debate within the ACT community. We have accepted in the end, after a long period of debate, that there should simply be one electorate for the ACT. I indicated earlier that we are looking at a unique city State environment-unique in terms of Australia, although not unique worldwide. The objective was to find an electoral system that particularly suited those unique circumstances, and in the end we accepted that there should be one electorate.

We have since had a long public debate about the most appropriate electoral system within that one electorate-whether we should pursue a Senate-type system, some other proportional representation (PR) system or whether we should move to something that is unique. In the end we were persuaded to accept a form of the d'Hondt electoral system-a popular European system for houses of government. Our concerns with the PR system are that it is a house of government that will be elected. The Assembly will have only a small number of elected representatives-17 in all. Our concern was that either a direct Senate-type system or a PR system would have the effect that the Government could be controlled by one or two elected representatives representing single interest groups or particular interests of the day. We did not think such a system would have the best chance of leading to stable government. In this exercise we are seeking for ACT self-government not only democracy but also stability.

The d'Hondt system is a proven system for houses of government. Obviously I do not have time to go through the structure, but I concede that it has been principally developed as a party-type system. Not surprisingly, there are those on our side of the chamber who, as we tend to be made up of individualists, have said that for us to support such a system there must be modifications to allow an adequate expression of the preference of individuals. That has now been accommodated in three ways, through a long series of negotiations and compromises, in a form that we now regard as satisfactory.

The first compromise is that whereas under the d'Hondt system small interest groups normally are excluded unless they achieve the `drop quota', those who vote for such small groups will now have their second preferences consolidated with the major parties or major independents so that their votes will not be lost. That is the first compromise, in accordance with our political psychology, that we think is wise. I understand that in Europe those votes are simply excluded and that further preferences do not come into the count. In this instance they will.

Secondly, the Government has been prepared to agree to preferences being expressed and counted within parties. I think that this system has been adopted within only one of the European states. Certainly, it is unusual in the European context. Of course, it makes us much more comfortable.
