I note that none of my Tasmanian colleagues are in the chamber at the moment but Tasmanians, for example, sometimes do not much like following the party line. They will vote for candidates within a party but will want to establish their own order. We want the same flexibility within this system, and now there will be.

As to the third and last modification the Government has accepted, there can now be one expression of preference for individuals across party lines. That expression of preference for an individual will take precedence over an indication of a party vote. We think that that adequately allows for the individuality of the voter, who can express a particular voting objective within the d'Hondt system. We think that ultimately we have produced a form of the system, much compromised to meet the Australian political background, psychology and culture, that will be satisfactory.

I have mentioned that there is to be a fixed term of government and that we are supporting that. However, we are not supporting the Government's intention that the first election be publicly funded. That is consistent with positions we have taken in the past. However, if the Australian Democrats are consistent with their previous positions, we are likely to lose that matter. Nevertheless, we believe that the public purse should not be used in that way. Of course, after the first election the Territory itself will determine its own practices in that regard and will be accountable to its own voters for the costs involved.

The third of the Bills is the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill 1988, a critically important Bill which will divide the National Capital Development Commission into two bodies, one dealing with national capital planning matters and headed by a National Capital Planning Authority which will establish a national plan, and the second a Territory Planning Authority which will deal with Territory planning matters. I do not have time to deal with the structure of that Bill in any detail. However, I will say that in our view it maintains extensive powers in the Commonwealth. Some feel that a little too much power is retained to the Commonwealth function. Nevertheless, as I said, this is a cautious approach and, looking at our primary responsibilities in relation to the national capital aspect of the ACT and our national responsibility in that regard, we on this side of the chamber have endorsed that approach. I will deal with some matters in the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill at the committee stage. The ACT Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Bill deals with incidental matters and I do not have time to consider them at this moment. The Opposition is pleased to be able to support the second reading of the Bills. We look forward to the committee stage of the debate. We are confident that at the end of the committee stage we will be able to support the third reading of the Bills and, therefore, the ACT will achieve self-government.

Apart from the electoral system and the question of financial relations with the Commonwealth, the other major area of debate has been the transfer of appropriate functions. It was intended by the Government that a number of functions which one would normally believe were appropriate to self-government not be transferred; for instance policing functions, criminal law, legal practitioners and the courts. It has been very difficult to determine a sound reason for that failure to transfer, but as a result of negotiations the Government is now prepared, as of a date in 1990, to agree to have all of those functions, except the courts, transferred. It would like the courts question to remain open for further consideration. Short of any valid argument that the Government is able to put up for that exclusion we would still seek the transferal of the courts, but we would accept the date of 1990 which applies to the other functions. So if we were talking about making proper arrangements with judges for their tenure or other Commonwealth responsibilities, that would allow more than adequate time to address those matters.

I have mentioned the unique circumstances of the ACT and the efforts that have had to be made to meet those unique circumstances. They are unique not only because of our constitutional responsibility for the national capital but also because of the geographical nature of a city State within Australia. I therefore confirm our support for the package as a whole and our hope that self-government in the ACT will be productive, useful and efficient. Certainly we intend to monitor closely the operation of these proposed laws. As I have indicated, we will be flexible in the future and will look at further adaptations of them to suit a maturing self-government environment. We are not bound in any way. We see this as one critical step within an ongoing process. On behalf of the Opposition, I wish self-government in the ACT a long and useful future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately seven Bills which will enable a suitable framework to be put into place for self-government for the people of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). The Government's Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill, the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill and the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill were introduced into the House of Representatives on 19 October-just a month ago. The Government's fourth Bill-the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Bill-was introduced into the House of Representatives on 1 November. The Australian Capital Territory (Open Government, Probity and Citizens' Rights) Bill, the Australian Capital Territory (Protection of the National Interest) Bill and the Australian Capital Territory (Establishment and Amendment of New Constitution) Bill were introduced into the Senate by me, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, on 8 November-just two weeks ago. Just a short while ago I heard that the Government intends to introduce a revised explanatory memorandum, which will be available to honourable senators tomorrow.

SPEECH.PARA: Going through the history of this legislation, I found myself in the fortunate position of being assigned the Australian Democrats' Territories portfolio when I first became a member of this place some 15 or 16 months ago. At that time the words `self-government' were on everybody's lips. Self-government and self-management were obviously needed by the people here. That was demonstrated to me very early on by a number of ACT residents, in steady succession, beating a path to my door. Without exception, the issues they raised were local ones that should have been addressed by their locally elected representatives who were directly responsible to them. However, the matters that concerned those ACT residents were being decided by Federal Parliament legislation, which at least is democratic and open; by ordinance or regulation, which is not so democratic and not so open; or by a stroke of the current Minister's pen on the advice of the ACT bureaucracy. That last method of making changes is the most objectionable and the least democratic.

During the time that I have been involved in this portfolio, on behalf of the Democrats, not one of the three Ministers or the two Opposition shadow Ministers, or I, have been directly voted into this Parliament by the people of the ACT, although I am sure that we have all done our best in the areas with which we have been concerned. At last self-government is about to come to fruition. It is unfortunate that not all the people of the ACT feel that it should. According to the result of a poll which was published in last Sunday's Canberra Times, a fair proportion of people still feel that they do not need it or want it. However, it may well be that the question put by the Canberra Times should have been framed somewhat differently. Perhaps people should have been asked whether they want the responsibility of self-government, self-management or self-determination. If we look back we see that people have given their lives for such rights. The suffragettes fought for it. When the Aboriginal and Torres Straits Islander Commission is set up, the Aboriginal people will have their first direct taste of it. I might add that a Senate-style electoral system is regarded by the Government as being suitable for our Aboriginal population when its own commission is set up.

I give the Government credit for the degree to which it has moved from the mean and grudging half-hearted self-government offer which was first put forward in 1986. In particular, credit must be given to the Government for agreeing to accept that the ACT must be a body politic. That is a major development. It represents recognition that the ACT is a significant and self-contained community, in addition to its other concurrent characteristics. The Government has also agreed that the electoral system for the ACT should be based on proportional representation. With severely muted enthusiasm, I applaud it for that decision. My enthusiasm is muted because the Government has identified and has proposed the only obnoxious form of proportional representation that I have ever heard of. In fact, we all rushed off to the textbooks when the word `d'Hondt' was first brought up. The d'Hondt system has now been consolidated and modified, but I can assure the Senate that the electoral reform societies all over Australia continue to tear out their hair about it. We are surprised that such a system has been brought in. I wish to quote from the Australian Labor Party's Platform Resolutions and Rules of 1988. Resolution No. 32 states:
Labor supports the adoption of a system of optional preferential voting for all elections with all votes remaining valid while the voter's intention is clear.

Although the d'Hondt system has been modified and adapted, it is still not a system where all votes remain valid while the voter's intention is clear. That is simply not so in that system, although a number of amendments will be moved during the committee stage which I hope will rectify that.

A further matter on which some progress has been made relates to the arrangements for the ACT to be treated fairly in financial matters. The Australian Democrats welcome the fact that it is acknowledged to be appropriate for this need to be recognised in legislation and regret the Government's apparent unwillingness to address the matter more comprehensively.

Another matter for which the Government deserves credit is its recognition of the commonsense of presenting the self-government proposals as a package of separate and self-contained but related Bills. This will greatly facilitate the debate, especially during the committee stage. Even more importantly, it will lead to legislation which I believe will be user-friendly and comprehensible to the person in the street. I must state that I am disappointed that my recommendation for the order of debate of the Bills in the committee stage was not accepted by the Senate. I believe that that would have helped the debate to be completed in a more efficient manner.

I would also like at this point to join Senator Hill in saying that the negotiations which I have had with Ministers and shadow Ministers on this matter during the last 15 or 16 months have for the most part been cordial, although it was apparent to me that I was working from a different ideological base. I had some surprises there; I was surprised to find how close the Government and the Opposition were in certain matters.

Having said all these things and having given the Government credit for the respects in which it has advanced its position to the benefit of the people of the ACT, I must record a fundamental concern about the processes which have been followed. I must also record a deep-seated sense of unease about what I refer to as the flavour of the legislation.

This Parliament should squarely acknowledge major defects in the processes by which this legislation has been prepared. I believe that we should acknowledge these defects for two reasons: first, in a curious mirror-image sort of a way, it highlights or exemplifies one of the major reasons why ACT self-government is so important and so needed; and, second, it emphasises the heavy responsibility which we carry in this place to check through the Bills with care, paying attention to the detail as well as to the self-evidently important elements.

The defect to which I refer and to which Senator Hill has already referred is the total absence of local citizen input into this legislation. We do not have the elected representatives of the people of the ACT able to be the main players in this because the former ACT Assembly was allowed to lapse a couple of years ago, which has meant that locally there has not been any group of aware and elected citizens, with support staff and an acknowledged mandate from their fellow citizens, to negotiate the detailed arrangements for self-government on behalf of ACT residents.

I pay tribute to the superb job done by Rosemary Nairn and her team in the ACT Self-Government Campaign Committee. Many honourable senators here will gratefully acknowledge the quality of the representations they made, but their actions were just that-representations made from outside the processes. They were not inputs made within these processes. My concern is that this major and wholly unfortunate defect in the process may be connected with another apparent element which causes me to have a sense of unease. There is something about this whole package of legislation which seems to me to denote a Public Service derived package of Bills, rather than a government package or elected parliamentary representative package.

As I will indicate later, there are ways in which these Bills are severely defective. I and the Australian Democrats have struggled hard with the task of identifying how these defects could be said to fit in with any elements or tenets of Australian Labor Party policy or with the policy of any major ALP factions. I have already read out one relevant ALP resolution. I have been unsuccessful in identifying any way in which the defects in these Bills-other than those related to the electoral system-benefit the ALP as a party or as a government. I have therefore formed the conclusion-and I hope I am not being unduly charitable here-that there are provisions in the Bills inserted by the ACT Administration in the interests of that Administration, or in the interests of that monolith which we in this place sometimes refer to as `the bureaucracy'.

The unusual earlier proposed arrangement for a super-bureaucrat is a case in point. This has already been modified somewhat by the Government since it was drawn to its attention by various groups. Another case in point is the extent to which the executive arm of government, which of course acts on the advice of the bureaucracy, has opportunities to intervene in and to overturn decisions made by the ACT legislature, although this too has been modified by the Government following representations.

The concerns and apprehensions which I have pointed out lead to a major point which I want to make about the context in which we are operating. The very broad outlines of the Government's proposals have been known for many months, but the substance of the proposals has been known for only a short time. Considering their complexity, the amount of new material not contained in the discussion papers, and the fact that amendments were coming in very late on Monday evening, I think this may lead us to some complexities during the committee stage.

The detailed arrangements for planning in the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill and the 41 pages of intricate but vital proposals in the Australian Capital Territory Self-Government (Consequential Provisions) Bill, which came in later than the others, are of great importance to this Parliamant and to the people of the ACT. At one stage it appeared that we might be expected to handle these complex issues with a very short lead-up time. As I said before, these issues are very complex and very important to the people of the ACT and they deserve to be dealt with properly and cautiously. Indeed, all of us here are expected during the committee stage to analyse the various amendments with great care and, at the end of it all, to come out with a total package of correct legislation. I hope that that will be the case. Although, as I said before, we have great complexities and a great number of amendments before us, I hope that they all can be dealt with properly.

Our discussions relating to all seven Bills before us will be facilitated, I believe, if we first identify the principles that should apply to these Bills. We should then, in my view, carefully check each Bill to discover to what extent it is consistent with those principles. I wish to propose several principles which the Senate might require the Bills to comply with: The principle that the electoral system applied should ensure to ACT residents a right to fairness in the electoral process no less than that right enjoyed in other parts of Australia; the principle that the ACT should have the maximum degree of autonomy that is consistent with the national and regional interest; the principle that in the case of the Australian Capital Territory, as with other jurisdictions, the general principle should be that there may not be interference with a legislature by an executive, and particularly not by the executive of another level of government-I am referring here, of course, to the Federal Government; the principle to protect the prerogatives of the national Parliament in relation to the national capital; the principle that the legislation must ensure proper financial protection for the ACT, protection which acknowledges the general processes of the Grants Commission and, in particular, areas during the transitional stages, which I know are of concern to some people; the principle that there must be statutory guarantees of proper consultation between the national and territorial planning authorities, and processes for negotiated outcomes, wherever possible, in the case of conflict; the principle that the ACT legislature should have the right to determine, not merely to advise on, the form of executive government and administration the Territory should have; the principle that open government, probity and civil rights must be guaranteed in the national capital; and the principle that the people of the ACT, through their legislature, must have an opportunity to establish a Constitution of their own choice.

The general character of the amendments that I will be moving to the Government's Bills will be to ensure that the principles I have mentioned are more adequately reflected in the legislation finally adopted. Where it is necessary to do so I will also be seeking Senate endorsement for my supplementary and complementary Bills which I believe represent a sensible way of attending to some of the errors in and omissions from the Government's Bills. I will also be supporting some of the amendments to be moved by Senator Hill. I would here like to acknowledge the roles that he and Senator Reid have played in identifying improvements to the Bills before us.

Notwithstanding the support for the Opposition's contribution in other respects, the first matter that I wish to address at this point is one on which an unholy alliance seems to have developed between the Government and the Opposition, and I refer to the question of the electoral system. The Government seeks to make much of the degree of flexibility it has shown, but unfortunately its credibility in this area is akin to that of a slave trader who claims credit for having reduced his annual trade from 10,000 brutalised victims to a mere 3,000. This is the form of flexibility that I believe the Government has shown on the electoral system. I draw the attention of honourable senators to one key deficiency in the present proposals-the way candidates not achieving a quota are all excluded at one time. Senator Hill has applauded that. I simply cannot do that. I would, in support, like to read from an article by Geoffrey Goode, who is President of the Proportional Representation Society of Australia, in yesterday's Canberra Times. He said:

The ``consolidated d'Hondt'' system being foisted on the ACT discriminates blatantly against independent candidates or small parties by excluding them from the count if they do not reach a quota as first preferences, ie they are not allowed to interchange preferences to build up a quota for one of them, but their votes are arbitrarily directed to one of their much lower preferences. Just as outrageous is the proposal that surplus votes received by an independent or a party are to be disregarded. All this legislatively-prescribed disregarding of votes can readily enable a minority of actual votes to become a ``majority'' of ``approved'' votes, ie those votes not disregarded. Such a ``majority'' then elects a real majority of Assembly members.

If the proven successes of the Tasmanian system are to be ignored, the very least the Senate can do for ACT democracy is to amend the ACT Electoral Bill to require the use of Senate-style quota-preferential voting, which does allow full and free transfer of each voter's preferences, but to forego that system's accreted restrictions.

I will be moving an amendment which will cope in part with that, whatever is the final electoral system decided by this place. At this stage, in relation to the motion that the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill be now read a second time, I move:

Leave out all words after `That', insert, `consideration of the Second Reading of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988 be an Order of the Day for 2 sitting days after today to enable the Government to prepare amendments to provide for the operation, in the ACT, of the `Robson Amendment' form of printing and distributing ballot papers as used in Tasmania, being provision which, to the maximum extent possible, will have application regardless of the particular method adopted for the marking and counting of ballot papers'.

In that way, whichever is the final electoral system which is decided by this place, at least if we are landed with a party vote system the names of the candidates can then be rotated on the ballot papers so people have the chance to vote for the candidate of their choice.

Another matter which I wish to address is the difficulty that the Government-or is it the bureaucracy?-has had in granting the new legislature immunity from interference by the executive arm of government. Proposals are contained in the Bills for the Federal executive to have the right to dismiss the ACT legislature, to disallow ACT enactments, and to override ACT laws by continued use of the ordinance-making process. Who would prepare, I ask the Senate, the material considered in these regards by the Federal Executive Council and the Governor-General; material, by the way, which is not to be made public and which is not subject to corrections of errors, bias or selectivity? Of course, that material would be prepared by the bureaucracy.

We have often enough seen situations in which we must stand up for the rights of legislatures, for the rights of those who are electorally accountable for their dealings with bureaucracies. On behalf of the Australian Democrats I shall therefore be moving amendments to protect the rights of communities which vote to have matters determined by the people they vote for.

Another matter to be addressed is the extent and nature of the powers the ACT legislature should have. This raises questions such as the range of matters on which the legislature should have powers to act. I will be addressing these matters and moving amendments during the committee stage of the debate.

More important is the question of the right of the legislature to determine and to change the form of the executive government and the form of administration which it wishes to have. The present Government Bills are wrong-headed, in my view, in considering it appropriate for this Parliament to specify detailed arrangements in these regards and again I shall be moving amendments. Interim arrangements can fairly be put in place, but to specify that these arrangements cannot be changed without the approval of the national government, even with respect to whether the number of territorial Ministers should be three, four or five, is in my view to inflict an inappropriate, nitpicking form of interference.

The Government has made what I consider a real dog's dinner of the planning arrangements. The present National Capital Development Commission should have continued for another 12 months or so, because at the very time when the work load for the new ACT legislature will be the greatest it will have to sort out as a matter of urgency details of the new planning system. We are refusing it the opportunity to develop and adjust the existing arrangements and to take part in negotiating more far-reaching arrangements at a sensibly dated later stage.

Further, even at this point we do not know what is to be in the complementary Interim Territory Planning Ordinance referred to in clause 58 of the Planning and Land Management Bill. Maybe in the committee stage we can learn something of that.

For the reasons that I have outlined, we must ensure that ACT self-government is achieved without delay, but it must be achieved within the right framework for the people of the ACT. I think all of us in this place must rise to that challenge. As I said, I believe we will be very busy during the committee stage. I believe the Minister at that stage will be Senator Richardson. He will have the advisers there, some of whose faces I know so well. We will also have Senator Hill for the Opposition and I have the fullest confidence in him, expecially after he was described by the shadow Minister in the other place as `Senator Hill, the shadow Minister for the Australian Capital Territory, with a bottomless pit of knowledge on this subject'. No doubt we will manage the committee stage quite adequately because of that.

The self-government of the ACT involves the putting into place of the last remaining segment of the overall constitutional arrangements of our nation. This is the first of the major reasons for the ACT self-government being important. We are at long last moving to complete a process that was commenced nearly 100 years ago. The constitutional arrangements to be applied to the national capital of that then new nation are now, it seems, at last to be put into place.

It is also the case that in the ACT there is a large population to be reprieved from feudalism-a population two-thirds the size of that of Tasmania; a population living without basic human rights in a curious form of medieval fiefdom. This is the second reason why ACT self-government is so important. Without self-government, at least 300,000 Australians will continue to live in an autocracy, denied the right to self-management as a community, a right taken for granted in all other parts of Australia.

There is, as well, the challenge of the complexities to be balanced as the ACT takes up its democratic inheritance. The ACT is three things in one: it is a major self-contained discrete State-type community in its own right; it is the centre of a coherent wider region, suppling major services to that region and providing major facilities used by that region; and it is the national capital. Balancing these three characteristics in a coherent package of self-government proposals is a task worthy of the close attention of the Senate. That is the third reason why ACT self-government is so important. It involves the making of judgments and the achieving of balances which deserve and need the scrutiny of all honourable senators.

On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I wish the ACT well in its quest for the correct framework for self-government and for the setting up of that self-government in its early stages and its first election next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a package of seven Bills, four Government Bills outlining the arrangements for Australian Capital Territory (ACT) self-government as proposed by the Australian Labor Party and the Government and, cognately, three Bills proposed by the Australian Democrats. I should say at the outset that obviously I will be supporting the four Government Bills and opposing the three Bills proposed by the Australian Democrats. Before I deal with them in detail I should like to comment on the somewhat paradoxical situation in which I find myself, and in which I think Senator Reid also finds herself. We are in a sense dealing with a matter of national significance. As Senator Jenkins said, it is the last stage in the democratic transition extending to all parts of Australia, with the exception of a few very minor territories, the rights of self-determination and accountability that are inherent in our otherwise democratic Constitution. For that reason it is an important national step.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very historic change for the ACT, for my constituents, and a matter of great importance to me as a citizen here and as a representative of this Territory. So, in one sense, we have before the Senate a matter of very great interest and importance to it. However, I have to say to my colleagues, other than Senator Reid, that in a very profound sense we also have a situation which is none of their business. With one significant exception which relates to the planning elements, where there is a profound national interest, all the other matters really have nothing to do with the rest of my colleagues. Most of them have reflected that in the marked lack of interest that they have shown in the matter, about which I am not the slightest bit critical.

However, in noting that paradox, it is important to note that one of the reasons I am supporting the legislation is that it will lead to a situation in which legislation of importance to the ACT is dealt with by people whose business it properly is. It will also be important for the Senate. It will liberate the Senate from some of the lengthy debates, such as that recently on the casino, on issues which are also none of its business. As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I have to say that it will make a significant difference to the capacity of that Committee to deal with all the other important pieces of delegated legislation which come before it because it will not have to deal with the welter of ACT ordinances. For example, both the House of Representatives and the Senate Standing Committees on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure will no longer after 12 months have to deliberate on minor questions of changes to road alignments here in the ACT. Those matters will be properly dealt with by the responsible representatives of the government of the ACT.

This issue is important nationally and for the Senate, but it is predominantly about the Australian Capital Territory. The legislation before us brings to the citizens of this city and the Territory those things which the rest of Australians take for granted. It gives to us in democratic terms equality with the rest of Australia. It allows our elected representatives to deliberate on the matters of health, education, transport and planning which are so important and affect the day to day lives of all citizens. Of course, it will give them equality in another sense which is important to me and my colleagues in the House of Representatives, and to Senator Reid. It will make the ACT's Federal representatives freer to participate as full members of the Federal Parliament without the constraints of also being shire councillors and State members of parliament. I do not say that by way of complaint because in my brief experience as a member of this place for the last nine months I have enjoyed the opportunity to be involved in a wide number of local issues. It has enhanced my capacity to participate effectively in national matters, but it must have been a substantial burden on ACT members who have represented it longer than I have, and I am sure they will welcome the opportunity to operate at the national level on an equal footing with their colleagues. But I warn the soon-to-be elected local representatives that I certainly and, I am sure, my colleagues, will not be losing the interest in and the desire to be involved in the local issues that affect the future of this city and this Territory. I will be particularly concerned to pursue my continuing interest and involvement in those matters.

Canberra has become a territory of more than 260,000 people. Its economic base is changing. It is no longer simply a government town. It is emerging as a growing diverse territory with the strengths and benefits of a growing healthy economy, but with the social and economic problems of any State or Territory. It is very difficult for colleagues who fly into Canberra on Monday or Tuesday and fly home on Thursday or Friday to the electorate in which they live, to which they are responsible and which they represent, to understand or even to know of the existence of the profound social problems that occur in this city in exactly the same way as elsewhere in Australia. Therefore, it is appropriate that these matters should become, as a result of this package of legislation, the responsibility of those whose job it is to advocate the interests of the people of the ACT and who are accountable to those people. As a matter of broad democratic principle it is unarguable, and I welcome the support, from honourable senators of all parties as far as I can tell, on this matter.

It is a pity that we will not have unanimity on all the matters before us, but I join with Senator Hill and Senator Jenkins in saying that in the main the negotiations have been carried out in a very positive and constructive manner. I welcome the fact that all the parties have had a commitment in principle to the question of ACT self-government, even though in my view some of them have not been prepared to make the sorts of compromises always necessitated in the negotiations in which we have been involved if they are to be amicably resolved. We have achieved an agreement that will, if my expectations are fulfilled, lead to a very profound transfer of power within our country-a transfer from this Parliament to a democratically elected territorial assembly, with proper recognition of the democratic rights and responsibilities of the ACT. I will come back to that question of responsibilities in a moment.

I welcome the fact that in the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Bill the very broad and proper responsibilities, defined as peace, order and good government of the Territory, will be the responsibility of the people of the ACT. I welcome also the fact that the recently published opinion poll in the Canberra Times indicated a very substantial change of opinions in the ACT since the referendum in 1978 towards the issue of self-government. It reflects the views that I have received from community members not that there is continuing apprehension about self-government-it is understandable that there would be with a major change-but that the community has changed its attitude profoundly since 1978.

I support the view that, despite the outcome of that opinion poll, this is not an appropriate matter for a referendum. In my view democracy is not optional. We do not have a choice to say that we want someone else to take care of our interests. In a democracy one has very profound rights but one also has an obligation to discharge one's responsibility to look after one's own interests. It is entirely appropriate that all the parties here support our proceeding with this matter by direct legislative means rather than by referendum.

Since 1978 there have been very profound changes to the financial arrangements in the ACT. In the last two or three years the financial arrangements necessary for transition to self-government have already been established. I congratulate those involved in initiating those steps and in implementing those measures. So there is no reason why this should be a financial burden on the citizens of the ACT-on any individual or on them collectively. It will certainly not create a situation in which, unlike in the rest of Australia, the people of the ACT are overgoverned.

At the moment the ACT has only four elected representatives. As a result of this legislation we will have 21 elected representatives for 260,000 people. Any simple scrutiny of the circumstances in any of the States in terms of the number of elected representatives in State upper and lower Houses, Federal upper and lower Houses and local government shows that the proportion of representatives in the ACT compared with that in the States and the Northern Territory is still going to be very low. I think that this arrangement is quite appropriate. I think it would be more appropriate if the States and the Northern Territory considered following the ACT model rather than the ACT going any further towards following what they do. I hope that when the election occurs-it should be held as early as possible, in February or March of next year, so that the hiatus period between the passage of this legislation and the holding of new elections is as short as possible-the appropriate democratic arrangements will be in place and that we will not be faced with the problems of overgovernment or extra cost which caused some understandable concern in 1978 to the citizens of the ACT.

I would like to deal briefly with the more detailed Bills-the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Bill 1988 and the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Bill 1988. I do not think that these Bills, which are part of the package, have yet received sufficient consideration. I support the electoral Bill, which now incorporates the final version of the consolidated d'Hondt system of voting. I say without any equivocation that the d'Hondt system is not my first choice. It is certainly not the first choice of my Party as an electoral system. I find it unbelievable to the point of being absurd that anybody should put forward the argument-as some people have purported to do recently in newspapers and, unfortunately, in the debate here-that in some way it is a system designed to serve the interests of the Australian Labor Party.

We have now put forward six systems, all of which are quite different and all of which, when analysed, produce a result that in my view is inherently democratic-that is, that the party that gets the most votes wins the election, which is more than can be said for the electoral systems in some parts of this country. At some stage everyone has seen that one of these systems has not been in someone's interests. In 1986 the level of opposition to any of the proposed reforms was so profound that no progress towards self-government could effectively be made at all. In the immortal words of Ian Warden, self-government was butchered.

We now have an electoral system that can work and that can achieve a fair balance between the desire to present a range of options to the people of the ACT, to have a result that reflects the wishes of the voters when they turn out at the polls and to provide a reasonable chance for stable government. I understand the wishes of the people of the ACT, as reflected in the most recent opinion poll, in which they say they would like to have their territorial government elected by the House of Representatives system, by the system that is established in every mainland State, under which representatives in their local areas will be elected by them under the optional preferential or preferential voting system. I understand that; I think they are absolutely right. I think that system must ultimately come to the ACT because it reflects the best principles of the Westminster system. But I accept that a majority of the Senate is not in favour of that system. I am prepared to support the compromise that most closely reflects the principles that underlie a proper electoral system.

I welcome the fact that after some tortuous and sometimes very difficult negotiations the Opposition has come to the same compromise. The Opposition started from a different position but we have come to a reasonable compromise. I regret the fact that the Australian Democrats have not accepted that compromise. At no stage have they in effect been prepared to make any change at all. They have advocated compromise but they have not changed their own position. I think that is a great pity. But self-government will be established under this proposal. There will be a reasonable chance of the people of the ACT getting a secure and stable government for three years. Over the years, as the people of the ACT see how this system works, they may become comfortable with it and choose to keep it permanently, or they may pursue the interest which is reflected in the recent opinion polls and seek to change a system which is more compatible with that in the rest of mainland Australia. I would, of course, welcome and support such a move. But that is a matter which will now go before the forum in which it should be properly discussed, which is amongst the citizens of the ACT and their elected representatives.

We are proceeding with a system which is not unique. I am amazed that supporters of proportional representation had to dash off and look in their books to find out what the d'Hondt system involves. It is actually much more common than any system in use in Australia. It is a system designed specifically to adapt proportional representation to the needs of Westminster government and to the needs of producing stable majorities. It is a system which has worked very well around the world. It is a great pity that so much nonsense and mumbo jumbo has been spoken about it. This system has the advantage that the ballot paper will not be complex. For all intents and purposes, the ballot paper will be exactly the same for voters as that which they used in the last Senate election.

I am glad that the electoral system is going to be modified slightly further. It was a cause of some embarrassment to me that some people in advocating the previous consolidated d'Hondt system gave it the inglorious title of the McMullan-d'Hondt on the basis that they held me responsible for working it out. I am delighted that there has been a minor change sufficient to kill off the speculation. Although I confess to playing a part in devising the proposal, I would much prefer that it be called something else. I think this final change will kill off that idea forever.

It is appropriate that the other aspects of the electoral operation should be based on the Commonwealth Electoral Act. This arrangement is simple and it ensures consistency and ease of administration. I support the fact that the first election will be conducted under the principles of electoral funding and disclosure. The ACT Legislative Assembly will be the first parliament in Australia ever to commence its political process on the sound footing that electoral favours should not be bought and that contributions to political parties must be disclosed. I have always supported those principles and I support their application in this case. I hope that the elected government of the ACT will continue to do so, but that will be a matter for its members to determine.

I would like to refer briefly to the planning legislation. This is one matter that is properly the business of the national Parliament, which will continue to have a significant responsibility to protect the national interest and the national capital aspects of the wonderful city of this Territory. Canberra does perform diverse functions and one of those functions is its role as the national capital. People in the ACT accept the uniqueness of that arrangement. They accept that the total planning autonomy that other States and Territories have is not appropriate in the ACT because of the peculiar national capital aspects of the city. That is as it should be. I welcome the fact that this principle is reflected in this legislation. In all the discussions that I have had with people in Canberra, the most fervent advocates of local autonomy have recognised that unique responsibility.

I believe that the legislation strikes the appropriate balance between local and national interests. This is a matter that needed a lot of detailed consideration. For all the criticism of it, the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC) has done an outstanding job for the people of the Australian Capital Territory. It was mildly ironic, I suppose, that environmental activists, who for years saw the NCDC as their bete noir and felt that it did not protect their interests sufficiently, should have become its most fervent defenders when it was proposed that it be abolished. If there is one thing that one needs in politics, it is a sense of humour.

It is appropriate that the new arrangements be put in place now. I understand the point that Senator Jenkins made about the difficulty of transition. That is correct. But I do not believe that the people of the Australian Capital Territory would accept that self-government should be transferred and that planning should stay in some way in limbo. After all, planning is the most profound local issue on a day to day basis. It affects many people and has a profound effect also on the economic development of the city. So the new arrangement needed to be put in place. The National Capital Planning Authority is a proper instrument for protecting and developing the interests of the national Parliament and of the people of the rest of Australia in this Territory. Those interests will be protected by the continuation of the leasehold system. These functions will be carried out in conjunction with the territorial planning authority which will have the responsibility for implementing the Territory plan. We have a situation of 12 months of transitional arrangements which will require continuing oversight by the national Parliament and by an appropriately constituted parliamentary joint committee.

I use this opportunity to say that I hope that in that 12- to 18-month period the parliamentary committee will be reconstituted in a more appropriate form. I say `12 to 18 months', because at the conclusion of the 12 month period for the development of the national capital plan I believe it is very important that this Parliament-jointly, the Senate and the House of Representatives-review the national capital plan as proposed and does not simply take it as a matter that may or may not be appropriate for parliamentary disallowance. I hope that the committee deals with it as a proposal that is of very great national interest, because it is the plan to protect the national capital aspects of Canberra, a matter that has been developed over many years with the interests of a large number of members of this Federal Parliament, those from the ACT and elsewhere.

I support the primary legislation, because it creates opportunities for appropriate review and planning and public consultation, and it retains the appropriate parliamentary scrutiny. I turn briefly to the Democrats' Bills and I will make some comments on them before concluding my comments about the Bills as a whole. The Australian Capital Territory (Protection of the National Interest) Bill, I think, is a waste of time. There is no need for it. There is a retained inherent power in the Commonwealth to protect the national interest in so far as it might be required, so there is no requirement for this Bill. I do not support it and I do not believe that the Senate should pass it.

I think that the Australian Capital Territory (Establishment and Amendment of New Constitution) Bill is premature. The Government's proposal will put the ACT in substantially the same position as the Northern Territory. I think we should say to the ACT, to its people and to its elected representatives: `Get on with running the Territory within this proposed framework, which is an enhanced version of anything previously put forward for the Territory and which provides a substantially detailed and delineated framework. Get on with running it and, after you have tried it for a while, you may wish to suggest some changes and you may wish to propose some alternative constitutional format'. If so, that matter can be looked at that time, at our leisure, after the people of the ACT, through their elected representatives, have had a look at it and have decided whether or not they want to proceed in that direction and whether they think it is necessarily appropriate or desirable.

What I accept about the principle in the Democrats' Bill-although I think it is premature and I will not support it at this stage-is that if at some stage in the political evolution of the Territory such a demand emerges, the onus will be on the people in this Parliament to determine why they should not support the wishes of the ACT as put forward, rather than the onus being on the ACT to establish why it should be entitled to such constitutional protection.

I certainly do not agree that it is appropriate for this Parliament at this time to be passing the Australian Capital Territory (Open Government, Probity and Citizens' Rights) Bill, but not because I have any difficulties with the framework of the administrative review proposed to be established in that legislation. I might disagree with the principle and the detail, but broadly I think the framework of administrative law which has developed in Australia under the Commonwealth legislation and which is substantially mirrored in the proposed open government Bill, if I can summarise it as such, has worked very well. It is a framework that needs review from time to time, and that is done by the Administrative Review Council very adequately. I am saying that, if we are to transfer self-government to the ACT, we should transfer decisions about the nature of the administrative review arrangements to that assembly for determination rather than have prior determination here. I will oppose those Bills for that reason, and I urge the Senate to do likewise.

I return to a point that was implicit in what I said about the constitution Bill and some of the other matters and that is implicit in the debate about the powers that are being transferred in the primary Bill: the arrangements being proposed are not set in concrete forever. There are aspects with regard to the powers that will be reviewed in 1990, and it may be that others will need to be reviewed subsequently. That is a matter which to some extent will come up in the committee stage and which to some extent, from time to time, will be capable of subsequent debate between the Government of the ACT and the Federal Government. I clearly have the view, as I expressed earlier, that in the long term the electoral arrangements may well be changed. There may well be a demand locally that that should be the case, and that is a matter that should be considered at that stage.

I agree with Senator Hill that some of the safeguards and constraints built into the legislation and not reflected necessarily in the legislation of the other States may not be long term and may not last forever. However, I say with regard to those matters, as I said previously with regard to the Democrats' proposed constitution Bill: Let the system work. It is a very comprehensive and complex system, and it will be a very large task for the newly-elected members to set up a new government and operate the system that is being put before them-in some ways, a greater task than has ever been put on any newly-elected government, because it will have the unique combination of both State and local government responsibilities. Let it work. After the elected representatives have tried it and the people of the ACT have seen it, we may be approached by the ACT Government to make changes and the onus will be on the Commonwealth as to why it should not agree, other than with regard to national planning matters or other appropriate national responsibilities.

In conclusion, I will say two things. I welcome this important initiative: Firstly, as a matter of principle, it is a proper extension of the democratic process to this Territory; and, secondly, I think it is the right time for it to be undertaken. I would like to have seen it done some years before, but in some ways the delay has been used to good advantage and has been beneficial. It is the right time in terms of the evolution of this Territory, because we now have a healthy breadth and diversity of the ethnic origins of the people, of the economic base, of the cultural life, of the sporting activities and of the whole gamut of social, cultural, economic and political activities that make it appropriate that we should be self-governing, and because the transitional arrangements with regard to finances and administration have been adequately determined. I think it is appropriate in terms of efficiency and in terms of the extension of accountability. So I welcome this very important initiative. I welcome it also, as I said earlier, because it removes inappropriate business from this Senate and will enable us to more adequately discharge our other responsibilities.

It is the last major transfer of such power to the ACT. There are some other areas in other territories of a minor nature that need to be examined, minor in terms of the number of people involved and the land mass involved, but still important to the people concerned: for example, the matter of the people of Jervis Bay. Nevertheless, a major transfer is involved and it is an important step. It is something which I think even those people in the ACT who currently are apprehensive will in hindsight come to welcome as a very major step forward. I welcome the fact that the majority of the people of the ACT have now come to see that self-government in some form is appropriate. Some of them would advocate a slightly different form of State or local government; and I understand that, because to some extent it reflects the diversity of the origins of the people of this city in that they have come from so many other parts of Australia and have had different experiences with State and local government.

I do not think that either half-way house would have been appropriate. To have given self-government to the ACT without giving it responsibility for the schools system or the health system-which would have occurred if we had not transferred State powers-would have been a sham, because if one looks at the media in the ACT one will see that two of the predominant issues reflected and about which concern is expressed here relate to the health and education systems; and a similar argument could be put with regard to planning if local government powers were not transferred.

I support this major transfer of powers and the form in which it is to take place. I congratulate the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Clyde Holding, for the work he has done in bringing this matter to fruition. I particularly congratulate the previous Minister, Gary Punch, for the enthusiasm and verve with which he gave impetus to the self-government debate; and I also mention his predecessors, Gordon Scholes, Tom Uren and John Brown. I join others in supporting the community activists, particularly the ACT self-government campaign committee, for their work in improving this proposal. I thank the public servants who have been involved, particularly in the ACT Administration; and the media in Canberra for the constructive role they have played. I regret that there was some delay in achieving agreement. I welcome it now. I have great pleasure in supporting these Bills. I look forward to participating as a citizen, in a self-governing ACT.
Debate interupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.40 to 2.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Finance still agree that, as he said on the Face to Face television program on Sunday, 9 October, one more bad monthly balance of payments figure-that is, coming on top of the figures then already recorded in July and August-will require the Government to review the economic strategy announced in the August Budget Papers? Now that we have seen a bad balance of payments deficit for September and a disastrous one for October, with a total deficit of $5.4 billion for the July-October period, does the Minister agree that his condition for such a review of economic strategy has been satisfied? In particular, does the Minister still agree that, as he stated on that program, any such review would require the Government to review its spending programs with an eye to making cuts in them or does the Government now simply propose to rely on a prolonged credit squeeze, via some of the highest interest rates in the industrialised world, to depress the economy sufficiently to make room for its promised tax cuts next July?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that it has taken Senator Stone so long to ask this question. I was fully expecting to get it as the first question yesterday. Since his demotion from the front bench apparently other people in the Opposition have to take priority. First, Senator Stone did not quote the comments that I made on the Face to Face program completely. He quoted one of the conditions that I had laid down as being those, should they all eventuate, which would probably require a change of strategy and particularly a change on expenditures. The other point to make-the Treasurer acknowledged this, I believe, last Wednesday-is that the Budget forecast for a $9 1/2 billion current account deficit now seems to be unlikely; it will probably be exceeded perhaps by $1 billion, perhaps by a bit more. However, it is too early to try to be any more definitive than that. It ought to be remembered of course that, apart from the normal seasonal factors in current account deficits, stocks of our major agricultural products-wheat and wool-were pretty well exhausted in the early part of this financial year. So the seasonal factor for this year is probably stronger than it is normally.

ANSWER.PARA: However, having said that, I make no attempt to establish a case that the October current account figure was anything less than disappointing. Of course it was disappointing. Indeed I acknowledged that on a television program with Senator Stone's successor as shadow finance spokesman, Dr Hewson. I also mentioned to Dr Hewson that Senator Stone was making the same predictions of doom and gloom immediately after the 1987 Budget and the October 1987 stock market collapse as Dr Hewson was making last Wednesday. His response was, `Don't quote Stone at me'. The probability now is that the current account deficit will be somewhat more, although probably not a great deal more, than the 3 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) that was forecast in the Budget. There is certainly no likelihood at this stage that it will be as much as 4 per cent. It is worth noting, particularly since the Opposition has asked this question, that in the final disastrous year of the Fraser-Howard regime, we had a current account deficit of 4 per cent of GDP when we were in the biggest depression that Australia has seen since the 1930s. That was a deficit of 4 per cent of gross domestic product in the depths of the biggest depression for 50 years-while this Government's will not be that high in the midst of what is almost one of the strongest periods of growth that we have had in recent years or in many decades.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Minister's flight of fancy in the latter part of his response to me about the comparison between the present situation and that of the last year of the Fraser Government, would the Minister care to complete the comparison that he was making by referring to the fact that, of course, at that time we were experiencing the tail end-and it was the tail end, admittedly-of a business investment boom? Will he compare that situation with the situation at present?

—I cannot remember off the top of my head what the relative levels of business investments were in 1982-83 as compared with the likely levels of business investment now. However, I would be surprised if they were as high in 1982-83 as they are likely to be for this year.

—Is the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories aware of an article in the Hobart Mercury of 27 October 1988 in which Mr Robin Griffith claims to have developed a process by which jarosite waste from the Electrolytic Zinc Co. (Australasia) Ltd plant at Risdon could be converted to inexpensive building materials? Given that Risdon is the only major plant in any westernised country that is allowed to dump jarosite at sea, will the Minister investigate why the process was not proceeded with when drawn to the attention of the Government about 15 years ago by the then General Manager of the company at Risdon, Mr Reg Barker? Will he undertake to investigate the feasibility of this process as an alternative to dumping jarosite at sea? Further, if the process proves to be a viable alternative, will the Government refuse to renew the licence for the EZ company to continue to dumping of jarosite at sea?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a proposal, which was put forward as far back as 1974, in relation to incorporating jarosite into building plasters and cements. However, all the products tested at the time failed to meet industry standards, and the project lapsed. In fact, apparently Mr Griffith put forward suggestions for a jarosite composite, containing building panel, at about that time. Apparently, the final work on this was postponed at his request, pending a patent application, which does not appear to have been proceeded with. Mr Griffith has also come up with another process comparatively recently which is currently being investigated by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Division of Building Construction and Engineering.

ANSWER.PARA: As one of the conditions of a sea dumping permit, EZ is required to investigate alternative means of disposal of the jarosite waste. Any feasible alternative to what is being undertaken at present that comes up as a result of that would obviously have to be considered seriously. At this stage, until the CSIRO has given us some final report on Mr Griffith's latest process, it is not possible to make judgments on the right of EZ to retain the sea dumping permit. As soon as I receive some information from the CSIRO I will inform the honourable senator further.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce will recall that two years ago he advised manufacturers to make investment plans on the basis that the Australian dollar would remain very close to its then level of just above US 60c. I ask the Minister: Should manufacturers now base their planning on the assumption that the dollar will remain at or about its current level?
—I have answered this question on several occasions.
—We will keep asking it until you get it right.

—I propose to get it right. As Senator Chaney full well knows, I will not comment on the current value of the dollar. If Senator Chaney wants to make a criticism of me for having done so two or three years ago, I plead guilty to that.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I note the Minister's confession and remind him that not only two or three years ago-the example I gave-but just a year ago he expressed another view on the value of the dollar, when he said that from an industry point of view he would like to see the value of the Australian dollar around US65c to US68c. So this has happened not just a couple of years ago. The Minister has, on a number of occasions, essayed a view, presumably as a guidance to the people in his manufacturing constituency. I ask the Minister: Is he aware of the concerns which have been expressed, and not just by manufacturers? For example, an article was published this morning about a wheel manufacturer whose profitability on his exports to America have been considerably affected by the change in the dollar, and beef exporters have complained about the situation which now faces them. Is the Minister concerned that only last week the Executive General Manager of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Mr Russell Fynmore, said that at the dollar's current rates `I cannot see much future in investing in manufacturing for export'? What is the Government's strategy for dealing with these very changed circumstances that face Australian manufacturers? Should manufacturers assume that circumstances will again change? He has given guidance in the past. What is his guidance now?

—In addition to any guidance I might give in a moment, let me first of all give Senator Chaney a few facts. The first is that while the dollar has appreciated as against a declining US dollar, the movement in respect of the trade weighted index has been very limited indeed in the last couple of months. In so far as exporters write contracts in US dollars, there are hedging mechanisms available in the market to protect them from currency fluctuations, and the better companies are using those mechanisms. If other companies wish to speculate more on the value of the dollar, having themselves made projections about what it is likely to do, that is their business and is probably not very good business. The honourable senator asks me about wheel manufacturers, beef exporters and such things.
—Do you agree that these people are having problems?

—Senator Chaney asks me, by way of interjection, a question which might have been more pertinent earlier-whether I agree that these people are having problems. Certainly, some of them are. To go back to the start of the question, I did not say, as the honourable senator suggested in trying to lend strength to his bow in terms of the earlier part of his question, that from an industry point of view 62c to 65c was an appropriate figure.
—Sixty-five cents.

—The honourable senator is relying on a press report, which was totally inaccurate in terms of what I said at the time. What I did say is that I was aware of manufacturing exporters saying that they would prefer a dollar at that value, as I am now in terms of the honourable senator's question about the difficulties which are being encountered by some manufacturers and some exporters from other sectors in terms of the current value of the dollar. Having said all that, I am not about to say that I think a particular figure would be desirable. The dollar is floating. People in export markets are aware of that and some of them are taking steps to protect themselves from that fact.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to certain revelations from the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct over the last week relating to more than $2m worth of loans and a $1 rental for a Gold Coast penthouse involving Mr Russell Hinze, a former Minister in the Bjelke-Petersen National Party State Government. What is the treatment for income tax purposes of loans such as these for which the legitimate commercial basis, if any, is unclear and overly generous rental arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The liability, if any, for taxation on the loans cum gifts that were mentioned in the question is a matter for the Commissioner of Taxation or his deputy to determine. However, I can supply some information from the Master Tax Guide and make a couple of other comments. The first point I want to make is that I understand that income is income, no matter how it is derived-whether it is derived legally or illegally; honestly or corruptly. It is still taxable if it falls within the classification of income. What is important is the substance of arrangements and not any contrived veneer that might be put over them. I will give a few quotations from the Master Tax Guide on the subject of the definition of income for taxation purposes. The Master Tax Guide states:

ANSWER.PARA: Personal earnings from the performance of services whether as an employee or otherwise are clearly income, even though the services may be performed and the rewards received irregularly.

A gift by one person to another will not generally be regarded as income in the hands of the recipient. For example, a present given by a father to his son out of love and natural affection is not income in the hands of the son, but a tip given to a waiter or taxi driver is income in the hands of the donee because it is a product of the services which have been rendered.

Whether the provision of a $2m loan was a function of the love and affection of the people who were providing the loans to Mr Hinze or for services rendered by Mr Hinze is a matter for the Commissioner of Taxation to determine, not for me. The Master Tax Guide also states:
To be within the ordinary meaning of income, a receipt or benefit must be either of money or capable of being converted into money.

There are many more passages that have some relevance to this question, but I do not want to take up too much time. There are a number of passages that are relevant to exertion. It is difficult to determine what exertion might mean or be in this context. I notice that Mr Elliott has had a lot to say recently about whether the Australian Taxation Office should delve so deeply into the financial affairs of big business. I would be interested to see whether he has a view on whether the Tax Office should have a look at this particular case. I also noticed in today's Sydney Morning Herald a very good reply to Mr Elliott from Ross Gittins.

Finally in relation to the general question of people who hold public office receiving, either in cash or in kind, very valuable considerations, very valuable rewards or gifts, or whatever they might be, from those people in the private sector with whom they have some dealings as politicians, I would like to quote what I believe is an excellent passage-a passage which I believe is highly relevant to this-from Cyril Pearl's Wild Men of Sydney in which, in reference to one William Patrick Crick, Minister for Lands and Postmaster-General, among other things, of the colony of New South Wales prior to Federation, he wrote:

But I think that Crick, like many criminals, often saw all his actions through the rationalisation prism of an overwhelming ego. Even when conducting his own defence in the Criminal Court, he seemed to be unaware that there was anything wrong in taking bribes. `If a person came to me and offered me #10,000 to put through a matter for him, and I could put it through in a legitimate and honest way,' he told the jury, `I would take the amount, just as a barrister would take a #5,000 fee.'
That is the end of the quotation from Crick. Pearl's editorial comment was:

The manifest absurdity of this argument suggests that it was born of a deficient moral sense, rather than of conscious duplicity. And the reiteration of the honesty and legitimacy of his actions is significant.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Training to a Budget decision to introduce on 1 January next year an assets test on Austudy and the fact that this assets test will encompass the isolated children's allowance, which is already means tested. Will this assets test deprive many children from families with large assets but low or negative cash flow living in rural and isolated areas of a standard of education equivalent to that enjoyed by their urban counterparts who have access to schools paid for by taxpayers, and will the Government consider the total exclusion from the assets test of the education component of the total fees incurred by rural children who have to attend private boarding schools due to the non-availability of State boarding schools?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another free kick in the square. The isolated children's allowance has always been income tested rather than means tested. There is a difference between the meanings of the two. It has always been income tested, and when the new arrangements come into operation it will be means tested because an assets test will be added to the income test. I made the point in a speech a couple of weeks ago that all parents of isolated children receive an education payment. They will continue to receive that basic payment of $989 a year. Up to an extra $1,862 is available, subject to a parental income test, for a year 11 of year 12 student. There has always been such an income test. If a family has one child, that additional payment cuts out entirely at a family income of $24,399.

ANSWER.PARA: It was announced in May that, as from 1989, parents who had assets additional to the house in which they lived and a curtilage in excess of $300,000 would not get that additional assistance. For farmers-I think that this was implied in the question-and for some other businesses, only half of the asset is counted, so the total net assets additional to the house in which the parents live would have to be $600,000. If anybody who has control of business assets of that size is not earning on them a sufficient return to have income tested himself way out of the range of the additional payment for the isolated children's allowance-and remember that that is just over $24,000 a year-and is not generating a great deal more than $24,000 a year with assets of $600,000, it means one of two things: either the asset is grossly overvalued or it is being grossly mismanaged. Whichever one it is, not only is there absolutely no justification for governments--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or they are in a drought.

—I will come back to that. I suppose Senator Chaney is trying desperately to make sure that Charlie Court does not knock him off when he goes for pre-selection, like he did last time. Not only is there no case for governments intervening in a way that sustains ridiculous overvaluation of assets or the most horrendous mismanagement of those assets, but there is a very strong case for the Government not getting involved in such stupid activity. I would have thought that there was on the Liberal Party side of politics the odd person who might have understood enough about the way in which a market economy operates to realise that that is so. I am sure that Senator Stone understands why that is so, but I thought that Senator Chaney, and even Senator Panizza, would have understood it. Senator Chaney asked about drought. If people have net assets in excess of $600,000 they can borrow against their net assets to educate their children.
—What if they live in the city?

—If they live in a city, they do not get any allowance at all, if they have an income. On the equity side, there is a cut-off figure of $16,950 to get that full additional allowance. If the family income is in excess of $16,950, the full allowance is not paid. I cannot imagine anybody on an income of that level or a great deal higher who would not willingly forgo his additional allowance in order to receive $600,000 worth of net assets in addition to the house in which he lives. I am a bit surprised that the Australian Democrats, who often thump their chests and bleat about equity and fairness, should come in here and bat for people to receive additional allowances when those people have net assets, additional to their home, of $600,000, while people with an income in excess of $16,950 do not get a full allowance.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN HERITAGE COMMISSION AND NATIONAL ESTATE REGISTER

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories would be aware of my concern and that of many other Australians about reports a couple of weeks ago that the Australian Heritage Commission and the National Estate Register were under threat and would be downgraded. Can the Minister reassure me that those rumours are unfounded under this Labor Government? Can he also respond to last week's attack on the performance of the Heritage Commission by the National Association of Forest Industries that claimed that owners of land on the Register of the National Estate suffer economic loss for which compensation should be paid? Finally, is section 30 of the Heritage Commission Act a significant deterrent to mineral exploration as claimed last week by the Australian Mining Industry Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been aware for some time of Senator Coates's concern, as I have been concerned, about any threats to the Heritage Commission, but fortunately last week the Government was able to announce that the resources of the Heritage Commission were to be almost doubled-by the commitment of an extra $2m annually, including an extra 21 staff.
—What about the workers in Ravenshoe?

—At least I have given the workers of Ravenshoe $75m; those opposite have given them absolutely nothing. Turning back to this question, the commitment is for an extra $2m annually, including an extra 21 staff. I think that will have a significant effect. The only thing that I can agree with in the press releases that came from the forest industries and the mining lobby is that the Commission was behind. There were 3,500 places on the interim list that had not been dealt with and they had not been dealt with because the Commission seriously lacked resources. The additional resources which we are now able to provide will, I think, fix the problem.

ANSWER.PARA: However, if one looks at what the forest industries and the mining industries had to say, one will see that there are a couple of fundamental weaknesses in their arguments. The first argument that they seek to promote is that in some way places listed on the National Estate Register are in fact locked up; they cannot be exploited. But because Cabinet is going to look to a review, I made sure that I had a list done of what exactly was happening with the National Estate. It is sad to report that as far as the National Estate is concerned, because obligations under the Act are placed only on the Commonwealth-they are not placed on State governments or local governments-there are almost 70 places on the list currently being mined, drilled, logged or otherwise exploited. Hundreds of places have been removed from the list because if they are in the built areas they just do not exist any more, they have been knocked over; alternatively, if they are part of our natural heritage, they have been so modified by miners, loggers, or whoever, that they are no longer worthy of being on the list.

The reality is that, far from locking it up, what we had hoped over the years was that in some way there would at least be some moral suasion on those who seek to exploit to, in some way, have a careful look.
