The facts are that the development lobby has continued to knock over places on the National Estate Register.

With regard to implications for owners of land that might be put on the Register, there has been a suggestion in the press release to which Senator Coates referred that they ought to be compensated for some loss. The difficulty is that, whenever we ask the National Farmers Federation to name the farmers who have been so affected and who need to be compensated because their properties are worthless, it cannot give any names. When we ask the Mining Industry Council to give names of miners who need to be compensated, it cannot give any names. The facts are that this has been a smokescreen that has been going on for some years. It has been part of a deliberate attempt to confuse National Estate and World Heritage, both of which are very different concepts. In the case of the National Estate, no land use power at all is conferred upon the Commonwealth and that, I think, is what people have failed to understand.

Senator Coates asked about section 30 of the Heritage Commission Act and whether or not it was a significant deterrent to mineral exploration, as has been claimed. The fact is, of course, that section 30 has never been used. It sits there in the Act, but it has never been used. I do not know of any mining company which currently thinks that suddenly this Government is about to use it, given that it did not, the Fraser Government did not and the Whitlam Government that put it in did not use it either. Obviously, it is a very difficult section to apply. The Government has not used it and has no current plans to use it. It provides no deterrent at all. If it did, all of those places being drilled, mined or otherwise exploited would not be being destroyed in the way that they are now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Was the officer who sought names of people present at the Minister's farcical late night sitting of the High Court of Australia two weeks ago acting at the Minister's direction or at the direction of the Attorney-General? Will the Minister take this opportunity to apologise publicly for this outrageous behaviour? Having made a galah of himself once already by taking action against a non-existent article in Mr Brian Toohey's magazine the Eye, why is the Government persisting with court action against Mr Toohey by taking him to the Federal Court of Australia today? Is it the Government's intention to prevent this journalist ever publishing anything, including already published material dealing with the Australian Secret Intelligence Service (ASIS), or is the real motive, as suggested by Mr Toohey today, to try to bankrupt him because of his oft-critical assessments of leading members of the Hawke Government? Is this whole farcical situation a continuance of the Minister's past history of taking precipitate action because it seemed a good idea at the time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The activities of the officer of the Attorney-General's Department in the court on the original night that this matter was the subject of an application for an interim injunction were not at the direction of the Attorney-General, nor of anyone in the Attorney-General's Department, nor of the counsel conducting the case. It was obviously an error of judgment on the part of the officer concerned, acting in the public interest as he perceived it, but manifestly incorrectly. That was the subject of a detailed and extensive apology to the High Court yesterday by the officer in question through counsel for the Commonwealth. The judge in question, His Honour Mr Justice Deane, said that as far as he was concerned the matter was completely closed, and I think that is the way it should be regarded by us in this place.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the larger question of the continuing litigation against Mr Toohey, since the matter is still before the courts it would obviously be inappropriate to comment in any detail about the matters of fact that are in issue in that case, particularly evidentiary questions. But since that inhibition is clearly not being felt by Mr Toohey himself, on the basis of his comments all round the media so far today, I think it would be appropriate for me to correct the record in a couple of significant respects and in so doing respond to Senator Walters's question.

The Government's concern is not and never has been with the publication of material about the Australian Secret Intelligence Service (ASIS) as such. Much more specifically, the concern has been about the publication of information which identifies former or current officers of ASIS or their contacts, which identifies current or former places of overseas operation of ASIS, or which falsely describes specific intelligence activities involving those officers or those places. Our concern is based on three distinct considerations, all of them equally important: first, the danger to the individuals affected; secondly, the undermining of the efficacy of the Intelligence Service that would be associated with such disclosures; and, thirdly, the damage to foreign relations which can follow from such disclosures. Obviously, a lot more could be said about each of those points, but this is not the occasion to go into that.

The corollary of what I have just said is that, generally speaking, it is not the Government's concern to seek to stop the publication of information of the kind I have just described which has already been published, whether such original publication was authorised or not and whether such previously published information was accurate or not. Often it is not. Such damage as is likely to occur from republication has in most cases already occurred. Maybe cases can be envisaged where renewed publication would be dangerous but, generally speaking, once some purported piece of information is on the record it would be both ineffective and oppressive to pursue its subsequent suppression. That is a key principle underlying the way in which we are approaching this issue.

In understanding the action that the Government is currently taking-not just a few weeks ago but right now-it is important to appreciate that the Government now has reason to believe that what Mr Toohey is planning to publish is not a mere article in the Eye or some other journal, not something dealing just with the purported naming of one individual officer in one overseas location, but a whole book purporting to name a great many individuals. A subpoena has been issued today out of the Federal Court of Australia in Sydney dealing with this matter and it will no doubt be the subject of further court proceedings. I make it clear that there is no reason why a book about ASIS as such should not be published. But there is every reason why such a book or any other publication should not contain previously unpublished information of an especially damaging kind, in particular information of the kind that I have already mentioned, that is, information identifying current or former officers, particular overseas locations or the particular activities of those officers in those locations.

The principles which govern these matters were extremely well articulated by Mr Justice Mason in the Fairfax case a few years ago. It is worth putting what he said on the record because it is an admirable statement not only of the law but of the principles that we all ought to recognise. He said:

It is unacceptable, in our democratic society, that there should be a restraint on the publication of information relating to a government when the only vice of that information is that it enables the public to discuss, review and criticize government action.

Accordingly, the court will determine the government's claim to confidentiality by reference to the public interest. Unless disclosure is likely to injure the public interest, it will not be protected.

The court will not prevent the publication of information which merely throws light on the past workings of government, even if it be not public property, so long as it does not prejudice the community in other respects. Then disclosure will itself serve the public interest in keeping the community informed and in promoting discussion of public affairs. If, however, it appears that disclosure will be inimical to the public interest because national security, relations with foreign countries or the ordinary business of government will be prejudiced, disclosure will be restrained.

I said in this chamber a few weeks ago, at the outset of this whole matter, that Mr Toohey's protestations would be much more believable if he were prepared to swear that he has no previously unpublished material in his possession or control purporting to identify ASIS personnel, areas of operation or activities, or if he has such information that he has no plans to publish it. That remains the basis of our approach. This matter could be very quickly and readily resolved were Mr Toohey prepared to accept the kinds of principles that I have outlined, which will no doubt be understood and accepted, if not by Senator Walters, certainly by the overwhelming majority of Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Can the Minister, with his fictitious imagination, say who next he will draw up before the courts to swear that he or she will not divulge fictitious information such as the Minister has suggested someone may at some time in the future put forward? Will the Minister answer the last two parts of the question I put to him: is the real motive of the Government, as suggested by Mr Toohey today, to try to bankrupt him because of his oft critical assessments of leading members of the Hawke Government? Is this whole farcical situation a continuance of the Minister's history of taking action because it seemed a good idea at the time?

—Senator Walters obviously did not listen to the answer I gave to her question. She would have broken her duck if she had. Under those circumstances, I have absolutely nothing further to add to my answer.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to a coloured brochure entitled It's not World Heritage, it's your Heritage: The Facts, which is being circulated throughout Queensland by the Queensland State Government. Can the Minsiter advise the Senate whether the Queensland Government's case, as set out in the brochure, has any scientific basis to justify the claims that have been made in the brochure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the brochure in question. It is a fairly expensively produced coloured brochure, in keeping with what the Queensland Government has been trying to do in north Queensland. I understand that it is the latest in another $100,000 that it has allocated to its dismally failing campaign.
—It is Queensland taxpayers' money.

—Queensland taxpayers are paying for this. But a few Ministers use that amount of money each month. For them $100,000 is just not much of a problem. As usual, of course, there is absolutely no scientific justification whatsoever for some of the claims that are made in the brochure.
—When did you become a scientist?

—Just be patient. I am about to tell the honourable senator. He lacks patience. He lacks a lot of other things too, but I am concentrating on patience at the moment. A consultant was appointed to the Northern Rainforest Management Agency (NORMA), which was set up by the Queensland Government. Dr Carl Jordan from the University of Georgia was asked to have a look at wet tropics and the scientific base for the Commonwealth's case. He reported to the Queensland Government last March and is now wondering why he has never had any reaction to his report. Of course, the reason for that is pretty obvious. Like almost every scientist who has had a look at the wet tropics, he came down absolutely against what the Queensland Government was trying to do. In fact, I would like to quote one part of his report, which, I might say, I have seen. He says:

ANSWER.PARA: From an international perspective, logging of the Queensland rain forest would be the ultimate in short-sighted abuse of a world heritage.

He speaks with disdain of Queensland's plans to log virgin areas once again just to try to maintain a 60,000 cubic metre quota. He also speaks of how difficult it is-how, in his view, impossible it is-to have sustained yield forestry in a tropical rainforest regime. He says that it has never been successful anywhere in the world for more than a few decades.

I would have thought that it was time, in view of Dr Jordan's evidence and, of course, in view of the revolt of the entire NORMA scientific committee that has taken place this year, that the Queensland Government-and perhaps even Senator Boswell-woke up, and that they might say they had been on the wrong tram. Perhaps it is time that the Premier, Mike Ahern, stopped agreeing to his environment Minister's request in Cabinet to spend more and more money on trying to knock the case over in north Queensland. In conclusion, I can only say about Mr Muntz that at a conference I attended in Surfers Paradise the compere, in introducing Mr Muntz, spoke of his German heritage. He said that Mutz in German meant `bright', but unfortunately Geoff meant `not very'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I refer to Senator Richardson's reply of 10 November 1988 to a question I asked on 9 November 1988 concerning Army rations. In relation to that latest Kelly fable, is it not a fact that there is an estimated $3.1m shortfall for all rations this financial year because of, firstly, a carryover of claims from 1987-88 amounting to a bill of $2.2m; secondly, $1.4m needed to produce ration packs for exercise Kangaroo 89; thirdly, increased packing costs and general price increases; and fourthly, costs for the bicentennial tattoo? Unless more money is provided, do the effects of this very serious shortfall mean: Firstly, that the `measly Beazley' diet recently imposed on the Army in New South Wales will now snowball to other commands; and, secondly, that in Land Command literally dozens of Army exercises programmed for the next seven months will have to be cancelled because Land Command does not have sufficient funds to feed the troops in the field? Or to put it another way, would our current ration resources allow only one brigade to exercise for less than two weeks? Can the Minister say whether this is what Mrs Kelly meant in her submission to the joint inquiry into conditions of service, when she said:

QUESTION.PARA: The challenge of peacetime is efficient management, and effective training.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hard to remember just where Senator Newman's question began because, like all of them, it went on forever.
—Particularly for you.

—I can understand Senator Chaney's interest, given that the Canberra Times this morning reports that the new candidate for his job is Senator Newman. That shows the state that the Liberal Party is in-that once great party. God help us! I have been asked a question about Army rations. Just sit back and relax, because I have an answer. The 1988-89 Budget allocation for rations is $26.7m, which compares with $22.2m spent last year.
—That is a very big increase.

—It is a very big increase. Senator Tate is right again; he always is. The increase over 1987-88 comprises basically the elements to which Senator Newman just referred. They are $1.7m for higher than anticipated carryover of accounts to 1988-89; $1.4m as a special requirement for combat ration packs for Kangaroo 89; additional requirements for the bicentennial tattoo of $500,000; and $900,000 for a number of other variations. The allocation of fresh rations to local commanders throughout Australia is determined on the basis of such factors as personnel living on the base and their daily activities. This type of expenditure is termed `non-discretionary'. An additional discretionary provision is allocated to cover exercises, field activities, and so on.

ANSWER.PARA: As a consequence of the higher than anticipated carryover of claims into 1988-89, which was mainly for combat ration packs, the allocations to certain regions have been less than they estimated they would require. In most cases this has impacted on the level of discretionary expenditure. As part of the normal ongoing management of the Army budget, reviews are made of all financial allocations throughout the year. Subject to the outcome of these reviews it may be necessary to make adjustments in rations because there are fluctuations in the number of soldiers living in. In addition, there was higher than normal Army Reserve activity in the first half of the financial year. Local commanders have been requested to manage their allocations with regard to these factors and to make appropriate economies as necessary. Therefore, it is an internal Army management matter. Corrective action is already being taken to sort out the current local difficulties caused by the fluctuations outlined earlier in the rations vote. This has been achieved through reallocation of funds from elsewhere in the Army budget.

The rations available to soldiers have been, and remain, of a high standard in terms of both quality and quantity. There has been no decrease in the level of funds for the Army rations vote compared with 1987-88. Adjustments within the vote are a matter for Army management.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to comments made by the National Party Premier of Queensland, Mr Ahern, which suggest that the practice of providing cash advances for Ministers is not just restricted to Queensland but extends to other parliaments? Can the Minister assure the Senate that such a system is not available to Federal Ministers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that a modern day Machiavelli would write: If you are in trouble, try to spread the blame to others. It is quite apparent from what has happened in Queensland and the abuse of a variety of systems in that State that Mr Ahern is trying to imply that similar abuses occur in other parliaments. Of course, I cannot speak for every parliament in Australia but, from what I know of the systems that exists at the Federal level, it is very regrettable that the Premier is trying to sheet home that sort of association at the Federal level.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no system for Federal Ministers or Opposition officeholders that provides cash advances to those people. Therefore, we are not able, if we liked to do so, to get a cash advance to pay for meals for friends, flowers or perfume for typists, housekeeping for spouses or have $100 each way on the favourite in the last. None of those options are available to Federal Ministers or Opposition officeholders. Indeed, we have a system that is fairly accountable. For a start, all car travel by Ministers and Opposition officeholders is published once a year. I guess one can take some sort of measurement from that as to the extent that it is used or abused. That can be further followed up by use of freedom of information provisions, as has occurred from time to time.

The figures for overseas travel by Ministers are also published every year. There is a small cash advance system for overseas travel by Ministers based on the type of travel allowance. But again, that basically has to be accounted for. Travel allowances for Ministers and Opposition officeholders generally are also published once a year. If all those systems do not work particularly well, we have the Estimates committees which can also follow up, examine and look for any hollow logs that may exist. Nearly all the conditions of Ministers and Opposition office holders are set by the Remuneration Tribunal and therefore are very much open to public scrutiny. For those who have not caught up with the news, I also add that those extra allowances paid to Ministers and Opposition office holders are now fully taxable because of the substantiation rules brought in some two years ago. This means an increase of $10,000 to $12,000 a year in the taxable income of most Ministers and Opposition office holders. I suppose I may be presenting a grievance on behalf of Ministers. However, as far as Senator Walsh is concerned, the clawback to the Commonwealth is fairly considerable.

If Mr Ahern is thinking that the Commonwealth system is the same as his own, I wonder why he has contacted the Commonwealth Government to find out our procedures with a view to implementing them at a State level. It is a fairly desperate act for Mr Ahern to try to have an inquiry into not only the Ministers in Queensland; he also lumps the backbenchers into it. He proposes to lump the backbenchers into it hoping to throw the net out and catch someone else. When that does not work, he tries to smear all politicians. The reality is that everyone in this chamber, not just Ministers, has been smeared. There is no question of that. If one goes out into the sticks and talks to the people one finds that they believe members in this chamber all have their hands out for cash advances, credit cards or something else. It is a pity. As one colleague rather lamented to me the other day, we have to get all the odium and nothing to show for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In view of the highly publicised and extremely successful flight from Hobart to Antarctica by adventurer Dick Smith, could the Minister kindly advise whether it is the intention of the Government to make funds available in the near future for the completion of a feasibility study into the possible provision of aircraft support to the Australian Antarctic stations as a quicker and more efficient method of transporting personnel and essential stores to the region. Does the Minister agree that, given the problems which have plagued our shipping services to the region, the successful operation of air transport could provide significant savings for Australian taxpayers? I remind the Minister of the recent problems that the Lady Franklin had because of pack ice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —After Dick Smith has reported to us on what has happened on his flight I will be in a better position to answer Senator Calvert's question. Clearly, the issue of supplying our bases by aircraft has been looked at by a number of Ministers over a number of years. It has been claimed in the past that it cannot be done because of the need to construct an all-weather airport and how difficult that might be. It has been Dick Smith's contention-not just recently, but for some time-that by using the Twin Otter aircraft which he is using on this flight we could in fact manage to supply at least some of the bases and transport scientists to and fro where necessary and that we could do that without the necessity to build an airport because this plane could land in some parts on the ice. I will be interested to see the results of Dick Smith's trip and just what comes from his findings. He has talked up a long way the Twin Otter and its possible uses, and I just hope that as a result of this trip he can prove that what he has been claiming for the past several years is correct.

—Does the Minister for Resources regard the atmosphere as a resource over which we should exercise some responsibility? Does the Minister recognise that the capacity of the atmosphere to absorb pollutants is finite? Is the Minister aware that the 10-volume Energy 2000 discussion papers-a report over which his predecessor, Senator Gareth Evans, was responsible-mentioned the greenhouse effect only once-and that his final Energy 2000 report mentioned the greenhouse effect not at all? Can the Minister's newly created National Energy Consultative Council consider and advise on the greenhouse effect? If not, where and how in the Minister's portfolio will it be considered? Finally, in view of the Minister's remarks at the presentation of awards for energy efficiency in Melbourne at the weekend, and in view of the 25 per cent cut in Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation greenhouse-related research since June 1983, is he pressing his colleagues for more funds for basic data collection and analysis on the greenhouse effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should thank Senator Coulter for giving me the opportunity to answer such a wide ranging series of questions on the greenhouse effect. He asked firstly whether I regard the atmosphere as a resource. I should say that concern for the integrity of the atmosphere is a legitimate responsibility of all Ministers. It is one that this Government has never shied away from, because it is one of the most environmentally responsible governments in the history of Federation. That is true, and I have to acknowledge the fine work done by my colleague, Senator Richardson, who, as Minister responsible for the environment, is one of the most effective Ministers for the environment.

ANSWER.PARA: The new processes announced last week by the Government-part of the package of Cabinet decisions referred to earlier by Senator Richardson-will ensure that environmental and resource development aspects are addressed in an integrated way. These processes include the establishment of a resource assessment commission and the development of a forestry accord and a national forestry inventory. Clearly, the policies for the resource industries are of fundamental importance in addressing problems relating to the atmosphere. These policies include the sustainable use of renewable resources, including forest resources. For the minerals and energy industries, policies include environment protection, efficient use of resources and energy conservation.

In relation to the second part of the question, about the finite nature of the atmosphere, concern for greenhouse-related issues and broader questions of climatic change must, I believe, be kept in perspective. No unequivocal cause and effect relationship has been established. Nonetheless, as I have indicated in recent addresses, we are putting into the atmosphere an ever-increasing quantity of greenhouse gases, and we have to have a responsible way in which to examine ways that we can mitigate any adverse environmental consequences of doing so.

The third part of the honourable senator's question related to the Energy 2000 report. The Energy 2000 report is a most misunderstood document. It should be read more frequently. If it were it would be seen as an inventory of energy resources rather than a long discussion paper about energy policies. However, I must say with respect to the work of my predecessor, Senator Gareth Evans, who chaired the initial Energy 2000 conference, that the issue of the greenhouse effect was not at that time enjoying the public attention that it enjoys now. The conference that Senator Evans chaired was a representative conference of State governments, energy associations and conservationists. I do not want to preach that they perhaps misconstrued their responsibilities then; I want to talk about what are in terms of the future the obligations of the Government to come to grips with the greenhouse effect, which is an issue that has rapidly gained considerable momentum in recent times and one which Mr Kerin and I have been addressing by way of a complete portfolio review. As recently as last Friday, at the meeting of the Australian Minerals and Energy Council, the meeting of State and Commonwealth mining and energy Ministers, we decided to compile under Commonwealth leadership a compendium of what is happening in the States and the Commonwealth on policies related to the greenhouse effect.

In reply to the fourth part of the honourable senator's question, yes, the National Energy Consultative Council can consider energy issues associated with the greenhouse effect. In fact on 14 September last, when I announced the establishment of a National Energy Consultative Council-a body, I should say, that arises out of the Energy 2000 report-I also announced that at the top of the agenda for its first meeting would be a consideration of energy policies against the background of the greenhouse effect and what we should be doing in terms of energy policy preparation in view of that greenhouse effect. I add that the National Energy Consultative Council is also a representative body, being made up, in part, of environmentalist representatives.

In reply to the last part of the question, about funding for basic data collection and analysis on the greenhouse effect, I draw the honourable senator's attention to the Prime Minister's response in the House of Representatives on 3 November to a question without notice from Mr Cohen. The Prime Minister said:

. . . the Government attaches a great deal of importance to obtaining a better understanding of the greenhouse effect . . . and . . . has initiated a review to find out exactly what the range of existing research is in this country and the potential in the light of that review for further research.

The Prime Minister further stated that if it appears that more funds should be made available to enhance research relevant to a better understanding of the greenhouse effect, that will be done. Against that background, I can assure the honourable senator that I would fully support additional funds if basic data collection and analysis on the greenhouse effect in the Government's view indicate the need for additional funding. Finally, my comments made at the National Energy Innovation Awards, to which the honourable senator referred, are comments that I do not think I need to reiterate now but they are comments which I stand by.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Firstly, is the Minister aware that the Energy 2000 conferences to which he referred came after the publication of the 10 documents which formed the Energy 2000 discussion paper? It was to those that I referred. Secondly, are we to assume from the Minister's reply that separate from the Energy 2000 document his Government is preparing an energy policy for Australia?

—The answer to the first part of the supplementary question is yes. The answer to the second part is that I have referred the issue of the greenhouse effect to the National Energy Consultative Council as the first priority issue for that Council to address in advising the Government on energy policy. That Council is meeting, I think, next week in Canberra, and I look forward to its deliberations.

—On 4 November Senator Teague asked me a question about the proposed exchange of embassies with Romania, and I said I would follow up one aspect of the supplementary question that he asked me. The situation is this: Romania has formally requested that it be permitted to reopen its embassy in Australia and that we reciprocate by opening an embassy in Bucharest. Romania did maintain an embassy in Canberra from 1976 to 1983. Australia has agreed to the reopening of a Romanian embassy in Canberra. It is established practice that Australia allows those countries with which it has full diplomatic relations to maintain resident embassies in Australia, and we expect the embassy to reopen sometime in 1989. Australia has informed the Romanian Government that we will not be opening an embassy in Bucharest.

—In the Senate on 3 November I undertook to provide a response to Senator Michael Baume's questions relating to the production of two booklets, Achievements in Aboriginal Affairs 1983-87 and A Renewed Commitment, and the video entitled A Solid Foundation. I am advised that approximately 6,950 copies of the booklet Achievements in Aboriginal Affairs 1983-87 were produced at a cost of $10,407. Staff costs are unquantifiable. About 3,031 copies of the booklet were posted. Approximately 300 copies of the speech A Renewed Commitment were printed at the Australian Government Publishing Service sub printery and additional copies were printed in-house, at a total cost of approximately $807. Staff costs are unquantifiable. About 3,000 copies of the speech were posted. Approximately 700 copies of the video A Solid Foundation were produced at a total cost of $23,683. This cost includes $200 for the design of the video cover and $418 for the printing of the cover. Staff costs are unquantifiable. A total of 694 videos were distributed. It should be noted that these productions costs represent a downward revision of those included in Mr Holding's return to the Australian Electoral Commission. The revisions arise from a re-examination by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs of the costs involved. It should also be noted that the Australian Electoral Commission does not require costs associated with the postage of electoral material to be included in a return of electoral expenditure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine . . . should be ashamed at the language she has used tonight about our service men and women . . . I believe that Australian service men and women should know of the total lack of support that they would receive at the hands of Senator Vallentine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I was interested to read the report on the operation of the Student Assistance Act and also the press release issued by Mr Peter Reith, the shadow Attorney-General, and the then shadow Minister for Education, Mr Jim Carlton, on 24 March. The press release referred to documents obtained under the Freedom of Information Act revealing a saga of incompetence, cover-up and poor administration by the Government in dealing with billions of dollars of fraud against the Commonwealth. The documents included confidential minutes of meetings of the Government's fraud committee, various correspondence, an independent report from Price Waterhouse and some extraordinary cases of fraud. The press release outlined key features of the Price Waterhouse report into the Department of Employment, Education and Training. It stated:
the schemes where fraud and overpayment are potentially greatest are Austudy Tertiary, Austudy Secondary, Astudy and Absec.
``the scope for fraud and overpayment against the Commonwealth in relation to the present student assistance scheme is substantial''-
that was a quote from the report-

the fact that the Department has 300 administrators who ``ensure applicants obtained maximum entitlements'' and treat recipients as `clients' engenders an attitude or ``service environment'' which ``creates risks''-
again, those are quotes from the report-
By contrast, no one in the Department was on full-time assignment to combat fraud.
the Department has a ``loose administrative control environment''.
``virtually no analytical anti-fraud work has ever been conducted in the Department''.
strong criticism for the fact that ``no detailed review of applications processing has taken place since a `methods' study in 1982''.
the revelation of ``significant fraud in the research grants program''.
``withdrawal from studies is the major avenue for overpayment in the student assistance scheme''.
``Departmental prosecution and investigation activity in the Student Assistance area has not been a high departmental priority''.
the proposal to conduct a survey ``aimed at measuring the incidence of fraud'' was deferred ``until a more opportune time in 1988''-
again, those are quotes from the report-

the report details cases of fraud which have been detected. One adult secondary student received $167 944 before being convicted and placed on a good behaviour bond. Another student received $1700 for free air travel between Townsville and Sydney.

And so it continued. Documents extracted from the Attorney-General's Department on the fraud steering committee revealed attempts to play down the extent of fraud. Given all of that, I was surprised to see that those serious allegations were dealt with in one paragraph of the report. I read from page 1 of the report on the operation of the Student Assistance Act 1987:

Amendments to the Act were introduced into the Parliament during 1987 to provide significantly increased penalties for attempts to defraud the Commonwealth's student assistance schemes and to bring investigative procedures and options for the recovery of overpayments into line with those available in the Social Security Act. The amendments were still before the Parliament at the end of the year.

It seems strange to me that while we have an independent report and indications from the fraud steering committee that gross acts of fraud are being undertaken by students, so little reference is made to them and there are no suggestions as to how they will be overcome. Penalties will do something about it rather than the report indicating future plans for schemes to be put in place to investigate those frauds. I do not feel at all assured by the report that mechanisms will be in place. I alert the Department of Employment, Education and Training that I for one will be keeping a close watch on the Department to ensure that those attempts at fraud will be investigated appropriately. I hope that attention will be given to that in the next annual report so that the Senate and the public can be assured that people will be brought to justice if they defraud the Australian taxpayer in a way that has gone on for many years, and ignored by the Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1987 report on the operation of the Student Assistance Act arises out of the requirement in the Act, set by this chamber, that such reports be made. It is an interesting exercise now that we have received the first of these reports to go through it. Unfortunately, some of the tabulations are not of the type that would be readily useful to many people outside in trying to estimate what is going on with the operation of this Act. But, more importantly than that, the Government is now looking at a review of the postgraduate award scheme through the Higher Education Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training that was set up by an Act of this Parliament in the middle of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The major problem in terms of the review as against the White Paper is that we are likely to find that there will be increased emphasis, following the Government's insistence, on national priorities-a term that has not actually been explained. My worry is that we are going to provide scholarships on the basis of public servants' perception of the national interest rather than on the basis of excellence. For example, I foresee that we are likely to find that people with second class honours in, say, commerce are preferred to people who have outstanding first class honours in literature. The ultimate distribution of scholarships resulting from an exercise along that line will severely depress the pursuit of excellence within our tertiary institutions, particularly within the various disciplines that are said not to be of great importance to so-called national priorities.

The difficulty in working out national scholarships is, I think, in the notion of who might set those priorities. It is interesting when one goes back through educational history to discover that a whole variety of people who could have benefited from the provision of scholarships in fact did not. One example that comes readily to mind is the problem that Einstein had in getting any support for his type of work because it was of theoretical kind. In fact, the bureaucrats of his time were unable to get their minds around it. Presumably it was also encompassed in what might be called at that stage `national priorities'. We are lucky that people of his type of genius managed to overcome the inhibitions put in their way by people of stunted vision. If we should embark on such a course here as the basis for providing assistance to our students, we will be embarking on a scheme which will be to the national detriment while it will be promoted by the bureaucrats as being for the national benefit and in accordance with national priorities. It will be an everlasting national disgrace if we do not seek to promote and assist people who have the capacites and the excellence and who have done the hard work to partake of further higher studies. Rather, we will be contributing directly to mediocrity. I think that that is the central problem that will confront us in this area as a result of the White Paper's philosophy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I note that the third satellite has been successfully launched and that Aussat Pty Ltd is now reducing its losses. The system's use was increased by 28 per cent and revenue was up by 40 per cent to $104m for the year, so apparently it is now on target for profits next year. The coalition parties welcome the fact that Aussat is on target to make profits. We recognise that Aussat is providing a commercial service to Australia, and I emphasise the words `commercial service' because it is our policy that Aussat should be privatised. Our policy is:
To enable this potential-
that is, Aussat's potential-

to be fully achieved, the Liberal and National parties will transfer ownership of Aussat to the private sector by the sale of 100 per cent of its shares to the public, with preference given to Aussat employees. No foreign person or company will be permitted to own shares and no person or company will be permitted to own more than 15 per cent of the issued shares of the company.

We believe that that is the way to go for Aussat. The interests of all Australians would be served by Aussat being owned in the private sector. Page 10 of this annual report mentions pay television. Last week the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, made a speech about television in the next decade and repeated what was said by the Hawke Government in 1986, that there would be a moratorium on pay television until September 1990. But having said that, he went on to say in essence that the Department is now preparing an options paper and in due course, and some time before September 1990, the Minister will make a submission to Cabinet on what should happen with regard to pay television after that date. He talked about the use of Telecom Australia's fibre optic cable, whereas in this report Aussat talks about pay television being provided by way of a satellite service. Telecom's fibre optic cable, to quote what the Minister said, is not likely to be available until well into the 1990s.

The coalition parties are not opposed to Telecom contracting to allow the use of its fibre optic system for pay television or any other service. We would welcome that. But Australians should not have to wait until that system is in place before they get access to pay television. By then some new, better or different system may have been discovered. What we say is, open up the service to enterprise and initiative now. That is our policy. Frankly, the Government's approach is just not good enough. We are committed to allowing the immediate introduction of pay television services, whether they operate by satellite, by cable or whatever system is available to some entrepreneur. This again shows the difference between the Hawke Government and the coalition. The Hawke Government is about words, empty rhetoric. There is a lot of talk about deregulation and freeing up the system. But with the Hawke Government it is always going to happen at some time in the future. The coalition is talking about doing it now. This arrogant and out of touch Hawke Government simply is not acting to address the concerns of the people of Australia for the late 1980s and 1990s. It should be fixing up coastal shipping. It should be fixing up the labour market. It should be concerning itself with the declining living standards of Australians. After the next election we shall see what the people of Australia have thought about this currently inactive, out of touch Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the remarks of Senator Lewis in relation to the annual report of Aussat Pty Ltd and in particular I welcome his comments regarding access to pay television and the delay that is being occasioned by Telecom Australia's insistence on the use of fibre optic cables. The community should be in no doubt as to why Telecom exercises such a monopoly control and such insidious influence over these critical decisions. One needs to look no further than the actual structure of Aussat to see that Telecom has 25 per cent of the ownership of Aussat and the power to appoint two directors, and of course it makes good use of that by having the Managing Director of Telecom, Mr Ward, and another senior director-in this instance the Director of Corporate Services-on the Aussat board.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard that as a very unhealthy development. It is not conducive to encouraging Aussat to move to a competitive system. It is certainly not designed to encourage Aussat to take on Telecom in many areas where it is eminently better suited. As Senator Lewis rightly pointed out, a classic example of that would be direct broadcast satellite television. As we now know, this service can be provided in rural and remote areas, but Aussat has a much greater capacity to deliver services right across the board and to be highly competitive with Telecom. In fact, it has the capacity to compete not only in the educational market but in the hotels and clubs markets and in many ways to be the low cost alternative. But because of the manner in which Telecom is able to influence those decisions, I do not have a great deal of confidence that Aussat is going to be able to show any dramatic expansion.

The other matter of utmost concern is that, despite all the cosmetic changes that are supposedly designed to inject a more competitive enterprise arrangements into government business enterprises such as Aussat, the fact remains that Aussat will still have to go cap in hand when it seeks funds for the second generation of satellite systems, which will need to come on stream by the mid-1990s. Despite all of what was said in the May statement, the fact is that Aussat's borrowings will remain subject to Loan Council scrutiny. Although the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will not have the power of veto over day to day borrowings of the magnitude of $600m, which is the sum generally thought to be required for the purchase of a second generation satellite system, those borrowings will certainly remain subject to Loan Council scrutiny. This is yet another example of a government business enterprise that is required to go cap in hand to government, that is not able to take risks out there into the marketplace and obtain funds on the merits of its case. The only way in which Aussat is able to obtain funds is via banks, which insist to a great extent on government guarantees. As a result, Aussat has what would otherwise be regarded as a very uncompetitive gearing ratio.

While the loss of just over $5m is not overly significant and there have been some encouraging signs of progress in relation to product development-and I think generally one can be pleased at Aussat making the most of its limited opportunities-the fact remains that it is still a cripple. It is still going to be a very poor relative of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and Telecom. It is not going to be in any position to flap its wings. While the present structure remains in place, one cannot have any great degree of confidence that Aussat will be a major contributor to satellite development around the world.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It appears from the 1987-88 annual report of the Australian Postal Commission that generally Australia Post is beginning nowadays to do quite a good job. I believe that is a result of some competition which it is now facing. I see from the report that Australia Post delivered over 3.5 billion articles of mail to over 6.5 million addresses in Australia. According to the report, 93 per cent of those articles were delivered within the advertised time and another 6 per cent were delivered only one day late. Unfortunately, the fact that 7 per cent of articles were not delivered within the advertised time certainly gets under the skin of a lot of people. Certainly, great difficulties are created by the one per cent of articles which are delivered more than one day late. After all, one per cent of 3.5 billion articles of mail is a lot of articles being delivered more than one day late.

The report also claims that productivity performance has increased substantially. Australia Post is certainly to be commended for this. According to the report, labour productivity rose by 3.7 per cent last year, which is about five times the national average of 0.7 per cent identified by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Australia's productivity must continue to increase if we are to become, or remain, internationally competitive. Quite frankly, the current rate of increase in national productivity levels is disgraceful. Australia Post may have started from a low level due to the lack of competitive pressure in the past, and that is possibly the explanation for its current rate of productivity increase, nevertheless, for whatever reason, the coalition parties certainly applaud productivity increases of this magnitude. Australia Post's return on assets is much better than that of many other government business enterprises. It is shown as 7.8 per cent compared with the return on assets by, for example, the Australian Industry Development Corporation-the annual report for which is also tabled today-at only one per cent.

I think the problem is the value of Australia Post's assets. One would wonder whether Australia Post should be questioned about the location and quality of its real estate holdings. Skyrocketing real estate prices around Australia, combined with Australia Post's accounting method of cost less depreciation, probably means that the true value of Australia Post's assets is substantially understated. Therefore, its return on assets probably is nothing like the 7.8 per cent shown in the report. Of course, the profitability of any enterprise depends in part on the tax regime that it faces. Australia Post is only now starting to face some of the tax imposts which have long burdened the private sector in Australia. I wonder how long it will be before Australia Post's voice is added to those of industry and the coalition parties in calling for substantial reform of the taxation system because Australia Post is now about to face those imposts.

One of the things which concern me greatly relates to those developments whereby Australia Post appears to be cross-subsidising some of its related services. The report talks about Australia Post having a competitive edge in agency services. It talks about its unique national retail network and the fact that it currently provides travel related services. In one of today's newspapers we read that Australia Post will soon be selling letterboxes. All of these things are to be applauded if they are coming out of enterprise initiatives of offices of Australia Post, but they are not to be applauded if they are coming out of cross-subsidies arising as a result of Australia Post increasing its charge for ordinary mail from 37c to 39c. That is one of the reasons why the coalition parties would be looking to Australia Post to provide statements of income and expenditure on the basis of profit centres rather than a general statement of income and expenditure as set out in this annual report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments on the 1987 annual report of the Australian Postal Commission. I will deal first with a couple of aspects of its service which are outlined in the report. The first is its service performance targets as outlined on pages 16 and 17 where is it shown that 93 per cent of envelope mail was delivered within advertised times and in excess of 99 per cent was delivered within the advertised times or one day later. I think this is an impressive result but, apparently, it is not enough for Australia Post and a target of 94 per cent has been set for next year. I think that shows a level of commitment to providing consumers with an increasingly better service, and that is a credit to Australia Post.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing that I would like to mention, moving through the report, is the excellent stamp issues during this bicentennial year. I must say that the `living together' series of stamps featuring Australia's leading cartoonists was particularly interesting. It highlighted a large number of important aspects of Australia's life and it was typical of the exceptional high standard of our stamp designs, many of which were very appropriate, as I said, in this our bicentennial year.

On page 60 the report lists information on the numbers of post offices and post office agencies in Australia as at 1 July 1987 and then 1 July 1988. I note that the number of post offices has decreased, as has the total number of agencies. This is indeed a concern as it has occurred in a period of population growth and a growth in mail volume and delivery points. What is perhaps of even greater concern is the prospect of even greater cuts which have come before us in recent days with respect to what are vital services. I refer to further closures or downgrading to agencies of other mechanisms which appear to be in the minds of planners within Australia Post.

A large number of Australians, and particularly Australians in rural areas, I do not believe will take this lying down. It is certainly something that the Australian Democrats protest about very strongly. If the rumours which have been abroad this past week or so are accurate, in particular the one that suggests that there are plans to close post offices in rural centres with populations of less than 3,000, I suggest that there would have to be an enormous backlash. It would be a backlash not just against Australia Post or even this Government but in the face of the privatisation policy of the Opposition it would be a backlash which, unless the Opposition repudiates that sort of plan, would occur in those electorates that the Opposition claims it supports.

In the year that the closures noted in this report have occurred I think we should note and place on the record that at least one beautiful new post office has opened-here in this new Parliament House. We do not appear to be subject to the restrictions that people in isolated and remote areas are being placed under through the closure of post offices and the downgrading of services. I think that people in rural and remote areas would have every right to be a touch cynical, especially as our post office is not only brand new but also operates on very extended hours which are not available to those people.

I find it quite an irony that there is a prospect of the closure of post offices in the same week in which the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Bill has been passed by agreement between the Opposition and the Government. The post office will be a major point of access for people in the community to gain a tax file number, which will be very important to them unless they want to pay the top tax rate as a penalty for not having a tax file number. Once again, country people are disadvantaged. They face the prospect of having to travel long distances for services which are taken for granted by people who live in urban areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to speak on the 1987 annual report of the Australian Postal Commission. I do not think one can take a great deal of notice of the figures contained in the annual report of an organisation that has a monopoly in a wide range of areas. Certainly to use the language of `rate of return' in terms of financial targets demonstrates a lack of understanding of the inadequacies of that concept. It is quite clear, as my colleague Senator Lewis pointed out, that Australia Post operates on an historical cost valuation basis on many of its real estate holdings. In those circumstances the real rate of return is likely to be much lower than that publicly disclosed.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is disappointing to have the sort of mindless reaction that we have just had from Senator Powell. I presume it is at first blush rather than considered, because this Parliament House has gone from a population of zero to in excess of 3,000, I think. In a situation where most of its inhabitants are inveterate users, at least indirectly, of the Australian postal system, it is not surprising that there should be an increased demand that must be met with that response. The problem in rural and remote areas quite often is that there is a declining demand. No-one is suggesting that people who need postal services should not have them. What is being suggested is that those services should be delivered more efficiently. That is what is behind the concept that Australia Post is valiantly trying to float at the moment of contracting out and franchising. I would support that approach because--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would you buy a franchise for something that is unprofitable?

—If it is unprofitable, one has to ask the question: is it a service that should continue to be provided? If it should be provided, then it should be provided by government. It is quite clear that that can be done by applying a levy on all other personal uses if necessary.
—Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the third report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on proposals for variations to the plan of layout of the City of Canberra and its environs, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have a short statement in relation to the report incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
This report is the third report prepared by the Joint Sub-Committee on Variations to the Plan of Layout of the City of Canberra and its Environs and covers Variation 1988/4.

Variation 1988/4 contains two proposals to vary the City Plan-one to rectify the encroachment of a driveway onto Commonwealth land in Bruce; the other to provide for an access for a residential development in Isaacs.

Although the proposals were only gazetted on 14 October 1988, the ACT Administration asked that we look at these proposals quickly. The NCDC, following public consultation, received an objection to the Variation. The Joint Sub-Committee held a public hearing on the Variation last Tuesday, 15 November 1988.

A number of issues were raised at the public hearing. In relation to the driveway encroachment in Bruce, it was pointed out to the Joint Sub-Committee that the house on the block concerned was prominent and the siting and design of it did not blend in with the topography. Special building conditions were imposed on houses in the Bruce south area. However, these conditions were not so well-enforced in the later stages of the development and therefore this house is at the lower end of the acceptability range.

Further, there were changes to the development plan which took in the Hill Reserve behind the Bruce south development. Residents were neither consulted or informed of the changes to the nature-cum-fire trail nor were they consulted on the construction of a pedestrian access in the gully.
The Isaacs proposal provides for an access road to enable development of standard residential blocks by the Housing Industry Association.

The briefing notes provided to the Joint Sub-Committee on this proposal by the NCDC and ACT Administration were misleading. The notes indicated that the access road was to be constructed when in fact it had already been built.

The Committee is concerned that developers should not seek approval from the Joint Sub-Committee for gazettals which are of a retrospective nature. An administrative process which allows such a situation to occur is clearly inadequate and this causes a serious concern about how future private sector development will proceed. The current procedure which enables private developers to pre-empt the parliamentary approval process must be revised.

The Joint Sub-Committee has approved the two proposals in Variation 1988/4, as the Bruce proposal is a minor road addition and the access road in Isaacs is the only logical means of sub-dividing the block. In so doing, the Committee expresses its concern that the NCDC did not ensure compliance with the building conditions in all instances in the Bruce south development and that there was no public consultation following changes to the development plan which takes in the Hill Reserve.

The Committee is also concerned that the ACT Administration allowed construction of the access road in Isaacs to proceed when there was still uncertainty about its status. Seeking retrospective approval for a variation to the road plan of Canberra makes a mockery of the parliamentary review procedure.

In future any project for which there is even a slight possibility of the inclusion of a public road should be sent to the Joint Parliamentary Sub-Committee for approval as early as possible in the planning process. Otherwise the private sector land development process will simply become a means for avoiding public scrutiny of Canberra's development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1988-89[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1988-89APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1988-89]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 October, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek the concurrence of the Senate to have the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1988-89 debated cognately with Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1988-89.
—If there is no objection, that course of action will be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is now to debate three Appropriation Bills which cover the appropriation of the bulk of the funds which are required for the carrying on of government over the coming year. This debate presents an opportunity for the Opposition and, indeed, the whole of the Senate to debate generally the Government's record and program. The Opposition welcomes the opportunity that this debate provides. Indeed, I am somewhat surprised to find that no less than 39 senators have indicated their desire to speak in this debate. I think that reflects the level of concern which there is in this chamber about the situation in Australia today. The Opposition, for its part, faces an embarrassment of charges to make against the Government. The difficulty will be not merely to limit the time of this debate but to limit the scope to ensure that the charges that we make against the Government are understandable. In fact, one could put in months of debate on what is clearly going wrong with the Government's various programs. It is an unfortunate fact and a concession to reality that we have to restrict the debate within the time available to us.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to start the debate by indicating that I will move an amendment in relation to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1988-89 which focuses on some of the Opposition's key concerns. The amendment reads as follows:

At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate condemns the arrogant and out of touch Hawke Government for the failure of its economic policies and its maladministration in areas such as Aboriginal affairs and the Australian Bureau of Statistics, and, in particular, the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) producing stagnant productivity, high inflation, a continuing balance of payments crisis and rising interest rates which are hurting business and home buyers alike;

(b) raising, then dashing, Aboriginal expectations with unrealistic and divisive promises on national land rights and a so-called Treaty and for appalling mismanagement at both ministerial and bureaucratic levels; and
(c) coercing participation in the ABS Household Expenditure Survey in the face of substantial doubt about its validity and legal basis,

and calls on the Australian people, as they have done in by-elections this year, to reject the Hawke Government and support the policies of the Liberal and National Parties, which reflect community values and which will deliver improved living standards for those millions of Australians who have been abandoned by a Labor Government now totally out of touch with their hopes and aspirations.

The proposed amendment refers to a government which is arrogant and out of touch. One need go no further back than yesterday to see an example of why the people of Australia are so disenchanted with the Hawke Government. Yesterday during Question Time Senator Patterson rose in her place and asked the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), representing the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), a question about the impact that high interest rates-and as a result, the high cost of buying a house-were having on Australian families and the preparedness of young Australians to undertake the rearing of children. The fact is that we face a very low birth rate in this country. We face a situation where we do not reproduce our own population. It is increasingly clear that many young Australians have a choice between child bearing and child rearing, and home ownership. That is a comparatively recent phenomenon.

The sad fact is that the extraordinary price of housing and the very high interest rates have combined to confront many young Australians with an unpalatable choice. That is a matter which has been the subject of public comment by bankers, people in the home lending industry generally and people who are concerned simply with the impact this is having on society. What sort of response did we get from Senator Cook? We got a response which was abusive of Senator Patterson. He suggested that she was drawing a long bow in making this connection between the ability of young Australian couples to plan for a family and the extraordinarily high financial demands which are made upon them if they wish to own a house-something which has been part of the normal ambitions of most Australian couples. That was but one example of a Government which has failed to keep in touch with the people who elected it.

Senator Cook comes from my State of Western Australia. By his reply he might as well have come from the moon. He was apparently totally unaware and unconcerned about the very real pressure which people are feeling. The fact that lending institutions can say to young couples, `We will require a commitment from you that you will be a two income family; there will be a postponement of child rearing for 10 years' is most extraordinary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Double income, no kids.

—It is institutionalising the double income, no kids family. If one stops and thinks about the welfare of our country and our society, what could be more central? I pause on that point because I think it encapsulates what can be described in a lot of statistics. Much of this debate will go to what is wrong with the economy, but that simple area, so central to the lives of so many Australians and to our functioning as a country and as a society, encapsulates much of what the economic theory will be about. We are concerned about the position of the men and women of Australia and the pressures they are being put under by this arrogant and out of touch Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is that sort of example which explains the vast disenchantment with the Labor Government. I have agreed to restrict my time in this debate in the interests of allowing other speakers to participate, so I do not have time to dwell on the Labor Party's misfortunes in the by-elections of this year. Let me simply mention the by-election in the Western Australian State seat of Balga, when the unlamented ex-Premier Burke went his way. We had a by-election in one of the strongest Labor seats in Western Australia, and the swing was close to 23 per cent. I have certainly never before worked in an election where there has been a swing of nearly 23 per cent. It is hard core Labor country, full of battlers and people on modest to low incomes-people who traditionally have supported Labor. The simple explanation as to why such a huge proportion of them swung to the Liberal Party can again be encapsulated in the following example: A man handing out Liberal how to vote cards in the polling booths to whom I spoke said to me, `Senator, I have voted Labor all my life and I am voting Liberal now because I cannot pay my bills. I work just as hard as I did before but I cannot pay my bills and I have to find an extra job to do at night just to keep my head above water'. That person represents what this Government has done to the average earners of this country.

For those who want a technical description relating to this, a paper published recently by the Economic Planning Advisory Council shows graphs of the taxes paid by Australians. One can see that the average amount of tax paid by income earners at different levels is growing and growing. It is fascinating. In recent years there has been a bit of a downturn in taxes that are paid by high income earners, but taxes have not been reduced for average income earners, or for the very large number of people on salaries of about three-quarters of average weekly earnings-and one should remember that 70 per cent of Australians earn less than average weekly earnings.

This Government has had an interesting set of priorities. It reduced company tax by 10c on 1 July and told the average earners of this country that they could wait at least 12 months for a tax reduction. There was no tax reduction for them, but as from 1 July this year there was a reduction of 10c in the company tax rate from the previous 49c in the dollar. There is no relief for the average wage earner until just before an election. The breathtaking cynicism of the Government's approach to this matter is, again, the simplest explanation of why so many people deserted the Labor Party in by-elections in the past 12 months.

The fact is that the high interest rates and high tax rates which have put such pressure on suburban Australia and on rural Australia are a conscious part of Government policy. It is this Government which chose to postpone tax cuts until just before an election. It is this Government which said to the trade union movement, `There will be no tax relief for you. We will have a wage-tax trade off next year when it suits us-next year, an election year, but nothing now'.

The Government has locked itself into spending policies and wage policies which mean that one of the few weapons it has to cope with Australia's current economic difficulties is interest rates. So, as a conscious act of policy, the Government has shoved up interest rates in a way that has impacted on everybody in this country who is buying a house, everybody who is running a farm and everybody who is running a business. That is not some accident of international trade but a conscious act of Government policy. That is the Hawke-Keating policy for Australia, and it shows no regard for the welfare of the people who elected this Government. All of the Government's para- meters have been set for political purposes. They have been set to meet the timing of the next election; they have not been set to meet the economic welfare of Australia and they have not been set to meet the economic welfare of the individual people of Australia.

Alternative strategies have been available to the Government. The Government could have given earlier tax cuts and engaged in some arrangement with the trade union movement in a tax-wage trade-off, as it has promised to do next year. That course was open to it. The option was open to it to take a harder line on expenditure. Last year, private meetings were being told by Senator Walsh that there were a couple of hundred programs that could have been tackled. The Government chose, in turn, to knock back basic reforms in industrial relations.

The Government sees continued waste in the field of industrial relations and growing amounts of industrial disputes, but it knocks back basic reforms and refuses to countenance them-one of the avenues which would have enabled us to have a more productive economy and enabled the people of Australia to have a high rather than a low standard of living. The big concern, the concern which is reflected in our amendment, is that the position in which we find ourselves now is even more fragile than the pressure on individuals would indicate.

What has happened over the past two years is that, since Mr Keating said in 1986 that we were headed for the status of a banana republic, things have not got better; they have got worse. What has changed since 1986 is that the price of our commodities has improved. The prices at which foreigners will buy Australia's basic exports have gone up since 1986. The terrifying truth is that in relation to our trade in goods and services, what we actually sell abroad and what we buy from abroad, the gap has become bigger, not smaller. The truth is that in physical terms, if we measure what we sell against what we buy, our trade balance is worse now than it was two years ago. That means that next time we have a drop in our commodity prices-nobody predicted the recent increases, and we know how volatile commodity prices can be-we will have even more significant problems that we had in 1986.

What will happen if there is a dropping away of our trade figures because the price of commodities falls? I simply remind those people who are groaning under high interest rates now that one of the weapons the Government will have to use then to cover our appalling trade balance will be a further dose of high interest rates. That is the strategy that the Government will have to follow. That is the hope that this Government is offering to the people of Australia in the Budget that is represented substantially by these Appropriation Bills. The fact is that the Government has got it dramatically and severely wrong. Our merchandise trade balance-in the end this is our living as a country-our export of goods less the import of goods, has deteriorated rapidly. The trade deficit for the first four months of this year, at $1.64 billion, is more than twice the size of the deficit for the same period last year.

There is a bit of a sense of complacency in one section of the community in Australia, and that is the business community. Quite a few sections of the business community are sitting back and enjoying the high commodity prices. I remind the Senate and the business community that suburban Australians, unlike the people who elected Senator Colston, who is sitting opposite me in the Senate now, are feeling the pain. Much of the big business end of town is not feeling the pain at the moment. However, let me remind the big business end of town that one sees from any of the key economic statistics that we remain in a perilous position, very akin to our position in 1986. This relates not just to the imbalance in our trade. Our inflation rate to September was 7.3 per cent and it was 4 per cent in the United States of America and Canada. It was 0.5 per cent in Japan and a little over one per cent in West Germany. So inflation is twice the rate of that of our Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) trading competitors. Our wage rises are twice to three times as high. Interest rates in Australia are 15 per cent and rising compared with 10 per cent in the United States, a little over 3 per cent in Japan, 6 per cent in West Germany and 13 per cent in the United Kingdom. Our tax rates are uncompetitive and our productivity is stagnant.

Statistics have been issued in the last few days which show an appalling productivity situation in Australia. We could enter into all sorts of fancy arguments about the causes of that-the shift towards a more service orientated economy, you name it. The truth is that our productivity level, not just labour but labour and capital in Australia, is going up at about half the rate of OECD countries. That is a situation which guarantees that our comparative position is getting worse instead of better. Stagnant productivity is one of the brilliant gifts that the Australian Labor Party has given to Australia. We do not congratulate it on that; we condemn it. We have a high foreign debt which is still growing, and it will continue to climb given our continuing trade imbalance. Real personal incomes are squeezed with the combined effects of personal tax and interest rates, and industrial disputes are rising. The situation is that we therefore have a very fragile economy at a time when the men and women of Australia are broadly saying, `We have had enough. We are sick of this squeeze and we want some relief from the Government'. The truth is that the totality of what the Government is doing simply means that the chances are that things will get substantially worse rather than improve.

What does the future hold under Labor? I think it can be fairly said that for the average man and woman in Australia the future holds more of the same or worse, and that is not an adequate mess of potage to be serving up to the Australian people. The fact is that any weakening of our export prices will accelerate our debt problem and put more pressure on interest rates.

I remind the Senate that there are still alternatives that the Government could follow. Probably the most central changes that could be made are changes to the labour market. We indicated in detail the sorts of changes we wanted in the recent debate on the industrial relations legislation, but the truth is that the living standards of Australians are sacrificed in myriad ways by the Government's failure to come to grips with defects in our labour market.
