There are areas of conspicuous waste on our waterfront; there are areas of conspicuous waste in transport, not least in coastal shipping; and there are areas of conspicuous waste in industries like the coal industry, which has a strike record of 40 times the industry average.

Many things could be done to make the Australian economy more efficient. The Government's own McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport said that inefficiencies in the transport sector because of lack of competition means that grain growers on average are paying $10 per tonne too much in transport charges. If we want to understand why Australians are poorer than they should be, it is necessary only to look at some of those areas of conspicuous waste brought about by lack of competition. Think of the farmers who, in recent bad seasons, have gone broke or nearly broke, and think of the difference it would have made to them if they had been getting $10 per tonne more for their grain because of an efficient transport system. It is in those areas of reform that this Government has totally failed. In this debate on the Appropriation Bills I make the point that the available alternatives, the more constructive approaches which could have been adopted by the Government to increase our national wealth, have too often been ignored, and we therefore have a very gloomy prospect for too many Australians.

I want to close by referring briefly to the position of Australian families and by going back to the arrogant and out of touch Senator Cook. Senator Cook, in response to Senator Patterson yesterday, said this:
This Government's record in terms of assistance to families in Australia and its record on the provision of public housing is second to none.

With respect to the provision of public housing, when the Hawke Government came to power there were about 100,000 Australians on public housing waiting lists. Five years later there were 150,000 Australians on public housing waiting lists. That is the brilliant record of the Hawke Labor Government-50 per cent more Australians on waiting lists for public housing.

With respect to assistance to families, I condemn the Government for the fact that the only families it has been prepared to help have been those on the lowest incomes. It has been prepared to help 10 per cent or so of families through the family allowance supplement. The truth is that all other families have seen the terms of trade move against them, with no adjustment to the family allowance and no adjustment to the taxation system to take into account their position. Those Australians who have borne the heaviest brunt of the financial burdens under Labor have been middle income families with dependent children. This Government has a disgraceful sense of priorities. It has ignored that substantial group of its own supporters but, most importantly, it has ignored that group of people who are doing something fundamental to the nation's good-bringing up the next generation of children. My final remark is that some adjustment of both the taxation and the welfare systems in favour of families with dependants is grossly overdue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2), which constitute the expenditure side of the Budget for 1988. The Hawke Government was given a clear mandate in July last year to continue its program of structural adjustment to the Australian economy. For the record, this adjustment is to help bring foreign debt under control, a process which is now well under way--
—It is still increasing.

—The rate of growth has been reduced. There is very slow growth. If the honourable senator would like to stay for the next 20 minutes or so, I will inform him as to the reasons. The process of adjustment will also enable the development of new, dynamic export orientated manufacturing industries in the Australian economy. The Federal Government's Budget strategy and macro-economic policies have a fundamental role in setting the right conditions for structural adjustment in the Australian economy. Last year's Budget and the economic statement of May this year made substantial reductions to Commonwealth expenditure in order to reduce domestic demand in the Australian economy and to reduce the public sector borrowing requirement which has been an important objective of policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to dwell on the public sector borrowing requirement for a moment, because I think in that area we have on the record a major achievement for the Hawke Government. For example, in 1983-84, the first full year of activity after we were elected in 1983, the Commonwealth Government's net public sector borrowing requirement constituted 4.2 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product, but in the last financial year, 1987-88, instead of 4.2 per cent of gross domestic product, or Australia's national income, being accounted for by public sector borrowing there was in fact a negative public sector borrowing requirement of minus 0.8 per cent of gross domestic product.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be hugely consoling to the suburban people you represent.

—There has been a very big turnaround in the records. When Senator Chaney's leader, Mr Howard, was Treasurer of this country and Senator Chaney was a Minister in the Government led by Malcolm Fraser, public sector borrowing totalled about 4 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. Now, as a result of the policies of the Hawke Government, there is no net borrowing occurring at the Commonwealth level. So there has been a big change.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the period of the Hawke Government there has been a change in budgetary strategy from the high economic growth of its earlier years. This has been necessitated by the dramatic decline in Australia's terms of trade, which is, of course, the ratio of the prices we receive for our exports to the prices we pay for our imports. In the 1985-86 financial year those terms of trade declined by over 10 per cent and in 1986-87 they declined by over 4 per cent. That decline, as we are well aware, is outside the Government's control and essentially reflects the long term decline in international commodity prices compared with the prices paid for manufactured products. However, I am pleased to note that in the last financial year, 1987-88, there has been an increase in the terms of trade, that is, a relative improvement in our export prices compared with our import prices, of 8.2 per cent. That has contributed to national income growth, to gross domestic product growth, in Australia. That turnaround has also meant encouraging news in terms of Australia's foreign debt. Senator Chaney interrupted me a moment ago to mention foreign debt. The record is that in 1986-87 Australia's net external debt-and I am talking about the net debt-was $82.1 billion, or 31.5 per cent of gross domestic product, but by the end of the 1987-88 financial year it was not 31.5 per cent of gross domestic product; it had in fact been reduced by over a full percentage point to 30.4 per cent. The growth in the foreign debt has been slowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to increase the exchange rate by the same amount next year too, are you?

—As Senator Stone is well aware, the great part of the foreign debt owed by this country is owed not by the Commonwealth Government or, indeed, by State governments but by the private sector, the capitalistic sector, of the economy, which has borrowed overseas in recent years to finance large takeovers. That is for the record. In fact, the relative amount of foreign debt, both government and private, has been stabilised. In relation to gross domestic product, which is growing strongly, the ratio has fallen significantly.

SPEECH.PARA: The important thing about this Government's policies is that the Government has moved to correct external imbalances without inducing recession or attacking living standards directly. The Government has been restructuring the economy and overcoming external constraints by pursuing a strategy of restraint with equity. For example, the Hawke Government has rejected outright the traditional, conservative, Liberal strategy of shifting the burden of economic readjustment on to the poor and the lower income groups in the Australian community. That was the sort of strategy adopted in the late 1970s and the early 1980s in this country when Senator Stone, who is now in the chamber, was over the road as the head of the Australian Treasury. That was the deliberate strategy of reducing the level of demand in the Australian economy to adjust the economy. As a result of reducing the level of demand, which happened quite rapidly, to try to check the rate of inflationary price rises in the community, more and more Australians were thrown out of work. It is a fact that, in the last 12 months that Mr Howard was Treasurer, 186,000 Australians were thrown out of work; 186,000 were thrown on the industrial scrap heap as a result of Mr Howard's policies, which Senator Stone advised him to adopt. Those were the sorts of policies of honourable senators opposite when they were in government. They deliberately adjusted to external circumstances by strongly reducing the level of demand in the Australian economy. As a result, 186,000 Australians were thrown on the industrial scrap heap. As a result of their policies, 186,000 Australians were thrown out of work.

The 1988 Budget will continue the policy of fiscal responsibility adopted by the Hawke Government. It is a matter of record that the Budget deficit has been progressively reduced since 1983-84 and, in fact, in the last financial year moved into a significant surplus of over $2,000m.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much will taxes go up?

—For Senator Boswell's information, that is the record. We inherited from honourable senators opposite a prospective deficit for 1983-84 of some $9,600m. The outcome for last financial year was a Budget surplus-not a deficit-of over $2,000m. As we are able to read from the Budget Papers for this financial year, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is in fact budgeting for a surplus of over $5,000m for this financial year. Therefore, the turnaround compared with the prospective deficit--
—And a record level of taxation.

—I am going to talk about taxation in a moment. Senator Stone may well learn something from that. The turnaround from the prospective deficit of $9,600m for 1983-84 to a surplus of over $5,400m this year in fact amounts to $15 billion. That is the turnaround in the finances of the Commonwealth as a result of the policies of fiscal responsibility which have been practised by the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stone and recently other honourable senators such as Senator Parer, Senator Messner and Senator Panizza have claimed that the Hawke Labor Government is a high tax government. That is the sort of claim that has been made by those people. However, the fact is that when they were in government-and Mr Howard, who is now the Leader of the Opposition in this country, brought down five Budgets in the period 1978 to 1982-they were not fiscally responsible. Their very record in government shows that the people who now sit on the Opposition benches in this place, despite their rhetoric that we are a high tax government, were not fiscally responsible. That is the record. That is the legacy of the Liberal Party and the National Party when they were in government.

What they preferred to do when they were in government was not to be fiscally responsible at all. They preferred to have Budget deficits. That was what it was all about. That was the easy way out. It was a case of the traditional, soft option of conservative, Liberal Party governments to have the easy way out and run up a Budget deficit instead of taking the hard way out and ensuring that their expenditures at the national level were covered by revenues. In not one of Mr Howard's Budgets-and he brought down five Budgets-were his expenditures covered by revenues. That is the record for the period nationally from 1978 to 1982-a Budget deficit in every year under Mr Howard when he was the Liberal Treasurer.

In fact, it is particularly interesting to note that in 1982-83-that is, the last financial year when Mr Howard was in control of the Treasury and Senator Stone, as I pointed out earlier, was across the road at the Treasury Department advising him-the Budget deficit came in at 2.7 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. That was the record. The Budget deficit in that financial year was equivalent to over one-fortieth of Australia's gross domestic product-broadly defined, Australia's national income. The prospective deficit that they left for us in 1983-84 was not 2.7 per cent but in fact 4.2 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. That is the record of these people when they have the chance to sit on the treasury bench and pull the economic levers and run the Australian economy.

The record shows very clearly that when the Liberals and the Nationals are in power they prefer to have Budget deficits rather than government expenditures covered by revenues. They would not face up on the revenue side of the Budget in that whole period when Mr Howard was the Treasurer from 1978 to 1982. Instead, we have a $5,000m surplus in prospect this financial year, something that Mr Howard never achieved as Treasurer.

Another way of turning this whole debate around, of turning around the rhetoric of Senator Stone, Senator Parer and all the others who sit opposite and who say that Labor is somehow a high tax government, is to look at their record on expenditure. That is the other side of the Budget. That is a very illuminating examination. When one looks at the outlays side of the Budget one sees that, for example, in 1982-83-Mr Howard's last Budget-government expenditures constituted 29 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. That was their record. In the Budget brought down by Mr Keating in August it was not 29 per cent of the Budget taken up with government spending; it was not 28 per cent; it was not 27 per cent; it was not even 26 per cent. In fact, the level of Commonwealth outlays through the Budget this financial year is estimated to be some 25.6 per cent, a massive reduction on the record of Mr Howard and Senator Stone, the dynamic duo, when they were in charge of the Australian economy from 1978 to 1982. That was the record: 29 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product taken up in government spending, compared with 25.6 per cent in prospect this financial year. The record of the Liberal Party and the National Party in government is one of high expenditures and a Budget deficit. That is their record. However, Labor has cut government expenditure to 25.6 per cent of gross domestic product and has a $5,000m surplus as well. That is Labor's record.

One of the reasons for the fall in the ratio of revenue to gross domestic product this year relates to the Budget measures on the excise on beer. For example, last financial year some $1,400m was collected in excise on beer. It is estimated that this financial year some $850m will be collected. So there has been a significant reduction of some $600m in that excise tax. It is pleasing to note that the excise on beer is now based on its alcohol content. The objective of that measure was to cut the retail price of beer and, in that way, to reduce the consumer price index through the price of that very important commodity. Consequently, that will help to assist the disposable income of the many working families in Australia. There has been a very significant reduction in excise revenue in prospect for the consumer price index and an increase in the disposable income of households as a result of that reduction in beer excise.

The Budget surplus of over $5,000m that I have spoken about paves the way for further personal income tax reductions next year. I am sure that there will be significant personal income tax reductions during calendar year 1989. Of course, that will have the effect of boosting the disposable incomes of Australian families. I am sure that both Senator Foreman and the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, who are in the chamber, would wish those tax cuts to focus on lower and middle income families in Australia, because they are the ones who are in particular need. I will certainly be doing all I can to stress to the Government that that is where the focus for the income tax reductions should be during calendar year 1989.

The Budget forecasts are for 3.5 per cent growth in real economic activity this year. The figure is down a little on the 3.8 per cent of last year, but in line with that we predict that the total number of persons employed in the Australian economy will grow by 2 3/4 per cent compared with 3 per cent last year. That is still a very high rate of employment growth compared with other developed countries. As a result of that 2 3/4 per cent estimated growth in employment during the current financial year, the Government expects that the average number of persons who are unemployed on a monthly basis will fall to about 7 1/4 per cent compared with 7.8 per cent last financial year.

This Government's record is one of creating over 1,100,000 new jobs in the Australian economy. In respect of the Liberal and National parties it is very important to look at what they have said in the past, because it is always very illuminating. They play on the assumption that the public has a very short memory. Therefore, it is very important to document what conservative politicians have said in the past. It is illuminating to look at what the Liberals said during the election campaign in 1983 when the present Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, promised that in three years he would create 500,000 new jobs in the Australian economy. I well remember various conservative politicians scoffing at that claim. Based on their past record in government, that was all they could do. No doubt Senator Boswell was out on the hustings in Queensland scoffing at the claim made by Mr Hawke that some 500,000 new jobs would be created in a three-year period. Of course, the record of those opposite in government was one of destroying jobs, not creating them. So one can understand their scoffing.

In just over five years of Labor government in Australia we have not only achieved 500,000 new jobs in three years but the number of new jobs has gone up to 1.1 million. Overwhelmingly, those jobs have been created in the private sector. They have not been created through some sort of Liberal-described bandaid or make-work schemes. It is a matter of record that the average annual rate of new job creation under the Hawke Government has been exactly 3 per cent per annum. There has been 3 per cent growth in employment per annum under the Hawke Government. The record of the Liberals, when Mr Howard was Treasurer, was not 3 per cent, 2 per cent or even one per cent: Mr Howard's average annual growth in employment was 0.7 per cent. Under Labor the rate has been four times as high. If one compares it with the last year in which Mr Howard was in charge of the Treasury, one sees that Labor's rate was an infinitely better result because he destroyed jobs in his last year. A total of 186,000 Australians were thrown on the industrial scrap heap when Mr Howard was in his dying days as Treasurer of this nation.

I want to focus on a couple of key areas in the Budget, particularly in regard to social security, and to make the point that in the Budget there is a very important increase in the payment of the family allowance supplement. As honourable senators would be aware, the Government introduced the family package last year. Currently, it provides financial assistance of up to $22 a week per child to low income families where the children are below the age of 13 years and $28 a week for teenage children. Those payments are available to working families. They are an innovation in the social security system in that the money goes essentially to families whose head is in the work force rather than whose head may be dependent on social security. Those payments are available to families whose head is earning $300 a week or less.

I am pleased to say that this Budget provides for significant increases in the family allowance supplement. That supplement is in the front line of Labor's attack on poverty. There is no doubt, from research on poverty in the Australian economy, that there is a very high incidence of poverty in families with children and in larger families. The family allowance supplement is targeted at children. Therefore, it is in the front line of the attack by the Hawke Government on the scourge of poverty in the Australian economy. It is very important to note that, while a $300 a week income limit applies for the basic payment, some family allowance supplement is available to families having much higher incomes. In fact, a three-child family on an income of up to $24,000 a year can receive part of a supplement. So the family allowance supplement is paid when there is a quite significant income.

This Budget, importantly, provides for an increase in the family allowance supplement from 29 December next. For younger children the $22 a week will be replaced by an amount significantly higher-that is, $24 a week. For children aged from 13 to 15 years, the current $28 becomes $31 a week. It is important to note that that payment is essentially tax-free. It is outside the taxation system. So its equivalent in terms of corresponding wage rises is very large. In other words, a very large wage rise would be required to produce the same impact on disposable income-that is, after-tax income-as the family allowance supplement.

I have been provided with information that suggests that at present some 140,000 low income Australian families, which include over 340,000 children, are benefiting from the family allowance supplement. As I said earlier, essentially the supplement is going to families whose head is in the work force, therefore differentiating it from other sorts of family payments. I would certainly urge families who may be wondering about their entitlements to make sure they check with the local Department of Social Security office as soon as possible to determine their eligibility for this very important payment. I have estimated that in my own State of South Australia, where there are some 13,000 families receiving the supplement, with 32,000 children, the payment is not only attacking poverty but also, on the most conservative assumptions, adding about $32m per annum-that is in one State-to retail spending. So it is a very big boost in two directions-both in attacking poverty and in enabling families to raise their spending power, therefore boosting retail spending in the Australian economy.

Since 1983 the Commonwealth has provided a pensioner rebate of $250 to ensure that those who are wholly or mainly reliant on the pension do not pay income tax. I am pleased that in the 1988 Budget, the one we are now debating, the pensioner rebate rises from the present $250 to $430. The result of this will be that many more Australian pensioners will be exempt from personal income tax in the current financial year. The fact is that formerly, up to 30 June last, the annual amount of pensioner tax free income was $6,142. As a result of the increase in the pensioner rebate, that amount of tax exempt income will rise from $6,142 to $6,892. It is quite a significant amount of tax free income when one considers that members of the work force, employed members of the community, have a tax exempt income of $5,100. It represents a very significant rise in the tax exempt status of income earned by pensioners.

The pensioner rebate is also a very highly equitable measure, one that should be supported as it helps lower income pensioners most and then shades out on higher incomes so that those who are in less needy circumstances do not get the same benefit from it as those on the lowest incomes. In addition to the increase in the amount of tax free income, the levels of income at which the rebate shades out have been increased enormously. While the full rebate of tax will be available on incomes of up to $6,892, part rebates will be available on incomes of up to $10,330, which are significant retirement incomes in the present circumstances in the Australian community. So pensioners can now have incomes, including the pension and investment income in the form of savings bank interest perhaps, up to $10,330 and still get some benefit from the pensioner rebate.

In addition to that, the Government in this Budget has further examined the circumstances of Australia's pensioners and has relaxed requirements for the payment of provisional income tax. In this financial year if pensioners qualify for a part pensioner rebate-that is, if they have incomes up to $10,330-they will not be liable for the payment of personal income tax on a provisional basis. They are very significant improvements in the position of pensioners under the Hawke Government during the current financial year.

Next month the Budget will enable a further increase in the basic rates of pensions to occur to compensate age pensioners and other pensioners for cost of living rises. On my personal calculation-I am not claiming this as the official one-there will be a 3.5 per cent rise in pensions next month based on the increase in the consumer price index in the March and June quarters of this year. This suggests that the standard pension of $120.05 a week should rise from December by $4.20 a week to $124.25. The combined rate of pension, which is currently $200.10 a week, should rise by around $7 weekly to $207.10 a week. I believe that those increases will help pensioners to better keep up with cost of living rises in the Australian community. As a result of those rises, the age pension will come in at around 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. That compares with the figure in the last year when Mr Howard was Treasurer, when pensions approximated 22.7 per cent of average wages.

As we are discussing the 1988 Budget I want to delve very briefly into history and look at the 1987 Budget and particularly at Mr Howard's reply to the speech of the Treasurer last year. It is very interesting to look at some of Mr Howard's claims. I made the point earlier that it is very important to check the claims of conservative politicians-what they said in the past and how they tally with the future. It is particularly interesting to note that on 17 September last year Mr Howard, in his reply to Mr Keating's Budget, said, for example, that the unemployment forecasts in the Budget were wrong and that unemployment had `stalled at 8 per cent or more'. But the reality is that unemployment in Australia is not stuck on 8 per cent; in fact, in the last month for which we have data-October this year-unemployment was not even 7 per cent; it was 6.9 per cent. That is a very tangible case of somebody who claims economic confidence-Mr Howard, the present Leader of the Opposition-being totally wrong. In the same speech on 17 September last year he also described the Government as `fiscal fools'. How can he say that this Government is a group of `fiscal fools' when it is only the second government in many years in the history of Australia to record a Budget surplus? The Budget surplus last financial year was only the second one in the last 35 years. So a couple of Mr Howard's claims can be totally disproven by history, which exposes his lack of competence on economic matters.

The Hawke Government recognises the challenge to Australia's future and through the Budget has responded appropriately by creating the right macro-economic environment in which industries can flourish. In the last 12 months the Government has achieved a Budget surplus, stabilised the exchange rate, continued employment growth policies and continued to focus assistance on the needy. However, governments alone cannot restructure the Australian economy. We need a collective effort from all sectors of the community to build a prosperous economy and society in the next century.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate on the Appropriation Bills to discuss the Government's expenditure this financial year on rural industry assistance through the Department of Primary Industries and Energy as provided for in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and in Appropriation Bill (No. 2), centring on payments in areas of rural research-the national soil conservation program, water research, the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, the national afforestation program, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Australian Democrats I take this opportunity to draw the attention of the Senate to some issues of relevance to the future of agriculture in this country, particularly in the context of the passage of Budget and appropriations legislation. I refer particularly to what the Australian Democrats believe is the increasing recognition that agriculture needs to be sustainable in the long term-a recognition which is penetrating quite significantly the minds of decision-makers and particularly those who are concerned about the long term ability of our basic resource, the land, to sustain agriculture. With this comes the need for research and funding efforts to be directed towards ensuring agricultural sustainability. I have in the past and will no doubt in the future refer to a report entitled Our Common Future, from the World Commission on Environment and Development. I believe that this book puts this point quite well when it states:

The ability to choose policy paths that are sustainable requires that the ecological dimensions of policy be considered at the same time as the economic, trade, energy, agricultural, industrial, and other dimensions-on the same agendas and in the same national and international institutions. That is the chief institutional challenge of the 1990s.
The report also states:
. . . environmental stresses and patterns of economic development are linked to one another. Thus agricultural policies may lie at the root of land, water, and forest degradation.

It is in the context of these views, with which I wholeheartedly agree, that I believe the Federal Government needs to make a concerted effort to direct its agricultural policies and funding programs towards measures which reflect a commitment to ecologically and economically sustainable agriculture. One definition of sustainable agriculture is provided by the National Association for Sustainable Agriculture, Australia (Ltd) (NASAA) and is provided in the 1987 publication entitled Sustainable Agriculture: A Viable Alternative. The authors, Els Wynen, an agricultural economist, and Sandy Fritz, who holds a degree in agriculture, present the definition as adopted by the constitution of NASAA, which I shall read:

A system of agriculture able to balance productivity with low vulnerability to problems such as pest infestation and environment degradation while maintaining the quality of land for future generations. In practice this involves a system which avoids or largely excludes the use of synthetically compounded fertilisers, pesticides, growth regulators, livestock feed additives and other harmful or potentially harmful substances. It includes the use of technologies such as rotations, mechanical cultivation and biological pest crop control; and such materials as legumes, crop residues, animal manures, green manures, other organic wastes and mineral bearing rocks.

I will now spend a few minutes highlighting the major issues discussed in this very valuable book, which is the first in a series of discussion papers to be published by the National Association for Sustainable Agriculture in order, and I quote from the Association's publication, to `stimulate the exchange of ideas and information regarding issues of importance in the field of sustainable agriculture'. In the first instance the book deals with the conventional agricultural production system and issues such as pests, pesticides and pesticides resistance, soil, human health, fertilisers, pesticides and their short and long term effects, feed additives and environmental issues. The book then goes on to deal with these issues as they are related to sustainable agriculture. A comparison of conventional and sustainable farming systems is then addressed, with particular reference to quantity and quality of farm products. A review of the financial aspects of the two farming systems is then undertaken, including the costs of variable inputs such as fertilisers, manures, feed, pesticides, credit and fuel; the fixed inputs of machinery and labour; and the issues of information, research and extension.

A more detailed comparison of the economics of sustainable and conventional agriculture in south-eastern Australia is presented by Els Wynen, one of the authors of the book which I have referred to, in a La Trobe University School of Economics discussion paper, No. 22/88, published in August this year. She concludes:

In summary, the results from the survey indicate that net private financial benefits from sustainable farming were similar to those in the conventional sector in certain areas in 1985-86. This was the case despite that year's relative output prices which were unfavourable for sustainable farmers, despite lack of information about the sustainable management system, and despite the fact that some conventional farmers were likely to be better managers than their sustainable counterparts.

Returning to the book by Wynen and Fritz, chapters 4 and 6 address government policies and different aspects of such policies on conventional and sustainable farming; farmers who have adopted sustainable agricultural practices, both in Australia and internationally; and initiatives in the international sustainable agriculture movement, including activities related to research, extension and education, marketing, and policy development. In their final chapter the authors make a number of concluding comments which I will set out briefly. They say, in answer to the question they pose of whether there is a role for government in encouraging this method of agriculture:

In spite of the viability of some sustainable producers, sustainable farming has not been adopted widely. This is due to a variety of factors, such as the difficulties during the transition period (low initial yields; high input prices (especially for machinery); no premium prices for produce); difficulties in obtaining information about production possibilities; competition with conventional producers who receive preferential treatment in the form of subsidies; restrictive marketing legislation and regulations; and social unacceptability. All these factors decrease the likelihood of farmers transferring from conventional to sustainable agriculture.
They go on to say:

There is a role for government in removing some of these obstacles. However, government involvement need not necessarily be in the form of financial assistance. Increased information about aspects of sustainable systems of farming could be obtained by a redirection of existing research and extension facilities. Equal subsidisation of producers of the different systems would require a change of policies, but not necessarily increased financial assistance. Similarly, changes in marketing regulations do not necessarily imply increased costs to the government, although the establishment and enforcement of standards for sustainable produce might need funding in the early stages. A positive encouragement of sustainable production may require financial assistance in the transition period.

If we read, as I do, the vast volume of material now available on sustainable agriculture systems, we see that one issue keeps reappearing-the need for governments to achieve some semblance of balance in the allocation of research funding for conventional and sustainable farming systems and to undertake a redirection of existing research and extension facilities so as to provide much needed information for farmers. Sadly, these are areas where Australia is lagging behind other countries.

Some initiatives elsewhere include the following-a five-year research program into sustainable agriculture by the Canadian Ministry of Agriculture; comparative studies of conventional and alternative agriculture by education and research stations of the Austrian Government; similar studies by the Swiss Government through its federal agricultural research station and the Research Institute of Biological Agriculture; the financing of a study on organic farming in England and Wales by the United Kingdom Ministry of Agriculture; a 1983 study of biological agriculture by the New Zealand Ministry of Agriculture and a more recent promotion of organic agriculture by the New Zealand Government. Various studies on different aspects of sustainable agricultural practices have also been carried out in the United States, Sweden, the Netherlands and West Germany, with Denmark and the Netherlands providing government extension offices specifically on sustainable agriculture.

Education in sustainable agriculture is also carried out in a number of countries, with the United States now offering degree programs in sustainable agriculture in a number of States. The inclusion of the alternative farming systems information centre as part of the National Agricultural Library to assist farmers wanting to convert from conventional to sustainable systems is another United States initiative, as was the establishment of a chair in sustainable agriculture at the university of Minnesota in 1986. Similar programs and courses in Canadian and New Zealand universities also exist and departments of ecological agriculture and alternative agriculture exist in the Netherlands and West Germany. This is not an exhaustive list.

Meanwhile, down under, the National Association for Sustainable Agriculture has twice had its marketing submission to the Innovative Agricultural Marketing Committee knocked back. Last year the Special Rural Research Council rejected NASAA's submission for meagre funding for its information clearing-house proposal. I sincerely hope that it will be successful in submissions this year, because one of the key issues as outlined by Wynen and Fritz in their publication is the ability to provide information to all farmers so that they can make a real choice between the systems of agriculture that they might wish to undertake.

Given the long but by no means exhaustive list which I have been able to mention here today of interest and action in this area overseas, I think Australia as a primary industry export nation would be less than sensible if it took no notice and did not begin to turn around the approach so that when these moneys are being spent in these Department of Primary Industries and Energy areas, at least a reasonable proportion is allocated in response to submissions from groups like NASAA or from individuals who are showing that they wish to be innovative and responsive to the needs of both the resource base upon which they are dependent for their livelihood and of the community which is increasingly suggesting that it wants to be sure that the food it is buying is safe and clean and that this Government does give due attention and due resources and funding to those people.

I would like to refer to a couple of initiatives. First of all, I draw attention to an initiative under the heading of high country beef which has been undertaken by a former Elders executive, Ron O'Dwyer. This very frustrated man came to see me some weeks ago in my Melbourne office. Although Ron O'Dwyer comes from a beef producing background, he is not just a simple farmer who is trying to break into something new. As I say, he is a former Elders executive and marketing man of proven competence who has been in the meat industry throughout his professional career. His marketing expertise as well as his own consciousness of progress have led to the establishment of the high country beef project. In an article in, encouragingly, the epicure section of the Melbourne Age of 1 November, Mr O'Dwyer is quoted as saying that his long career in meat marketing has left him with a troubled conscience because he believes it is time that Australian consumers knew that their thick, tender steak may be no more natural than Olympic athlete Ben Johnson's thigh muscles. He is quoted in the article as saying:

I'm a marketer, and I look for opportunities, but morally, what we were doing in the industry was wrong. Why are we introducing artificial growth promotants? It all comes back to the bottom line, which is profit.

This man is in this industry for perfectly sound economic reasons, overlaid with a consciousness of the fact that consumers are looking for a particular product. Ron O'Dwyer has gone to great lengths to persuade producers in the high country of the north-east of Victoria to use a private sector firm to test their properties. The producers, who have joined together and are organised, are meeting enormous resistence. The article puts it this way:
High country beef is provoking considerable tension.

It is suggested that one of the problems is that the issue of growth promotants should be kept quiet. Ron O'Dwyer is drawing attention to something which the conventional producers and, more particularly, the large meat organisations do not want attention drawn to. That, of course, flies in the face of what I and the Australian Democrats believe is everyone's right-the right to information and the right to choice.

Ron O'Dwyer has not gathered around him a whole lot of hippy dropouts. He is working in the north-east with third generation beef producers, who one would believe, on the surface and at face value, would be among the most conservative of rural people. But they can see, as he can see, that it is good business to provide for what is a community need and a community wish for a particular product. Yet there needs to be some sort of backup for the marketing proposal if this project is to proceed beyond a small chain of city butchers who have taken the product up.

The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation annual report, which we addressed in this chamber some weeks ago, made great note of the innovative marketing programs which the Corporation supported. Well, it is not supporting this one. If this enterprise of an individual and a group of producers is not supported, quite clearly the larger operations in the meat industry will be able to come in and overpower them. The Democrats strongly suggest that it is this kind of exercise, which also has enormous export potential, that ought to be supported by government and industry programs. We plead with the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to look seriously at these sorts of projects, of which this is but one. As I have already said, Mr O'Dwyer brings a particular expertise to the sustainable agriculture movement, if I might call it that. He brings the expertise of big business and entrepreneurial marketing. I hope that he will persist, as many others in the sustainable agriculture movement have persisted over many years.
An article in yesterday's Australian headed `Nature's way stops whining about pests' contains another example of persistence. The article states:
An Australian wine-maker is cashing in on vast new international markets created by consumer resistance to chemical additives in food production.

These words appeared in the Australian. The article is not something that was written by some nut. It was not written by an Australian Democrat, although we have said often enough that vast new international markets are available and have urged this Parliament and the Government to do what they can to ensure that Australia participates in those markets and that we are not locked out of them because of the foresight shown by our competitors in international agricultural marketing. As I said, New Zealand is doing a great deal in the field of organic agriculture. The same can be said of the United States and some European countries. The article continues:
Mr Gil Wahlquist, of Botolobar Wines in NSW's Mudgee district, has become Australia's first recognised organic wine-maker, a status that is earning him access to lucrative markets at home and abroad.

It is interesting to note that Mr Wahlquist really had no need to export. Apparently a British wine wholesaler heard about his efforts and requested samples of his wine which carry the Botolobar label. I am sure that this New South Wales town will become famous as Mr Wahlquist's wines do. Mr Wahlquist is now exporting to that British wholesaler although, as I said, he does not need to because his product could be totally sold at the cellar door. The article points out:
The grapes are grown without the use of chemical fertilisers or insecticides and his wines are bottled with no preservatives or drastically reduced amounts.

This is a very good story of the sort of process which Wynen and Fritz outlined in the book from which I have quoted. The article states that when Mr Wahlquist and his wife first began planting vines:
. . . idealism had to come to terms with problems created by his early attempts to wean his land off insecticides.
He refused to spray his vines with DDT . . .

Of course, all farmers do that now, but this was back in 1971. The article points out that the caterpillars came because there were no predators as a result of the DDT killing birds. Mr Wahlquist then grew controlled weeds underneath the vines to harbour insects on which the birds could feed. He found that the birds came but they attacked the grapes because they were so nice and juicy. He then provided water tubs from which the birds could drink. He has now developed a balance and is successful, as the article shows. I think the following statement by Mr Wahlquist is the most important quote from the article:
If you are going to plant something, you have to evaluate the total environment because you are really invading it.

That certainly is a fundamental approach. He said that he and his wife were considered ratbags in the district and there are some people in this Parliament who would have been the first to call them ratbags, but he also said that they encouraged other local farmers to stop using herbicide sprays. Of course, one has to do this if one wants to get into this sort of production because, as many Australians have learned to their sorrow, fences and boundaries do not stop chemicals. It is also interesting to note his comment:
The old farmers who have been brought up in the days before pesticides supported us . . .

I am reminded of my early childhood on a farm where really the only chemical that was used was superphosphate as a fertiliser. In my later years my father got interested in the new-fangled things that young farmers around him were using. He died at the age of 57 from a very strange disease, as did our neighbour, who was 20 years younger.

As I have said, a British wine wholesaler heard about the wines and Mr Wahlquist became a very successful exporter. I suggest that lots of other people could follow that example. Mr Wahlquist's organic growing methods have been officially recognised by the National Association for Sustainable Agriculture in Australia, about which I spoke earlier. Those are just two examples. My files are full of other examples of people in Australia who are using these growing methods. However, the problem in Australia, as I have said, is that there is very little information on alternative methods of agriculture disseminated by governments and their extension offices to farmers. That is really a very unjust situation. We all pay for government extension, we all pay for government research funds through our taxes, and sustainable agricultural practitioners no less than anyone else.

The current review of agricultural chemicals legislation in Victoria in recommending that `research efforts into alternative non-chemical methods of pest control are required' falls short of taking the crucial step of actually conveying this kind of information to those who need it, that is, the farmers. NASAA has suggested to the review that it adopt the following:
Results from research into alternative non-chemical methods of pest control will be communicated to farmers . . .

Governments must make a commitment to that communication. Governments must face the challenges ahead and take action now to support people like this by implementing policies which are ecologically alert and taking the lead.

In Question Time today Senator Cook made the strong claim that this is the most environmentally conscious Australian government in history, or words to that effect, and he congratulated his fellow Minister, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), and generally gave the Government quite a good pat on the back for its record in this area. I suggest that there is a long way to go. However, I also give credit where credit is due. I believe that governments at all levels in Australia, like people all over Australia, are beginning to realise that we will not have too much of a future unless we take care of our resource base and recognise, as does Mr Wahlquist, that if one is going to plant something one must evaluate the total environment because one is invading it. We are beginning to realise that in some of the more dramatic areas such as the ozone layer and the greenhouse effect, but we in Australia must never forget our very vulnerable soil resource base.
I reiterate that the Democrats concur with the view put forward in that report from the World Commission on Environment and Development, the book called Our Common Future, that:
The ability to choose policy paths that are sustainable-
in other words the ability to anticipate and prevent environmental damage-

requires that the ecological dimensions of policy be considered at the same time as the economic, trade, energy, agricultural, industrial, and other dimensions-on the same agendas and in the same national and international institutions.

So these projects should receive funding in the same way as conventional agricultural projects should receive funding, support and information. For Australia's agriculture to be sustainable in the long term we need to set in train these kinds of policy principles right now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address in particular the amendment foreshadowed by Senator Chaney in this place this afternoon, the text of which has already been circulated for the advance information of honourable senators. In particular, I refer to those sections of the amendment which deal with the failure of the Government's economic policies and the fact that this failure has produced stagnant productivity, high inflation, a continuing balance of payments crisis and rising interest rates which are hurting business and home buyers alike. I will say something about each of those aspects in turn.

SPEECH.PARA: We have, I think, no great need to make a case for the evident fact that the Government's economic policies have failed. That is true whether one considers its macro-economic policies or its micro-economic policies. As to the Government's macro-economic policies, let us consider a few aspects and see how each of them measures up in terms of the test of success or failure. Let us take, first, that which we are debating today in any case, that is, the Budget. I suppose the Government could most convincingly or at least most plausibly claim to have been successful because the Government has, as Senator Maguire pointed out earlier, produced a Budget in surplus this financial year. I will not detract from that particular achievement as far as it goes because it is highly desirable that our Budget has been brought back into balance and indeed into surplus. The only thing that is wrong with that outcome is the process by which it has been achieved-the process whereby we have seen a major series of both new taxes and tax increases and where the Budget this financial year contains estimates of taxation revenues which again, I think for the third year running, are estimated to run at a record level of gross domestic product. That is on the basis of the estimates in the Budget Papers.

I think all the preliminary evidence to date-and admittedly only three months of data is to hand-suggests that the revenue side of the Budget in particular will run in excess of the Estimates. Work produced by the Macquarie Bank, as reported in today's press, seems to confirm that view. If so, we are likely to find that this year that record ratio of taxation to domestic product will be even more a record than estimated in the Budget Papers. To quote just one figure from the Budget Papers, however, we see that the revenue to be derived from pay as you earn taxation is estimated by the Government itself to increase this year alone by 13.8 per cent, and I hazard the expectation that that already huge rate of growth of taxation garnered from ordinary wage and salary earners, will come out to be appreciably higher than 13.8 per cent.

Let us look at the next test of macro-economic competence on the part of our present Administration. Where have interest rates moved under this Government? You will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that when the Budget was brought down the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said in his speech that he expected the Budget surplus of $5.5 billion-it is probably more than that now-to produce `downward pressure on interest rates'. Those were the Treasurer's words. I think it was two days later when we received the first horrific balance of payments result for July, which had been delayed, ironically enough, by industrial disputes. We received a market shock and interest rates began rising two days after the Budget and, quite frankly, I think it is literally true to say that they have not stopped rising since. Of course, there was a new quantum jump about two weeks ago when the Treasurer, in response to a dorothy dix question in the House of Representatives, finally owned up that he and the Government had actually been seeking to tighten monetary policy and to raise interest rates for some time past-a fact which, if I may say, the Treasurer had been studiously denying in the preceding weeks. If time permits, I may have more to say about that failure of the Government in relation to interest rates. At the moment I merely point out that we have seen a failure of this Budget to produce in the Treasurer's words `downward pressure on interest rates'.

That brings us to the next indicator of success or failure in macro-economic policy terms, that is, the exchange rate. Of course, as a direct consequence of what has been happening to interest rates in the past nearly three months we have seen the exchange rate for the Australian dollar climbing, particularly against the United States dollar but more generally against foreign currencies. While I do not want to suggest that I see virtue in a particular exchange rate for the Australian dollar against a particular currency because that would be totally inconsistent with a flexible and deregulated financial system, I nevertheless think that when one sees our Australian dollar moving over a relatively short time-just a few weeks basically-from a rate of about 78c to the US dollar to a rate which, as of this morning, was about 86c to the US dollar, one has to ask: What possible justification can there be for a development of that kind in respect of the competitive situation of our exporters and, for that matter, our import competing producers who will be competing against, in Australian dollar terms, cheaper foreign products? One has to ask: Are our money wage costs rising less fast than those in the United States for example? Is our productivity performance superior to that of the United States? If either of those things were true, and of course if both of them were true, it would provide some justification for the fact that our dollar is strengthening against the United States dollar. But I am not aware that that is the case. I want to say a little more about productivity performance later to indicate that quite the reverse is the case.

If neither of those things is so, why is our dollar rising against the United States dollar? We all know the answer to that. It is because this Government has the mix of its economic policies wrong. It is now relying upon a credit squeeze, via higher interest rates forced upon the market by Reserve Bank of Australia action in the money markets, to do the work that the Government's Budget, brought down three months ago, has failed to do. On that test certainly the macro-economic policies of the Government have failed miserably.

But perhaps the most obvious area where that failure is apparent is in the balance of payments. The Treasurer, in what is now perhaps the most rapidly discredited forecast made by any Treasurer in this country's history, forecast on Budget night that we would have a $9.5 billion current account deficit on the balance of payments this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —He must have meant six months.

—As Senator Parer indicates, he must have meant six months. We have had a deficit of $5.4 billion in the first four months. While it is of course true-as has been remarked ad nauseam by Government senators and Government Ministers-that there is an element of seasonality in the balance of payments this year, even the Treasurer has now been forced to abandon that $9.5 billion forecast for the year as a whole. At this stage it is not clear what the Treasurer's new forecast is. There were some leaks in the press a few weeks ago that suggested that the Treasurer had now moved to a forecast of $10.5 billion for the year as a whole. But the Treasurer has conspicuously failed to confirm those revised, or indeed any other, forecasts. I point out in passing that to achieve a deficit even of $10.5 billion would require a deficit of not more than $638m a month for the last eight months of the year. To use understated language-unlike, if I might say so, some of the rather overblown rhetoric on the other side of the chamber-I do not think that that is likely.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh, during Question Time today in response to a question I asked him, said that he was sure that the balance of payments deficit this year would be less than 4 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). If one thinks about it, Senator Walsh was saying that, using an estimate of GDP as laid down at the time of the Budget, the balance of payments deficit would be less than $12.8 billion-not $9.5 billion, not $10.5 billion, but less than $12.8 billion. Just for the record it is worth mentioning that this year GDP, in nominal terms, will be almost certainly higher than was forecast at the time of the Budget; so a deficit of 4 per cent of GDP would be even greater than $12.8 billion. That is now the mark against which the Government is measuring its performance. If it comes in under 4 per cent-under 13 point something or other billion dollars-the Government will tell us that it has been successful.

As a matter of interest, if the Government is to do better this year than its abysmal performance last year of an $11.8 billion deficit on the current account of the balance of payments, the deficit will have to average less than $803m a month for the next eight months. The truth is that the balance of payments performance of this Government is not just a failure; it is a disaster. The high exchange rate which the Government's credit squeeze is now inducing will make that disaster worse. By definition it will render our import competing industries as well as our export industries less competitive. Of course, because of this disastrous balance of payments outcome, our foreign debt keeps on climbing.

We had some interesting statistics from Senator Maguire earlier this afternoon who told us how the Government is getting on top of the foreign debt position. He told us that on the basis of the figures for the end of June which, to be fair to Senator Maguire, are the latest figures we have. But he failed to mention that the improvement in the foreign debt figures he referred to is principally due to the revaluation effect on the stock of foreign debt brought about by the fact that during the June quarter in particular our exchange rate rose significantly. I will not be surprised if we see the same thing when we get the September quarter figures. The Government will no doubt again claim success in bringing our foreign debt position under control. All I can say is that if it keeps on bringing our foreign debt position under control by pushing up our exchange rate, shortly we will not have any exporters left in this country. I hope that we do not hear any more of that spurious stuff about how the Government is succeeding from Senator Maguire or anyone else on the other side of the chamber. Senator McKiernan at least is assuring me that he will not indulge in that kind of spurious rhetoric. I accept his assurance.

Let us now turn to the Government's prowess in its micro-economic policies in which there is a whole galaxy of failures, the most important one of which is its total failure even to tackle the micro-economic problem of the labour market by way of deregulation of the labour market. Senator Chaney, who has just come into the chamber, said something about that during the course of his earlier remarks. In that respect I join with him in his comments. We have also seen the Government's almost equally total failure in the area of deregulation of the market for traded goods. We have had extraordinarily limited progress in that area from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is much better at talking than acting-like most Ministers of this Government. The levelling of the playing field-to pick one of the Treasurer's favourite phrases when he talks about taxation policy-is notably absent from the area of deregulation of the market for traded goods, and notably absent from the area of putting our exporters on the same level playing field as our import competing industries. The result of both these failures, particularly the failure to tackle the problem of trade union power in its effect upon the operations of our labour market, has been to produce an abysmal productivity performance.

Quite by chance, last Thursday the Australian Bureau of Statistics put out a new publication which is highly relevant to that issue. It carries the very dull title of Australian National Accounts-Gross Product, Employment and Hours Worked. What the Statistician has done is to produce two series of figures for what, in technical jargon, he calls real gross domestic product per person employed and per hour worked. These figures are based on two separate bases for calculating gross domestic product.

Without going into all the technicalities of it all, what do we find? Honourable senators will remember that over the first two years of the life of the present Government-that is, in 1983-84 and in 1984-85-the economy was recovering and coming up from the trough which had been created. To correct a point made earlier by one or two Government senators, that was created not by the previous Government but by the policies of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the 23 per cent increase in hourly wage rates forced upon the economy by the ACTU and a centralised wage determination system-a subject which, above all, the Government will not tackle-which created some 130,000 additional unemployed in the course of 12 months. Coming up from that trough, created by the Government's own supporters, the economy, under this Government in its first two years of office, registered an increase in gross domestic product per hour worked, on the more favourable of the two bases of estimation; in other words, choosing the best possible figures to make the Government's case. On that basis, we found over those two years a rise in gross domestic product per hour worked of 4.6 per cent-2.3 per cent per annum. One might say that in the past that has been about average for the Australian economy-and so it has been-but we are talking not about an average period but about a period of cyclical upswing and recovery, when one expects to get the best productivity performance.

Let us consider the past three years, that is, 1985-86, 1986-87 and 1987-88. We find that, on exactly the same basis, over those three years there has been a rise in gross domestic product per hour worked of 1.2 per cent-less than half of one per cent per annum. That is what the Commonwealth Statistician tells us about the productivity performance of this economy during the last three years under the Hawke Labor Government. According to the Treasurer, it was in those three years that the economy turned the corner. It has turned the corner so many times that we have become positively giddy in the process!

That is the record of this Government; the record of its failure. That is why our economy is uncompetitive. It is why our balance of payments deficit is blowing out yet again, despite all the rhetoric about the J-curve and all that stuff that the Treasurer went on with for at least 18 months before he started to get ambitions to become Prime Minister. Why do we have that failure? Principally it is because the Government has refused to face up to the trade unions.

We have heard a lot from the Government about the accord between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I want to say here and now that that accord is a fraud. The whole record of boastful rhetoric from this Government on that subject is totally fraudulent. While I do not have time now to argue that case extensively, the truth of the proposition is evident from the bottom line, from the result. We have the result, which is that in the last three years, when the Government has been assisted by its mates in the trade union movement, we have had a rise in pro- ductivity of less than one half of one per cent per annum. That is the result of allowing industrial relations in this country to be controlled by the principal interest group involved, namely, the trade union leaders, the ACTU.

If anyone were to suggest that this Government or any other government should allow our industrial structure to be controlled by a few great capitalist monopolists, there would be outrage. Yet we have the process of monopolistic control of the labour markets by a small group of trade union heavies, and that is regarded as being an eminently desirable outcome by this Government, which enshrines it in the fancy language of the accord. Of course, exactly the same story applies in the case of industrial protection where, as I said earlier, we have had progress at a snail's pace. I suppose that is not surprising in view of the history of the past 80-odd years in this country, with the lack of deregulation of the traded goods market, marching hand in hand with the lack of deregulation of the labour market-one supporting the other.

Finally, let us look at the prospects which confront the economy under the failed policies of the Hawke-Keating Labor Government-or perhaps I should reverse that and say the Keating-Hawke Labor Government. We are told that there is a prospect of major real tax cuts-not just giving back to people the $2 billion or so which bracket creep alone will take away from them in 1989-90 by way of increased taxes, but real tax cuts over and above that amount as from 1 July next year. In fact, by that time we will have had another balance of payments deficit of about the same as last year. Perhaps it will be a shade less, or perhaps, if Senator Walsh's worst fears are realised, it will be a shade more. As a result we will have incurred more foreign debt and have made more sales of Australian assets to foreigners, in both cases to pay for the fact that we continue to refuse to live within our means internationally.

We will have had another year of high inflation. That is another area of failure which I have simply not had time to refer to. Let me simply say that the Treasurer's forecast of a 4.5 per cent consumer price index increase by the end of the June quarter of this financial year is now considered by the Treasurer himself to be the pie in the sky that it always was. We will have had another year of rotten productivity. Even the Budget Papers themselves forecast a productivity increase of only three-quarters of one per cent this year, although one would have to say that that would be a significant increase on the performance of the last three years. At the end of all that time-I might add, at a time when we will have had sustained high interest rates and a high exchange rate-we will have a major real tax cut. This will come just at a time, perhaps-although nobody can foresee these things with precision-when the world economy either is about to slow down or has already begun to slow down and the prospects for our export prices are beginning to fade.

The truth is that the Government is out of touch not only with the lives, hopes and aspirations of ordinary Australians-as Senator Chaney has indicated in foreshadowing his amendment-but also with economic reality. The Government's policies have been a failure. The only question is: Will it acknowledge that failure and, if so, how soon? To put that point another way, when is Mr Keating going to stop trying to supplant Mr Hawke as the Prime Minister of this country and get back to being the Treasurer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate this afternoon is discussing a package of Appropriation Bills-the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2)-which were introduced into the Parliament recently and which essentially are the machinery provisions of the Budget which was delivered in August of this year. Before I begin my comments on these Appropriation Bills I want again to recognise a comment made by the previous speaker, Senator Stone, when he said that I do not engage in spurious rhetoric. I note that that comment was supported by Senator Puplick, but I realise that such support from diverging wings of the Opposition parties will still do me no good in the preselection battles that I may or may not have within my Party in the coming year. I am not inviting any comment from Senator Richardson because I am not sure that would help me.
—I support you in your preselection.

—I recognise that interjection. In the debate tonight I will deal with some spurious rhetoric, and the spurious rhetoric I refer to is comments made by Senator Haines in her response to the Budget delivered in this chamber on 29 August. The general theme of Senator Haines's comments on that night was that it was not a Budget for families but was a Budget for beer drinkers. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget does nothing for families, for ordinary Australians . . . There is nothing in this Budget to give joy to low income families . . . There is nothing in this Budget to assist ordinary Australian taxpayers.

I do not know what motivated Senator Haines to make the comments she did on that night. We expect a lot better from Senator Haines, not only as the leader of an important political party in this chamber but also as senator. I find her comments completely and utterly irresponsible. Contrary to what was said on that night, I believe that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) should be commended for having achieved much more support than many of us would have thought possible for low income families, for ordinary Australians, in the Budget delivered in August. Far from criticising the Minister or the Budget in total, we should be commending him. I believe we should applaud his achievements in realising equity and fairness for all Australians and not just for the fortunate majority. If Senator Haines cannot find it in her heart to commend the Budget on the ground of its realising Labor's social justice goals, it is at least heartening that it received accolades from the likes of Julian Disney from the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) whose press release of 23 August said in part:
A number of the measures (announced) are useful steps in highly desirable directions.
It further stated:
(ACOSS) greatly welcomes the Government's specific commitments to increase expenditure in (new employment and training programs) and other areas in future years.
It continued:

. . . the Government's commitment to further improvement of the new child support scheme, expansion of the new enterprise incentive scheme, improved funding for AIDS programs and expanded funding for preventative health.

Even if Senator Haines is unable to recognise the achievements of this year's Budget in achieving social justice objectives, it is interesting and welcoming to note that the likes of Mr Disney, who is not backward in saying his piece when he wants to criticise government initiatives, are prepared to commend the Government for its achievements in these important social policy areas. In my view it is proof of just how much this Budget attempts to achieve for Australian families, especially the disadvantaged families, those families in which the principal is either single and/or is a member of the ranks of the long term unemployed. The 1988-89 Budget will be remembered for the emphasis placed on assisting low income families, pensioners and other beneficiaries. This assistance reflects the Government's commitment to social justice issues and can be seen in many areas, including in the new start scheme; the new jobs, education and training, or JET, scheme; increases in the family allowance supplement; 40,000 additional higher education places by 1990, which is only just around the corner; a real increase of over 20 per cent for programs for Aboriginal advancement; a package of housing assistance measures to increase assistance to low income families; and the introduction of stage 2 of the child support scheme for July 1989. I go on: an increase of 30,000 in child care places over the next four years; the extension of the provision of non-institutional care for the frail aged and younger people with disabilities under the home and community care program by $40m; and the new extreme disablement adjustment to the general rate of the veteran pension. This means an extra $42.15 a week for those who are eligible. Likewise, the reduction of the disability requirement from 100 to 79 per cent for the totally and permanently incapacitated pension is an initiative that has been welcomed by many.

The sum total of these programs is a strengthening of the Government's commitment to its social justice program, reflected most clearly for me in the taking of positive steps to enable social security recipients to emerge from the poverty cycle which many of them have been submerged in for far too long.

For the benefit of Senator Haines and other honourable senators I now intend to look more closely at some of the programs I have alluded to and at what the Government has done in specific program areas for low income Australian families. Funding for the family allowance supplement (FAS) will cost $69m this financial year. From December, maximum payments under FAS will be increased by approximately 10 per cent, by $2 a week to $24 for childen aged 12 years or under, and by $3 a week to $31 for children aged 13 to 15. These increases in FAS are in line with the Government's commitment to increase total child care payments until they reach 15 per cent of the combined married pensioners rate for younger children and 20 per cent of that rate for older children.

The implementation of stage 2 of the child support scheme was announced in the Budget, and will begin in July 1989. This will ensure that adequate financial resources are available for children whose parents' relationship has ended. Under the scheme a formula will be used to determine child maintenance amounts, in most cases replacing court based assessment of maintenance. The formula will be based on the income of the non-custodial parent, taking account of the needs of any other children who live with the parent, and the income of the custodial parent if it is higher than average weekly earnings, plus an allowance for work related child care.

I am confident that the introduction of stage 2 of the scheme will make it easier for parents to resolve maintenance issues by removing the need to go to court to have an amount decided. It also means that we are moving closer to our goal of making all parents financially responsible for their children. As we heard earlier this year when stage 1 of the child support scheme was introduced, where parents have separated only 30 per cent of non-custodial parents choose to obey maintenance orders, which in most cases are totally inadequate anyway.

We should all be aware by now that the Government introduced two new employment programs in the Budget, JET and new start. The JET scheme recognises that many sole parents have few or inappropriate job skills and that they often feel that they face insurmountable barriers to work force re-entry. This program is therefore designed to help sole parent pensioners become economically independent by helping them gain the necessary skills to enter the work force, thereby lifting both themselves and their children out of the poverty cycle. The program is therefore a vital link in the Government's effort to eliminate child poverty by 1990, for a large percentage of the children living in sole parent families also live in poverty. For example, in 1981-82 the incidence of poverty for children in sole parent families was higher than for any other social group. Forty-six per cent of all sole parent families were living below the poverty line. If there were three children in the sole parent family, there was a 70 per cent chance that they were living below the poverty line. If there were four or more children in the family, the odds of their living below the poverty line increased to a massive 91 per cent.

This Government has improved the situation for the vast majority of such families-indeed, all beneficiary families-in the 5 1/2 years it has been in office. I will use the Henderson poverty line and June 1988 prices as a benchmark to demonstrate this. I qualify what I say by accepting that there is some dispute about the validity of the Henderson poverty line. Nevertheless, I will use it as the basis of my argument this evening. In March 1983 a single beneficiary with no children was $23.40 below the poverty line. In June 1988 that single beneficiary would have been $1.30 above the poverty line. In March 1983 a sole parent beneficiary with one child was $23.60 below the accepted poverty line. In June of this year such a beneficiary was $11.20 above it. In March 1983 a single parent beneficiary with two children was $37.10 below the poverty line. In June 1988 that beneficiary was 50c above it.
