In March 1983 a beneficiary couple with one child was $4.10 above the poverty line. However, in June 1988 the couple was $30.95 above. A beneficiary couple with two children in March 1983 was $10.60 below the poverty line. In June 1988 such a couple was $20.15 above. In March 1983 a beneficiary couple with three children was $26.30 below the poverty line. In June 1988 that couple was $10.95 above. Pensioners with children aged between 13 years and 15 years will have fared even better since December last year because of the recognition by this Government of the increased costs borne by families with older children.

Whilst this Government has made major inroads into reducing the appalling statistics, it cannot be denied that sole parent families have become the new poor in our society. The jobs, education and training program is an attempt to alleviate the situation. It recognises the enormous barriers to labour market participation faced by many sole parents. More specifically, JET is to begin in March 1989 at a cost of $40m. It will offer the following services to sole parents: needs assessment, counselling, advice and assistance; improved income security through Austudy and the formal training allowance to be paid through the Department of Employment, Education and Training-the study allowance to sole parent beneficiaries to be doubled, to $30 a week; access to education and labour market programs; and child-care tailored to their education, training and employment choices, in recognition of the fact that lack of available child-care is one of the most severe barriers to work force re-entry faced by sole parents. It is estimated that about 12,000 child-care places will be provided under the program.

JET is aimed at three specific groups of sole parents: firstly, those who have been on a pension for more than one year and whose youngest child is at school; secondly, those whose youngest child is 14 years or over-eligibility for the sole parent pension ends when the youngest child turns 16 and such parents will be needing to join the work force in two years or less; and, thirdly, teenage sole parents. I make the comment that, contrary to the myth that has abounded in recent times, in 1986 only 2.4 per cent of female sole parents were teenagers. This number is declining. In the late 1970s this group made up 4.2 per cent of the sole parent population. I refer now to the New Start program, which will cost $114m over the next 3 1/2 years. Like the JET program, New Start is designed to help those people with chronic labour market disabilities.

I turn to housing. Housing costs, particularly those in the private rental market, have long been recognised as a major cause of poverty. In this Budget the Government has taken further important steps, as an integral part of its commitment to eradicate child poverty, to increase assistance to low income families renting privately. We have injected $47m for rental assistance to low income families. From June 1989 maximum rental assistance to families who are pensioners, beneficiaries or on low incomes with one or more children will be increased by 33 per cent, or $5 per week, rising to a maximum of $30 per week by June 1990. These measures represent an increase of 150 per cent to 200 per cent in rent assistance for low income and pensioner beneficiary families since the election of the Labor Government in 1983. This will have a major effect on reducing housing related poverty.

I have mentioned Aboriginal affairs previously. In the context of the Budget debate and the Estimates committee hearings Aboriginal affairs have drawn the attention of the media. I will not canvass the specific matters that attracted that media attention, but I would make the point that in this year's Budget Government funding for Aboriginal programs has been increased by 23.6 per cent to $476m for a range of new measures in the areas of health, housing, education and employment. I welcome the attention that Aboriginal development programs are receiving from the media, but I do not welcome the particular attention they received on the most recent occasion. It would have been better if the media had focused on the fact that Aboriginal people in this nation receive only two-thirds of the national median income. Only 26 per cent of Aboriginal people own their own homes, compared with 70 per cent of all other Australians. An estimated 30 per cent of Aboriginals are unemployed, compared with the national average of 8 per cent. Only 2.5 per cent of employed Aboriginals own their own businesses, compared with 15 per cent of other Australians.

According to a 1987 housing needs survey, there is an urgent need for 16,498 dwellings to accommodate Aboriginals living in substandard and overcrowded dwellings. The percentage of Aboriginal families living in substandard housing is four times the national average. It is a pity the press does not concentrate a little more on statistics such as those rather than on the inflammatory material that it dwelt on in the last month or so. In mentioning Aboriginals, I extend my congratulations to Minister Hand on his achievements in attaining the funding he has obtained in this year's Budget. In passing, I also comment that a lot of accusations have been made about the use of money in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. Those accusations are being investigated. We on this side of the chamber will be looking very closely at the assertions and allegations that have been made.

I have mentioned that the Government is making provision for an extra 30,000 child-care places targeted to people with the greatest needs. The extra places will be made up of 20,000 out of school hours child-care places, 4,000 centre based, 4,000 family day care and 2,000 occasional care. The number of Government child-care places has been boosted in this Government's term in office from 46,000 to 110,000-which reinforces my opening comments tonight.

We have also increased funding for country counselling and access services, particularly for families in rural areas-targeted specifically, again, at rural women who quite often are overlooked in such programs. Additional funding has also been granted to marriage counselling organisations. It has increased by 11 per cent. Marriage education funding has increased by 76 per cent. Higher education places will be the subject of further discussion later in this session of parliament. I mention in passing that we will increase the number of places available in our tertiary institutions by 40,000 over the next three years. We will deal with that in more detail later in the debate.

In the fairly brief time I have had tonight I have sought to highlight some of the important aspects of the accountability of the Government's social justice strategy. I have sought to provide proof that economic responsibility and social responsibility are not contradictory goals. With great pleasure I support the Bills before the chamber. I do so because of what the Budget contains for families. Senator Haines could not be more mistaken than to say that it ignores the family. The Budget goes to the very heart of social justice. It is a Budget genuinely concerned with fairness and support for the disadvantaged in our community. While the Government has pursued sound economic policy and structural adjustment, it has not done so without continual recognition of the need to pursue simultaneously a social justice strategy. This Government does not believe, as the previous Fraser Government did, that social justice is something that should be suspended while we get the economy right. Once again, I ask that we all adopt an holistic approach to social issues and realise once and for all that aid directed to the less fortunate members of our community is to the ultimate benefit of us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support very strongly the amendment to the motion that Appropriation Bill (No. 1) be now read a second time foreshadowed by my colleague and Leader, Senator Chaney. For those who may not have heard what the amendment contains, let me summarise it briefly. It draws attention to this country's stagnant productivity, high inflation, continuing balance of payments, or deficit, crisis and rising interest rates which are hurting business and home buyers alike. It also draws attention to the squalor of this Government's management of certain departments, particularly the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Appropriation Bills authorise the Government's expenditures for the current financial year. Yesterday in the Senate the Government put down, two months early, a report on the Forward Estimates for the next three years. I will come back to that a little later. Firstly, let us acknowledge that the expenditures set down in the Bills are the core of the Government's economic policies. Its expenditure determines the size of the tax burden on the Australian people, the moneys it needs to borrow to carry on its affairs, as well as the broad impact on the economic welfare of the Australian people. This is the Government in action, determining its own economic, fiscal and political priorities. It is this matter that I want to emphasise today.

Do honourable senators remember that when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) brought down the Budget a little over two months ago he proclaimed, `This is the one that brings home the bacon'? The clear inference from that was that the tax cuts mooted therein were to be the centrepiece of the Government's strategy leading up to the 1989 election. Of course, the tax cuts were not to start until next year and would be there only if Australians sat up straight and took their medicine properly this year. The kind of medicine we had to take this year involved paying more taxes to the tune of about $5,700m over and above what might have been expected. That works out at a little over $1,000 a year, or $20 a week, per family in Australia. The next point was not spelt out but it involved higher interest rates-on our mortgages, farm loans, business loans and even our consumer purchases when we bought things on Bankcard or any other kind of credit facility. Those are the costs to the Australian people of not getting tax cuts now but, rather, having to wait until it suits the Hawke-Keating Government's electoral priorities next year.

What this all means is that the average Australian family has lost, in real spending power, $56 per week since this Government came to power. The average family is $56 per week down the drain. The point about this is that it takes place under the Hawke-Keating Government's political strategy. It is not a strategy to help the Australian people; it is not a strategy to restore living standards for the Australian people: it is a strategy to get the Hawke-Keating Government re-elected at the end of 1989. We have to pay now so that Mr Keating can hand back to us in the election year the money that he has stealthily syphoned off through bracket creep in this financial year. That was the strategy. It was closely aligned to the Treasurer's personal political agenda-to knock off Bob Hawke.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Come on! Senator Richardson knows very well that he was out to knock off Bob Hawke in the last few weeks. Senator Richardson must have talked him out of it. I notice that his mate, John MacBean, let him down halfway through. The fact is that Keating was not able to knock off Bob Hawke. He was not able to grab the crown in this financial year and now he has to try to make hard weather of it in the next financial year.
—He'll do it next year.

—I guess he will. The whole idea was this: having grabbed the crown from the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, he would survive for a few months as Prime Minister of this country, take it to an election in 1989 and then hand back to us the very taxes that he had ripped off us during the immediately preceding year. A row has already started in the Australian Labor Party (ALP) as its members choose sides between Keating and Hawke. Quite obviously, it is a very divisive issue. That was the game plan. The ALP was to set itself up and be ready, to get its chariot polished, all the shields ready and all the spears sharpened so that it could get the cart out, move out of the arena and into the financial year with Keating as Prime Minister and the tax cuts yet to come.

SPEECH.PARA: Suddenly, the wheels fell off the cart, because in September we started to get some bad economic statistics-not that they surprised anybody. Anybody who was at least informed about this country's financial situation realised that there were a lot of question marks hanging over the Budget that was brought down in August. Quite clearly, the Government has overestimated its capacity to keep inflation down. As we have already seen, it reached over 2 per cent in the last quarter, compared with a Government estimate that would have had to be of the order of one per cent to reach the target as set down in the Budget.

Also, we saw the collapse of the balance of payments in each of the first three months of this financial year. In September there was a $1.7 billion blow-out in the balance of payments. I believe that that is quite an understatement of the real position facing this country. The last three months demonstrate clearly that a hugh problem faces this country in terms of our exports, how we handle our imports and what will happen in the months ahead as we must continue to keep the debt that we owe the rest of the world on the downward path rather than the upward path. Every month we add about $1 billion or $1 1/2 billion to the debt that we owe the rest of the world. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the joint defence facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar, to move that the Senate take note of the statement and to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I wish to inform the Senate that the Australian and US Governments have agreed to a number of important changes to the arrangements under which we cooperate in running our joint defence facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar.

The changes we are making reflect the commitment of both Governments to maintaining and strengthening our long-standing partnership in these joint facilities. They ensure that the facilities continue to operate in ways that best serve the interests of ourselves and our partners.

These changes also reflect the commitment of this Government to informing the public as fully as possible about the facilities. On 6 June 1984 in the House of Representatives the Prime Minister made the first detailed public statement about the roles of the facilities. In making that statement he was convinced that better public understanding of the roles of the joint facilities could only increase public support for them. These remarks today, which will in some respects go beyond that earlier statement, are made with the same conviction.

Since the joint facilities were established in the 1960s, the alliance between Australia and the US has evolved and matured, the technologies involved at Pine Gap and Nurrungar have developed, and Australians have learned more of the skills involved in running the facilities.
The new arrangements at Pine Gap and Nurrungar accommodate these important changes.

At Pine Gap, the number of Australians engaged in the central operational activity is being steadily increased. Some of these personnel, who are drawn from scientific and intelligence areas of the Department of Defence, are taking over functions previously carried out by US employees.

Whereas only a handful of Australian Government personnel was directly involved in the central work of the facility in the 1970s and early 1980s-contributing less than 10 per cent of the staff there-the proportion is scheduled to rise to about 30% over the next two or three years.

But Australians are not only doing more of the operational work at the facilities. Under the new arrangements we have agreed, Australians will carry out more of the senior management functions at both Pine Gap and Nurrungar.

At Pine Gap, a senior Australian Defence official will be appointed to a newly created position as Deputy Chief of the Facility. He will advise and support the US Chief of Facility in managing the facility and its activities, and he will share responsibility with him for that work. He will also continue to be the officer in charge of the prohibited area, with ultimate responsibility for the physical security of the facility. Other senior management positions will also be filled by Australians.

Parallel changes have been agreed to the staffing at Nurrungar. Australians constitute some 40 per cent of the staff in the key operational areas, and will now take a role in management with the appointment of the senior Australian officer there as Deputy Commander. Like his counterpart at Pine Gap, he will share responsibility with the Commander for the management of the station and its physical security.

The integration of Australian personnel in both the operation and the management of the joint facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar is such that the Australian Government can be assured of having full knowledge of all aspects of the operations at the facilities, and reinforces our confidence that our interests and sovereignty are respected at all times.
At the same time, Australia will be able to take more direct advantage of the facilities' capabilities for our own purposes than has been practicable in the past.

Hitherto, by agreement between ourselves and our partners, we have spoken in public of the capabilities of the two facilities only in conjunction. Under the new arrangements and in pursuit of better understanding and stronger support for the facilities we have now agreed to specify the separate roles of Pine Gap and Nurrungar.

Nurrungar is a ground station used for controlling satellites in the United States Defence Support Program (DSP). The DSP satellites provide ballistic missile early warning and other information related to missile launches, surveillance and the detonation of nuclear weapons.

Few if any elements of the strategic systems of either superpower make such a decisive and unambiguous contribution to keeping the peace as the Defence Support Program. As an essential link in the DSP, Nurrungar plays a quite fundamental role in preventing nuclear war.
The DSP, through Nurrungar, would give the earliest warning of an ICBM attack on the United States or its allies.

Because the DSP gives longer warning of an attack than other systems, it reduces the chances that United States forces could be destroyed in a surprise attack, and that makes it extremely unlikely that anyone would ever try such an attack.
Together with other elements of the United States early warning system, the DSP provides highly reliable warning of attack. It thus plays a vital role in helping to prevent nuclear war by accident.
Australians can be glad that we help to operate this vital facility, and that every day, around the clock, Australian personnel are playing this part in helping to prevent nuclear war.
I turn to Pine Gap. Pine Gap is a satellite ground station, whose function is to collect intelligence data which supports the national security of both Australia and the United States.

Intelligence collected at Pine Gap contributes importantly to the verification of arms control and disarmament agreements. The value of that data has become more and more evident over the last year or two, as disarmament has moved from being an aspiration to become an emerging reality.

Today, for the first time since the invention of the atom bomb, nuclear weapons systems are, under the INF Treaty, being destroyed by their owners. The next step is already underway. In the START talks the superpowers are seriously negotiating to make major cuts in their strategic arsenals.

Verification is vital to this arms control process. Verification was the key issue in reaching that INF agreement last year, and verification will be the key to any START agreement in the future. If the START process were to fail, despite the efforts of both sides, it would be largely because of the difficulties with verification.

In April this year, nuclear risk reduction centres were created in Washington and Moscow. This new confidence building channel is being used to notify the two sides of missile launches required by arms control accords and will also serve to reduce the possibility of nuclear conflict.
Without Australia's involvement in arms control verification, the risk of nuclear war would have been directly and significantly increased.

I think it is important for those who have urged us over the years to close Pine Gap and Nurrungar to reflect on the undoubted fact that, had we done as they urged, the INF Treaty could not have been signed and the START process would not have got underway.

With the information now on the public record about the roles played by these facilities in preventing nuclear war, I think it is clear that nobody seriously committed to peace could argue for their closure.

There are of course limitations on what it would be sensible for me to reveal publicly about details of the operations that are conducted at either of these joint defence facilities, or details of the organisation and manning arrangements which apply there. It has been the practice of successive Australian Governments not to comment on intelligence matters, and this Government will continue that policy. Details of our capabilities in the sensitive and important area of intelligence collection, or in relation to systems providing attack warning, are not in our national interests to divulge and this Government will not do so.

The Government takes the view that the irreplaceable contribution made by these facilities gives us a special responsibility to ensure that they can continue to function in an atmosphere of stability and commitment.

At present both facilities operate under agreements which are terminable at one year's notice by either side. We do not regard this as satisfactory, both because of the continuing importance of their effective operation to global peace, and because of the specific benefits to Australia of long-term access to their capabilities.

To this end the US and Australia have, as part of the new arrangements for the operation of the facilities, agreed to extend the arrangements under which the two facilities operate for a further ten years in each case. We have further agreed that three years' notice shall be required to terminate the agreement.

Last week the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, and the US Ambassador, Mr Bill Lane, signed exchanges of notes to formalise this agreement. For the information of Honourable Senators I now table those exchanges of notes. Senators will note that this exchange also defines clearly the functions of the two facilities.

These agreements confirm the Government's conviction that the joint defence facilities will continue to serve Australia's national interests; that they will continue to reflect the depth and substance of our bilateral strategic relationship with the United States under ANZUS; and that they will continue to play a vital role in preventing nuclear war.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.
The statement refers to two exchanges of notes which formalise the agreements under which the Pine Gap and Nurrungar facilities operate. I now table those exchanges of notes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the statement presented yesterday in the House of Representatives and presented in the Senate tonight by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in relation to the joint facilities operated by Australia and the United States in Australia. It is very hard to overemphasise the importance of these facilities for the peace and security not only of this nation but of the world. That point is made very strongly in the statement presented by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) yesterday and by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade tonight. I quote just one paragraph of the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important for those who have urged us over the years to close Pine Gap and Nurrungar to reflect on the undoubted fact that, had we done as they urged, the INF treaty could not have been signed and the START process would not have got underway.

In other parts of the statement note is made of the fact that these facilities on Australian soil contribute greatly to the world peace and its maintenance. They do that in one broad way in so far as they provide intelligence as to what is going on in relation to missile launchings for test purposes, for developmental purposes and, of course, in the event of an all-out nuclear attack. They provide for a warning that missiles have been launched. It is always assumed that they would be launched against the United States. That is a reasonable assumption, though it is not always a certainty that the United States would be the target in an attack.

The other great function that these bases have is the function of verification, of being able to keep tabs on what the Soviets are up to and see that they are abiding by various arms control agreements that have been developed over the years and progressively will be developed in the future. The other point that needs to be emphasised about these facilities is that they are absolutely essential for the verification process. They cannot be sited in the United States, South America or Europe. To meet the particular forms of verification that we need for Soviet surveillance, they simply have to be in the current site. Australia for many years now has hosted those facilities. We have done that on a mutual basis, and we have all benefited as a consequence because we have maintained peace for nearly 45 years in a nuclear age-something that, if we were to listen to the more extreme members of some groups in the community, we would think was quite impossible.

I would like to dwell on the process of verification for a moment because verification is at the very heart of any arms control agreement. One side has to know that the other side is conforming precisely to whatever arms reductions or arms limitation agreement is in place. A very great stumbling block with nuclear weapons, given their relatively small size, ease of concealment, mobility and the way they can be deployed in many sites, has been the process of verification. The joint facilities in Australia have played a major role in one element of verification. In the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) treaty we have seen a whole new world open up in on-site inspection. This is something that some of us who have been involved in arms negotiation agreements and have followed them over many years never thought would happen, but now we have Soviet teams actually in American bases looking at the missiles that are deployed there and, even more surprisingly, we have American teams in Soviet facilities looking at the weapons there. One of the features of this on-site inspection is that it can be done at very short notice. The other side does not have time to prepare and hide weapons that it might have deployed. But the whole subject of verification never seems to get a recognition of importance from the Nuclear Disarmament Party and all the other unilateral disarmers who want us to sign agreements willy-nilly without any checks and balances--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats.

—Yes, the Australian Democrats. They say, essentially, `Let us disarm and because we are honest and good looking no-one will attack us'. Unfortunately, the world is not like that. It is interesting, in looking at the statement that has been put down by the Government today on the joint defence facilities, to see that in many ways it extends the concessions or the lease agreements, in so far as they are extended for 10 years to the United States. We welcome that because there has to be stability in these agreements. Alliances are made between nations, not between governments. We cannot have alliances between nations that change from day to day as governments of the day change. Certainly, when we come into government in 12 months time, or whenever the Government calls the next election, we will honour this agreement, as I am sure the Government in the times that it is in government through the next 10 years, will stand by the agreement it has made.

SPEECH.PARA: In one sense it is a great public sign of failure for the nuclear disarmers, the Democrats and the other Soviet funded peace groups that exist in this country that a couple of years back targeted this year as a time of increasing and intense activity so that they could drive the Government into not renewing the agreements with the United States. It is with pleasure that one notes that those Soviet funded peace groups have failed utterly because the Government was not in the least deterred from doing what was essential in the Australian national interest. The strategy of those peace groups is to remove joint defence facilities from Australia. They have failed in that for 10 years. The rest of the strategy is to develop a nuclear free north-west Pacific, or to engineer a situation there to support the Soviet aim of decoupling or neutralising Japan from the Western alliance. I do not think that will succeed for a whole variety of reasons, but part and parcel of that is the current strategy of these Soviet funded groups to talk about the freedom of the seas, denuclearising the seas, or whatever the policy is. It is directed basically at the creation of a nuclear free zone in the north-west Pacific area so that Japan can be isolated.

As I said before, the importance of these bases lies in the fact that they have made a major contribution to peace and security, not for this country alone but for the whole world, because we have operated under a system of nuclear deterrence ever since the nuclear age started. As I have said before in this chamber, I do not believe that it is the best system in the world, but at least it has worked and has kept the world free from a major conflagration for over 40 years. That is not to be lightly dismissed because in this century alone two huge world wars have resulted in the loss of millions of lives. World War I from 1914 to 1918 and World War II from 1939 to 1945 were without parallel in the history of civilization in the death and devastation that they brought to humanity. We have avoided conflicts of that type through the policy of nuclear deterrence. I do not happen to believe that in a hundred years time we will be following a policy of nuclear deterrence. This is why it is so important to see whether the strategic defence initiative can work. I think in the longer haul we will go to a safer system than nuclear deterrence, but at the present time we have that policy.

The Western nations are working towards a goal of reducing the level of nuclear armaments in the world, and in the Gorbachev era we are getting good support from the Soviet Union. While I strongly defend the place of nuclear deterrence at the present time, I am the first to acknowledge that we have far more nuclear weapons than we need to provide that level of nuclear deterrence. The system can operate at a magnitude of weapons several times removed from the present one, and that of course is the goal of this Government, of the Liberal Party and of the Western alliance when we talk about the need for mutual, balanced and verifiable reductions of nuclear weapons. I come back to the importance of the deterrence system. Not only has it kept the peace; it has enabled us to go down the path towards arms reductions. Within the last 12 months we have seen the INF agreement, which is quite historic. A whole class of nuclear weapons has been entirely removed and broken up and I believe the world is that much safer for it.

The Americans are prepared to start immediately on the strategic arms reduction talks and it only requires some cooperation from the Soviets before the START negotiations, which will deal with massive reductions in intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBMs), can take place. I believe that once the talks begin they will go to a successful conclusion, because the will is there in both parties to reduce the number of nuclear weapons that we have. The sticking point with the START agreement for the Americans is the existence of the mobile ICBMs in the Soviet arsenals, as they are very hard to verify. The sticking point for the Soviets is the sea launched cruise missiles, which again are very hard to verify. One can check ships out, but one has no guarantee that 24 hours later those ships will not have acquired from a submarine or from another surface ship a load of sea launched cruise missiles. In the end, I believe that both the Soviets and the United States will come to some agreement which accommodates their differences over those problems and puts them in the background.

I congratulate the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) on the way he has handled the joint defence facilities while he has had that portfolio. While poor Mr Beazley has very little to be congratulated on with his record level of failure as a defence Minister in the broader sense, he has taken the view that he should inform the Australian community as much as he can about these joint defence facilities. Progressively over the years, inch by inch, the door has been opened a little. I think it still has a way to go, and I would like to see it go a bit further because I hold to the Churchillian doctrine of trusting the people. The defence of this nation involves everyone. It involves everyone making considerable sacrifices of money and of their lives on some occasions. The defence of the nation cannot be left in the hands of a few elite who know what is going on.

I believe the reasons for the defence of Australia in itself, the reasons for the defence of the Western alliance and the reasons for the maintenance of world peace and security can be explained to the Australian people and their support can be enlisted. To that extent I welcome the moves that Mr Beazley has made to open up the joint facilities to a broader understanding by the Australian community. The joint facilities themselves are related to the alliances which Australia has. I turn to The Defence of Australia, the White Paper published in 1987, which is now the bible for Australian defence. On the first page, headed `Australia's defence policy', the second paragraph reads:
This policy of defence self-reliance is pursued within a framework of alliances and agreements. The most significant of these is with the United States.

It goes on to develop the importance of alliances. I would like to examine for a moment the record of this Government with respect to our alliances because even with the kindest interpretation it is a very, very dubious record. Alliances place obligations on both parties, even if they are not called up in their active form. Under this Government we had the Invincible incident in 1983: a British ship was denied docking facilities when it was in need of mechanical repair. That sent great shock waves through the American defence establishment, because it could just as easily have been one of its ships. Then we had the MX missiles decision. The Prime Minister had agreed in effect to enable some inert missiles to splash down in the Pacific because he granted refuelling rights to the observation aircraft-which was a reasonable thing to do and something that I would have thought was obligatory on us under the terms of the United States alliance-only to have his decision reversed by the lefties in the Australian Labor Party, screaming from under their beds. This again had a devastating effect on the way the United States viewed the stability of Australia in the alliance.

Then only a couple of months ago we had HMS Edinburgh, again with mechanical problems, wanting dry-docking facilities in Australia. The British Government asked the Australian Government whether it could guarantee that if the ship went into dry dock it would be serviced and it would sail when the service was completed. As it could not get the guarantees for that it did not make the formal application. That also was devastating for Australia's alliance. The British Government sends Royal Navy ships to Australia with a frequency of about one ship visit a year-maybe two; maybe none. It is a very low frequency. The Americans send at least 60 naval vessels here each year and they face the absolute certainty that at some time they are going to have a mechanical problem with the propulsion unit of a ship, through it rubbing against a dock or something like that and damaging the propeller. What are they going to do? Are they going to send a tug down from Pearl Harbour or Subic Bay? They are very worried about this and they have a right to be worried, because the response of the Government, in an act of blatant cowardice by not standing up to the Seamen's Union of Australia, the dock workers and the other sorts of people who are holding the country to ransom and writing the foreign policy for Senator Evans, is to say that it will buy a few tugs. Royal Australian Navy tugs will not solve the problem if there is a need to replace a propeller on a damaged US warship.

So, by a different route, this country with respect to its alliances has got itself into precisely the same position as the socialist Lange Government has got New Zealand into. Visits to Australia by American ships are now very much under a cloud. While I am on the subject of alliances and the way they are viewed by other countries, I cannot help reflecting that the man who made this statement on the joint defence facilities in the House of Representatives was the Prime Minister; and it was no-one other than the Prime Minister who, in that rabidly far left communistic phase he once was in, in 1976 and in earlier years, put his name to an advertisement in every newspaper in Australia calling for the abolition of the bases. So while it is part of the Judeo-Christian ethos of Australia that redemption is possible, it is certainly viewed with a jaundiced eye by military people around the world when someone who was violently opposed to the bases only about a decade ago now gets up and defends them.

Another matter I would like to look at in relation to our alliance is how reliable an ally Australia is. How reliable are we? What sort of preparedness is this Government prepared to make for our own defence? That is an important point, because one of the operative doctrines in respect of the ANZUS agreement is the Nixon statement of the 1969-70 era. The so-called Guam doctrine of the United States foreign policy is still the operative document. That doctrine sets out three precepts. The first is that the US will keep all its treaty commitments. The second is that the US shall provide a shield if a nuclear power threatens the freedom of a nation allied to the US or a nation whose survival the US considers vital to its security and the security of the region as a whole. The third requirement is that, in cases involving other types of aggression, the US shall furnish military and economic assistance when requested and as appropriate. The most important qualification in the Guam doctrine is where the US goes on to say:
But we shall look to the nation directly threatened to assume the primary responsibility of providing the manpower for its defence.
So there is an obligation on Australia under the Guam doctrine to prepare its own defence forces.

Only last week the report of a subcommittee of the Joint Committee or Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade was tabled in this place. This subcommittee, which is part of the biggest and most important committee in this Parliament, dealt with the crisis in the rates of resignation from the Australian defence forces. It analysed the reasons why around 45,000 men and women, out of a force structure of roughly 70,000, have voted with their feet and left the Australian defence forces since the Australian Labor Party came to power five years ago, a loss which, as the report says, has destroyed our defence capability not for a year but for at least a decade-presuming that the correct remedial action is taken, which so far the Government has not shown any inclination to do.

There has been a grievous loss of personnel from what are very small defence forces for Australia. These defence forces were highly competent, and certainly they were very professional before they bled to death as a result of high resignation rates. The Government just does not seem to recognise what is going on with respect to the capabilities of the Australian defence forces. Not only have we lost capability; we have also lost billions of dollars in real terms, because we trained the 45,000 men and women who have left and their average training cost was extremely high. That is a very great loss to the community, because their replacements have all got to be retrained. It is no exaggeration to say that the cost to the Australian taxpayer runs into billions of dollars.

The report went on to analyse why this was so. A fundamental point, of course, was the lack of leadership-the leadership failings of the Minister for Defence, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), the Ministry, the Government and, sadly, the Parliament as a whole. Many people in the Australian defence forces feel, and have felt, that no-one in the Government respects them or values the sacrifices that they make for this country. So they leave and follow another career. Part of this has been engendered by the inability of the Minister for Defence to stand up for his Department and fight for funds. We are now in a desperate position in respect of funding for the Australian defence forces.

Over 10 years ago the Department of Defence foresaw that, in the period from the mid-1980s through well into the 1990s, a great amount of new equipment would have to be bought to replace obsolescent equipment in the Australian defence forces. Provisions were made for that. The rolling five-year defence program on which the defence budgets are calculated was designed so that the capability of the Defence Force could be maintained and the new equipment could be bought. But a 4 1/2 per cent real growth per annum was required through that five-year period from the end of 1984 through to 1989 for that to take place.

What has this Government done? With a weak Minister who cannot fight with the social services, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) and others in Cabinet for a fair share of funds for the nation's essential defence interests, we have seen cuts every year in defence. This year alone there is a real cut of one per cent. There will be a cut on that of one per cent next year. The situation is really desperate. Ten years ago 18.2 per cent of the defence vote went to new capital equipment facilities. Now the figure is 29.6 per cent. Ten years ago 54.3 per cent of the defence budget went on personnel, the men and women in the Defence Force. Today the figure is 42.3 per cent. So there has been a huge lift in the ratio being allocated for the purchase of new capital equipment and a savage cut in what is going to personnel. The balance is totally wrong. Such a cut could be made without causing damage only if the size of the defence vote had increased. In fact, it has contracted-and contracted very considerably.

The worrying thing is that the situation is getting worse. Next year the Australian Defence Force will hold a big and ambitious exercise. That exercise, which is called Kangaroo 89, will involve the whole of 1st Division from the Army being deployed around the north of Australia, with major involvements by the Navy and the Air Force. Already we have seen gross reductions in defence expenditure or outgoings to compensate for what is now going to be a very reduced Kangaroo 89 exercise. Immediately after the Budget, the Chief of the General Staff, the head of the Army, circularised to all Army units that all outgoings would be cut back by 10 per cent. I see in today's paper that all Air Force flying is going to be cut back by 10 per cent. If that happens there will be a lot more accidents, because the present level of flying is either just below or at the barest minimum level required for competence to be maintained. We are seeing great cuts in command post exercises, or CPXs, which were set up before Kangaroo 89 in order that staff training could be put in place and analysis undertaken so that the most can be gained from the exercise. Those functions have been reduced to under a half.

Sadly, we are seeing a great cut in the amount of money that is going to the reserves, particularly the Army reserves. The scheme under which the Army reserves are integrated into the Army is working very well. The reserves have been neglected by all governments over the years. They have not had the priority for funding that they should have. This Government promised members of the reserves complete parity with members of the regular Army. The Government promised that they would be provided with adequate equipment and adequate funds to carry out their tasks. But the Government cut training days and taxed reserve personnel. However, it has now increased training days and removed the taxes.

The 12 Psychology Unit, a reserve unit from New South Wales, is due to go on its annual camp in the near future. But it simply has no money for rations. I have never heard of a more absurd situation than that. The unit will have to run its camp on a day parade basis with the diggers bringing a cut lunch. Coupled with the cuts in buying rations that were announced last week, we really are a mickey mouse operation. A more serious situation is the breaking of the promise with respect of the 105 Hamel guns. The reserve artillery units were promised that they would get the new 105 guns to replace the M2A2 that has been in service for many years. About 105 of these guns were to go to the permanent Army, with a further 43 of these guns to the reserve units. That reserve order has now been cancelled. The disappointment in reserve units will be enormous. It is a stupid decision too. We are producing this weapon in Australia and I support Government moves increasingly to make weapons and equipment for the armed services in Australia. But it is absolute nonsense to close the production line down and talk about buying new 105s from the United Kingdom if we need them, because the one thing that Australian defence manufacturing industry needs is continuity of orders. We are better off buying fewer units per year and keeping a production line going continuously rather than having a stop-start business with the inherent high costs that are involved. The Opposition welcomes the statement that has been tabled by the Government but we ask that it be viewed against the whole picture of Australia's defence, which is one of inadequacy, not to say disaster. It is no excuse for the Government to say after 5 1/2 years in office that it inherited the mess that we are in today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly with great distress that I speak about this 10-year agreement which was presented as a fait accompli to the people of Australia yesterday. The principal grievance is that, depite earlier proposals within the Australian Labor Party for discussions prior to any new arrangement, there was no community debate about the lease agreements after they changed in 1986-87. As usual, it was all done in secret and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) simply tabled the signed notes after they were signed a week ago by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, and the departing United States Ambassasor, Mr Bill Lane. This reflects a very bad process, I think, within the Labor Party, the governing party of this country, in which all factions certainly represent people in the community who would disagree with this decision. Resolution after resolution was passed at branch meetings but they were totally ignored. They reach the level of the State Executive and they are then tossed aside.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether the Labor Party will find a great lack of willing workers when next if faces an election, and I wonder whether there will be a great spate of resignations from the Party. Of course, the opposition is not confined to just the Labor Party: there are people in the National and Liberal parties also who will be disappointed that this decision has been made for a further 10 years. I remind the Senate that in 1986 the `no nuclear warships' write-on campaign during the Western Australian election saw 10 per cent of the people who voted for the Liberal Party write `no nuclear warships' on their ballot paper. That is a very clear indication that there is a constituency within the Liberal Party and also in the National Party, I believe, which is opposed to Australia having any involvement whatsoever with nuclear weapons.

I know that under the Westminster system the Executive can make decisions like this. It can sign notes of agreement with foreign powers and it does not have to consult with Parliament. It does not even have to consult with its own elected representatives and it certainly does not have to consult with the people. Of course, we are told in a very cynical way, `If you do not like what the Government does, you change the Government'. I would like to present an imaginary scenario tonight. I ask honourable senators to imagine that we had a coalition government-a Liberal-National Party government. Of course, one would expect such a government to make this kind of agreement although, as I have said, I think there are people within those parties and among their elected representatives who would not be happy about it. Imagine that the Opposition was in government and had just signed this 10-year agreement. The Labor Party in opposition would probably go to the next election on this issue opposing the agreement and it would romp it in. It would win an election on this issue because the public opinion polls in Australia are very clearly showing that the more people know about these bases the less they like them.

The tragedy is that it is the Labor Party doing what we might expect of the coalition. The Labor Party is ignoring its own supporters and it is a very cynical exercise indeed because it knows very well that there is not a better alternative on this issue as far as the national government goes. So I think it is just as well that we have people in this place at least who are prepared to stand up and voice their opposition to such appalling decisions which show such a total disregard for public opinion. So there will be many people in Australia tonight who will be feeling extremely disfranchised and who will be very pleased indeed that there are a group of Australian Democrats in this place and a couple of Independents who will continue to have the guts to stand up and say what needs to be said and to speak the truth on this issue because we are not getting the truth from anybody in the major parties.

What an abrogation it is of our sovereignty, especially in this our bicentennial year. Our sovereignty has been chucked out the window for another 10 years. So much for the glowing bicentennial talk. We are not able to chart an independent course on the international stage. It is a disgrace-a national disgrace. It makes me feel ashamed to be an Australian and to see us handing over our sovereignty to United States foreign policy, because that is what it amounts to.

There are many Australians today who feel disfranchised and disappointed because their elected representatives here in both Houses of the Parliament are not speaking out against this decision. Mind you, it is not too late for them to do so and I would be delighted to hear from anybody from the Liberal Party, the National Party or the Labor Party with the guts to speak out on this issue because so many of them know that it is not in the interests of Australia and that it is an immoral position for Australia to take. They are not being true to their own knowledge and, in many cases, they are not being true to the people that they meant to represent. I hope that people in the community will voice their disgust to their elected representatives right across the political spectrum at this agreement made by a Labor Government, of all governments. They would be voicing their opposition because the people in the community know that nuclear weapons are totally immoral and they know that the threat to use them, the presence of nuclear weapons and their very existence are totally immoral.

No nation, no individual has any moral right to threaten to use any weapons of mass destruction. There is no excuse, no reason and no justification, regardless of enemy perceptions or interests to be defended, and it is indefensible on any ground to consider the use of nuclear, biological or chemical weapons. Of course, by signing ourselves into this agreement for a further 10 years we are totally taking Australia along the same path for a longer period when we help the United States in its nuclear war fighting strategies. We are helping one of the superpowers with the possible use of these deadly weapons which are totally immoral under international law and against the laws of humanity and certainly against the laws of commonsense. So why has this change taken place? Suddenly the Labor Government, which we would not have expected to sign this kind of agreement for 10 further years, has done so in total secrecy.

The Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley, claims that he initiated the changes a year ago. A couple of years ago I asked a question in this place about whether there was any intention to change the agreements, and I was told very clearly that the agreements were working just fine as they were-that is, on a year-by-year basis-and that there was no intention to change them and the Government saw no need to change them. So why is it happening now? Mr Beazley says that it was not due to United States pressure, but it certainly looks that way. I believe that both the United States Government and the Australian Government are very aware of the changing opinion polls on this subject in Australia. It is as a result of the very good education program that has been carried out by the peace movement in this country over the past few years that the opinion polls are reflecting quite a dramatic change on this subject. In the latest defence track polls 44 per cent of Australians are shown to be opposed to United States bases on Australian soil; 58 per cent of young people under 25 are opposed to the bases; and 50 per cent of women are opposed to the bases. There used to be far more support for the bases when people did not know what they were there for but the more people know about them, the greater the opposition.

It is also interesting to note the age difference. Older people, who have a very much East-West view of the world and who were brainwashed very successfully, I believe, in the 1950s, are dying off and young people who have a different world view and who have not succumbed to the Moscow or Washington scenario are making much more intelligent decisions and they have a much more holistic view of the global family. That is how we must think of our world if we are to survive. We cannot continue to think in terms of the East-West bloc and to put all of our stakes in the Washington basket in opposition to the Moscow basket. That is a totally outmoded way of thinking. The greenhouse effect is showing us that. We must work together as a global community if we are to survive.

The Prime Minister says that the peace movement should support these bases now because there is greater Australian participation. I do not care how much Australian participation there is in the bases, their function remains the same-and that is to assist the nuclear war fighting strategies of the United States Government. Of course, there is no Australian in a top position. The best position that any Australian can be offered is a deputy position and it does not matter how many of them are there because the point is that the intelligence that is gathered by these bases is handed over to the United States. Once that happens no Australian has any control over the use to which it is put.

When we ask how the bases contribute to global stability we are told that much of the information is classified. In other words, the Government says, `Trust us'. The Australian Government is, in turn, trusting the United States Government. I think it is indeed misplaced trust. The United States does not have a very good track record; neither has our Government because of its deception and lying by omission. It does not have a very good record which would encourage us to trust it. We can find out more about what goes on in the bases from the United States under its freedom of information Act than we can from any Australian source.

There is a terrific obsession with secrecy in this country. I think it is really misplaced and totally unnecessary. We object to what we are not told about the bases, specifically the intelligence role and the first strike capability. Even Des Ball, who supports the existence of Pine Gap, though not Nurrungar, says that Pine Gap is doing monitoring and verification work only 40 per cent of the time. What is it doing the rest of the time? The satellites can look down over most of Asia. We know that the United States has used satellite intelligence in the past to pass on to allies such as Israel and the United Kingdom. Whom is the United States watching in Asia? To whom does it pass the information? For what purposes is it used? It is not only tracking and targeting of the Soviet Union that we, in the peace movement, are concerned about, although that is an overriding concern because it involves the use of weapons of mass destruction. It is also the information that the United States can use for its low intensity conflict such as warfare in places such as the Philippines and Central America.

Pine Gap makes us identify with the United States foreign policy through the selection of satellite observation areas even though our foreign policy objectives are not the same as those of the United States. They certainly should not be any way. It is about time we had an independent streak in our foreign policy. The first strike capability is something that our Government will not admit to. The Australian Government continues to quote United States government figures on deterrents but it has always ignored the differences between stated aims and actual policies. The military options are alive and well in the United States despite some glib political statements made by people such as President Reagan about nuclear weapons never being used and that a nuclear war must never be fought. The military planners in the United States have a doctrine of flexible options. Their intention is to use those nuclear weapons if they see fit to do so. We must not forget that there is a huge discrepancy between the military objectives and the stated political objectives.

As far as Nurrungar is concerned, according to documentation received from the United States Senate in 1982, General Randolph said of the NUDET system, which is a part of the Nurrungar system, `It is a war fighting capability'. Again, in March 1985, General Kutyna, when asked if the United States early warning system had a battle management capability, stated:
Yes, Sir . . . if you want to know which silos they have launched out of you can go after the full ones if you want to'.

That is a direct quote from two defence personnel in the United States who obviously intend to use the systems at their disposal with the cooperation of the bases in Australia. It is very clear that the military personnel in the United States want to hang onto those options. They spend all of their working hours working out exactly how well they can target the Soviet Union and how they can manage to get at the silos which have not been emptied. This is the kind of information used and passed to the United States through Nurrungar. The United States can identify which silos have been used and which ones remain to be taken out by the United States. That is a nuclear war fighting capability if ever there was one.

The new staffing arrangements show how much we have been coerced by the United States policy. We have surrendered our political independence. We seem to be identifying more and more with the United States world view. If it is true that the Minister for Defence initiated the change, it shows how totally he has gone over to a United States perspective on this. He is doing its thinking for it. Yet this is the man who, only a few years ago when the Labor Party was in opposition-I am beginning to think that may be the best place for it; it says some really good things in opposition-was asking the same sort of questions I am now asking. When he has been asked since what he has done with his conscience and how and why he has turned around on this issue, he cannot say anything. He has nothing to say.

We have to ask: what is in it for the Labor Government? What is in this for Bob Hawke? Why is Kim Beazley doing the thinking for the United States planners? The bases were set up in the 1960s to serve United States needs before any arms control agreements were ever signed. The monitoring and verification roles were thrown in later as an extra. Whatever the Prime Minister says about them, they play a legitimising role and were thrown in after the bases were established. They were established for the military prospectus of the United States. The United States has now thrown in the monitoring and verification system. Of course, it is very important that we have monitoring and verification. But I believe that Australia would be much better served by being part of an international monitoring and verification team. Why should we be doing the dirty work for one superpower against the other? Ipso facto then, the Soviet Union becomes our enemy and we become its nuclear target. It does not add up to a very sensible or logical position. If one thinks about the immorality of the possible use of nuclear weapons and Australia's contribution to that it is not to be commended in any way at all.

There was no mention in the speech of the Prime Minister yesterday about the impending redundancy of Nurrungar. It is most important that we understand the nuclear war fighting capabilities of Nurrungar and Pine Gap. The United States is now deploying advance nuclear detonation sensors on its new global positioning system-NAVSTAR. They should be fully deployed by the end of 1989, by which time technically Nurrungar could be considered obsolete. The data they pick up does not then have to be transmitted to Nurrungar in order to be relayed to the United States. It will go there directly via a UHF satellite to satellite relay. The United States has also created a satellite to satellite laser cross link enabling the DSP satellites to exchange data with each other without the need for ground relay stations. When this system is fully operational in a few years time, Nurrungar will no longer play a necessary role in either transmitting the critical DSP east data to the United States or processing that data. Once this system is operational, the arguments pertaining to the early warning role of Nurrungar will have lost much of their force.

Why now has the Labor Government decided to enter into a 10-year agreement? I believe it is because of pressure from the United States because it would be a great loss of face to the United States. It might set a precedence if any of the bases of the United States in Australia were closed down. The United States sees the writing on the wall as far as the opinion polls are concerned. It has other reasons for wanting to keep Nurrungar open as a backup system: firstly, the Nurrungar ground station is more capable than the mobile ground terminals in the United States; secondly, the United States seeks to have as much redundancy-that is, duplication-in its strategic systems as possible. That goes for all of them including the North West Cape which incidentally was not even mentioned in the Prime Minister's speech yesterday. The extension of an agreement is probably still being worked out.

The third reason why the United States wants to keep Nurrungar operational, even though it will not be of vital strategic importance, is that valuable research data is collected at Nurrungar which has little to do with early warning and which probably cannot be collected by the mobile ground terminals. It also provides command and control functions for the DSP east satellites which currently cannot be carried out remotely from the United States. There was also an argument about the Star Wars role of Nurrungar. It is almost certain that data on the boost phase of Soviet missile launches is still being collected at Nurrungar and handed over to the strategic defence initiative (SDI) office. This could also be used in a future SDI boost phase warning target acquisition and damage assessment system. North West Cape is also facing redundancy but will, for some of the reasons I have just mentioned relating to Nurrungar, be deemed desirable to be kept in place by the United States military, if for no other reason than that it would create a very dangerous precedent if a foreign base operated by the United States military was seen to close down. It could have a domino effect. Of course, this is what the United States was so scared about. It gave a name to the increasing opposition to the nuclear aspect of alliance arrangements after the New Zealanders very bravely chose to keep nuclear weapons out of their ports. The United States called it the Kiwi disease and of course it does not want it to spread.

The Minister for Defence says that North West Cape is more valuable to Australia than to the United States. But the fact is that it is far more than we shall ever need with our small fleet in the region. However, as has been shown by recent opinion polls conducted by the Australian peace movement, many Australians have the view that as long as North West Cape loses its nuclear connections-that is, as long as the Americans are not operating out of North West Cape-they would be much happier to see it being used by the Royal Australian Navy.

What does the peace movement want in terms of the bases? For a long time we have been calling for a national inquiry into the role of the bases. It is time that the public had more information provided to it by our Government. What the Prime Minister told us yesterday was an insult to the intelligence of anybody who has read anything about the role and function of the so-called joint facilities. It is what the peace movement has been saying for years and years-in fact, ever since it was established. We do not hear officially from the Government about the cynical use to which the information could be put. I believe that people in Australia have a right to this information. They need to be able to make an informed decision on this matter. Of course, the Government does not want us to have a fully funded public inquiry in this issue of the bases because it knows very well that informed public opinion would go against the bases. Australians do not want to be tied into the military operations of any other country, be it the United States or any other country, particularly if it involves the use of weapons of mass destruction. So the first thing that we think should be done, and we will continue to call for it, is that a national inquiry into the role of the bases be established.

We also believe that more work should be done by the Australian Government on an international system of monitoring and verification, rather than tying Australia into the arms race and identifying with one military superpower as against the other. We realise that the United States will not turn over its very expensive satellites or other technology to an international body, but we need to explore proposals such as the French proposal of some years ago or the current Canadian proposals. There is no technical impediment to an international verification and monitoring system. We should be working with other countries in our region, checking up on all countries which hold nuclear weapons-the French, the Chinese, the British, the South Africans, and the Israelis and possible nuclear nations like India, Pakistan, Brazil and Argentina. All of the world's people have an interest in seeing nuclear disarmament come about, so all of the countries which have nuclear weapons at their disposal or which have the capability of making nuclear weapons need to be monitored by the rest of the nations.

This is a role that I think Australia should be taking very seriously. We have a responsibility to be part of an international monitoring system. As I have said, there is no technical impediment but only a lack of political will on this subject. But increasingly the tide of opinion is turning on this matter of international verification, rather than the national technical means of verification-that is, the United States doing its own checking up on the Soviet Union, with the help of allies such as Australia, and the Soviet Union doing its checking up on the United States. The member states of the United Nations are increasingly calling for international monitoring and verification as the only responsible position to take.

Ultimately, I oppose the bases because I believe that we must get beyond the bloc thinking which has dominated the world since 1945. To work towards the de-alignment of Australia from the nuclear confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union is my aim. To do that we must get rid of all foreign military facilities from our soil. We must work towards a nuclear free and independent Australia within the wider context of a truly nuclear free and independent Pacific and a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean as well as a zone of peace, freedom and neutrality in South East Asia. That means an end to all foreign bases in the region, including the Soviet bases in Vietnam, the French colonial presence in the South Pacific, and all the United States military and intelligence facilities in the Pacific.

I do not believe that the peace movement is isolationist, and nor am I talking about neutrality. I am talking about a de-aligned and independent Australia that can take a constructive role for disarmament along with other middle ranking powers on the world stage. The peace movement will not be silenced by this recent decision by the Government. We will not stop our community education program. It is very interesting that peace groups around the country, of course, in voicing their opposition have some very particular concerns. I would like to quote from a press release put out by the Alice Springs Peace Group today. Of course the people there appreciate very much their position as nuclear targets. The press release states:

The Alice Springs Peace Group calls on all Alice Springs residents to take special note that the Government which so readily signs up for another 10 years under the nuclear umbrella has received only a few weeks ago a report on the risks to our town of an attack on the base which states clearly that 5,000 of us will die if nuclear war breaks out. In 10 years time the number will be twice or three times that. Is this the way our Government looks after our security?

Finally, I reiterate that these bases contribute nothing to Australia's security. Pine Gap and Nurrungar have nothing to do with Australia's defence. The only exception to that is North West Cape, which I referred to earlier, which is used by the Royal Australian Navy, but in a time of crisis all the communications channels are handed over to the United States, and we get a communications channel accessible to us only if the United States does not want all the channels. So much for our independence. So much for the shared and joint nature of the facilities.

The bases that the Prime Minister's statement referred to, Pine Gap and Nurrungar, make nuclear targets out of us and contribute nothing whatsoever to our defence. We will continue in our opposition to the bases until we see Australia free of its immoral contribution to the arms race. The people in the community know that this position is right. Eventually politicians will have to reflect the wisdom of an informed public. As I said in concluding my first speech in this Parliament of Australia, where I am proud to serve people who voted for me and proud to continue to be a voice true to the issues on which I was elected, when the people lead the leaders will follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very strange bicentennial gift that the Labor Government has given to Australia. Basically, the gift is the admission to the world that Australia is well and truly the fifty-first State of the United States of America, that we are all Americans. The United States prompted this change in the agreement. This change in the agreement about the bases was not prompted by Australia at all; it was done by the US, and it was done for the reasons that have already been outlined by Senator Vallentine. The United States is very worried about the opinions in Australia, which are changing so rapidly against the bases. So many people are worried about the bases. So many people see the dangers and so many people realise that there are very few benefits or no benefits in having them. The peace campaign is working, and this, of course, frightens the United States. It frightens the defence establishment, and when the defence establishment is frightened in the United States it pulls the levers and Australia responds.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I am ashamed to be Australian at this moment. I came to Australia as a migrant from America thinking that this was a free and independent country. I came here when Gough Whitlam was the Prime Minister. He looked like such a bright, shining beacon on the world stage. Now I find that the Australia of today is nothing but an imitation of that Australia. In fact, it is very much like Nixon's America, the America that I left. I would like to point out, too, that as a former American I know that the Americans like us, but they do not respect us-and that is because we are so eager to follow the wishes and will of the United States.

What about the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)? The Prime Minister made much of the increased Australian participation in the key operations and management of Pine Gap and Nurrungar. This, according to the Prime Minister, `reinforces our confidence that our interests and sovereignty are respected at all times', and means that `Australia will be able to take more direct advantage of the facilities' capabilities for our own purposes than has been practicable in the past'. I do not believe that that is the case.

To the extent that Australians do play an increased role at Pine Gap and Nurrungar, Australia is becoming a de facto nuclear power. One of the fingers on the nuclear button is now Australian. Of course, the massive thumb on that launch button is still American. Pine Gap and Nurrungar still remain fundamentally under United States control. The facilities still serve American purposes, not Australian purposes. Pine Gap's satellites gather signals intelligence according to American priorities. Their main target is the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) rather than countries in Australia's region. According to the Australian National University's Professor Des Ball, the targets which the satellites are to spy on are set out in a monthly joint reconnaissance schedule, which is prepared in the United States by the National Reconnaissance Office and approved by the National Reconnaissance Executive Committee. Nowhere in that procedure is there any Australian input. The National Reconnaissance Executive Committee is chaired by the Director of the Central Intelligence Agency and includes the Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs and a representative of the Pentagon.

The only Australian involvement in satellite scheduling comes after the real decisions have been made in the day to day implementation of the joint reconnaissance schedule. Nurrungar is the trigger which could initiate a US nuclear attack on the USSR. It also allows the US to locate nuclear targets inside the USSR during the course of the `protracted' and `controlled' nuclear wars for which the Pentagon has laid detailed plans. As the Government has now admitted, Nurrungar is part of the defence support program. This is an American satellite system operated by the US Air Force's Space Command and used by the Aerospace Defence Command, the Strategic Air Command, the National Military Command system, the Atlantic, Pacific and European commands and the intelligence agencies. Again, it does not need to be said that these are American agencies, not Australian.

Pine Gap and Nurrungar will always be under US command. I do not think anyone in this chamber could honestly think that they will be turned over to Australia to be used for Australian purposes. The claim that Australia can use the bases for its own purposes raises the question of what those purposes are. In the case of Pine Gap, the Government is presumably talking about spying on radio communications in the South-East Asian, south-west Pacific and eastern Indian Ocean regions. Of course Australia already does this, using the electronic spy bases run by the Defence Signals Directorate, or DSD. The Royal Australian Navy patrols the region, as do P3 Orion aircraft. The Australian Secret Intelligence Service, (ASIS), also attempts to spy on our neighbours.
In 1985 the Australian National University's Professor Des Ball was asked how Australia could collect adequate intelligence for its own purposes. His view was:

. . . if you put DSD together with an efficient and capable Department of Foreign Affairs, using diplomats to gather information . . . without engaging in clandestine activities, then that would be satisfactory for our purposes.

It would be. Why, then, do we have to go through this charade of saying that the Americans are giving us necessary data from Pine Gap and Nurrungar when in fact it is not happening? Mr Beazley himself is so proud of our own spying abilities that he told Parliament on 24 February last year:
We have our own intelligence gathering capability and it is very effective.

So why does Australia need increased access to Pine Gap? The answer seems to lie in the Government's new self-appointed role of regional policeman. It wants to know as much as possible about other countries' domestic affairs, far more than is needed for any genuine Australian security purposes. Australia's neighbours have every right to feel threatened by our present ability to spy on them.
