The added prospect of being monitored by Pine Gap adds to Australia's image as the big brother of this region, and it is not a benign big brother.

The best protection in this region for all of us is, of course, to remove the bases. Much has been said about Pine Gap's role in verification. We are often told by the Government that we are participating in the keeping of the peace in the world by the verification role of Pine Gap and Nurrungar. In a statement Mr Hawke claimed `intelligence collected at Pine Gap contributes importantly to the verification of arms control and disarmament agreements'. He talked about the breakthrough achieved in the intermediate range nuclear forces (INF) treaty, under which US and Soviet medium and short range missiles are now being destroyed. He mentioned the current strategic arms reduction talks (START) which, if successful, will reduce the US and Soviet long range nuclear arsenals to half their present size, and he claimed that without Pine Gap and Nurrungar `the INF Treaty could not have been signed and the START process would not have got underway'. That is utter rubbish. Verification, the process of checking that the other side has not cheated on an arms agreement, has been the Government's prime justification for the bases for some time. The Government has used verification to deflect criticism of the espionage and nuclear war fighting roles of the bases.

But the facts do not support the Government's case. The Pine Gap installation performs only one specific function which is potentially relevant to verification-it can monitor the test flights of Soviet nuclear missiles. The Nurrungar situation has to do, as Senator Vallentine said, with the location of empty silos and, by deduction, the location of full silos so that American missiles will not be wasted on empty ones but may be used more effectively on full ones. The verification role of the INF treaty that Mr Hawke is so proud of-we are all proud of the treaty-actually does far more than just limit nuclear weapons. I quote from a New Scientist article of 9 June 1988, headed `Verification pact underscores summit success':

The science of verification is at the heart of the treaty on Intermediate Nuclear Forces signed last week in Moscow by Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev. Both sides agree that the treaty has the most comprehensive and intrusive rules ever established to monitor compliance with an agreement on arms control.

I point out that what this treaty really did was make an arrangement for the first time so that military observers from the Soviet Union could visit the United States and United States observers could visit the Soviet Union. There is a swap of personnel. The paranoia that has surrounded the arms race for years is now evaporating. Unfortunately it has not evaporated in Australia or in this chamber, but around the world, in the real world, in the Soviet Union and in the United States, people are starting to trust one another. There was an article recently in the papers, basically buried right at the back on page 26 or on the weather page, headed, `Nuclear tests in the United States monitored by Soviet scientists'. There was another article a few days later headed `Nuclear tests in the Soviet Union monitored by United States scientists'. That is a massive breakthrough in trust for peace. Although they were monitoring nuclear tests, at least they were there: they were allowed to be on the evil empire's soil. There is a change taking place. I go back to the New Scientist article, which states:

The procedures for monitoring the INF treaty even cover nuclear weapons not regulated by the treaty, notably the Soviet SS-25 inter-continental ballistic missiles. The purpose is to ensure that the Soviet Union does not disguise its stock of SS-20s, which are covered by the INF treaty and which physically resemble SS-25s.
This is the verification part:

For three years, or until a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty . . . comes into effect, the US can ask the Soviet Union to open the roofs of buildings housing SS-25 missiles and move the missiles and their launchers to open ground as American spy satellites pass overhead.

Some might immediately jump to the conclusion that these have something to do with Pine Gap. They do not. The American spy satellites are in a polar orbit. They have excellent sensing devices in that they are multi-spectral and they have optical, infra-red and ultra-violet very high resolution detection devices, and they actually pick up the data and transmit it to the United States on the next orbit or the next orbit but one. They do not need to relay data to Pine Gap. Pine Gap basically runs geostationary orbit satellites which are located over the Equator and in an orbit which matches the rotation of the earth and as such has no part in this type of verification.

The US is permitted six such requests a year for each missile base. The Soviet Union must meet a request within six hours, leaving roofs open and the missiles and launchers in full view until 12 hours after the request is received, according to the Arms Control Association, an independent body of observers in the United States. The Soviet Union and the United States have now exchanged the names of 200 inspectors on each side who will carry out the tasks of verifying the INF treaty on the other country's sovereign territory, or that of its allies. The inspectors will be able to visit military bases in Britain, West Germany, Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands, East Germany and Czechoslovakia as well as bases in the US and the Soviet Union. The inspectors must be technicians, linguists and diplomats. They should not, however, operate as intelligence agents, and both superpowers can object to particular individuals within 20 days of being given the list of 200 names. There are a number of different types of inspections. Both countries can, between 30 and 90 days after the treaty comes into force, make baseline inspections of agreed facilities. They can also do close-out inspections which ensure that a military base that was once a facility for launching INF missiles has ceased to be so.

There is also a very interesting number of inspections called portal monitoring of production. This is a very unusual and intrusive inspection. The US and the Soviet Union can both establish a permanent team of 30 inspectors living near to a designated missile production plant. The US has chosen to establish its monitoring team on the doorstep of the Votkinsk machine building plant west of the Urals. The plant assembles SS-25 missiles, the strategic missile which the treaty does not cover but which can be confused with SS-20s. The Soviet Union has chosen the Hercules Plant Number One at Magma in Utah, where the US assembles its ground-launched ballistic missiles, notably the MX and the Trident weapons. So much for the Pine Gap verification role. Obviously it has no part to play in the modern disarmament situation because the United States and the Soviet Union have gone far beyond the time when all they could do was fly over each other's territory with spy planes or satellites and depend on them for information. We now have actual on-site inspection. There is no doubt and no disagreement anywhere in the world that on-site inspection is the most effective inspection-far better than any remote sensing could ever be.

What about Nurrungar? The Prime Minister stated that Nurrungar `would give the earliest warning of an intercontinental ballistic missiles attack on the US or its allies, which reduces the chances that US forces would be destroyed in a surprise attack and plays a vital role in helping to prevent nuclear war by accident'. The Government's statement is only one side of the coin. Nurrungar also gives the US the confidence that it can manage a nuclear war. The United States has devised detailed plans for fighting limited and protracted nuclear wars in which Nurrungar plays a key role. Firstly, Nurrungar's satellite can tell the US which Soviet missile silos are empty by detecting missile launches so that the United States does not waste its own missiles on them. Secondly, Nurrungar can tell the US whether a nuclear warhead aimed at a certain target was successful in destroying that target by detecting the resultant explosion. Anyone who doubts that these war plans exist need look only as far as a Pentagon document entitled Standard Operating Procedures for Nuclear Operations conducted by the Commander-In-Chief of US Forces in the Pacific. This document specifies operations in the event of `limited' nuclear wars and even plans to reconstitute US nuclear forces to fight World War IV once World War III is over. What a terrible indictment of the American thinking to actually be planning World War IV after World War III. This is the type of mind which is behind Pine Gap. It is at least as likely that the United States will start a nuclear war as it is that the USSR will do so. Nurrungar, North West Cape and Pine Gap will all be involved. Australia should have no part in these preparations for genocide.

What about North West Cape? The Prime Minister's speech made no mention of North West Cape, despite the fact that it is one of the three major US bases in Australia. Today's Age claimed that North West Cape's agreement would not be re-extended. At present, either side can give six months' notice of termination. This may reflect the fact that North West Cape has a purely offensive military function, namely, communicating with US surface ships and attack submarines, as well as Australian submarines. It is difficult to claim that North West Cape helps prevent nuclear war, although the Government has tried to do so in the past, and it is impossible to claim that the base contributes to verification. However, there is a strong possibility that the Government will secretly extend the North West Cape agreement at some time in the future. So far, Parliament has not been told otherwise. It is an odd thing that Parliament is not necessarily privy to this. These decisions are made by the Executive, not Parliament. We have tried for years with Bills, for example, to enable the Parliament of this country-the people of this country through the people's House-actually to control these agreements. Not so. Increasingly, it is the Prime Minister and the Executive of the present Labor Administration that control them.

Apart from serving US interests, the Government may want to ensure continued Australian use of the base for submarine communications. The Government claims that 25 per cent of communications traffic through North West Cape is Australian. The Government should establish a parliamentary inquiry into the future of North West Cape. It should also inform Parliament of its plans for the agreement.
What about democracy? On 25 November 1986 the Prime Minister answered a question on notice about the agreement covering Pine Gap, in the following terms:

The Agreement provides that when the present non-terminable period expires in October 1987, the Agreement continues in force unless either party gives due notice of termination. The Government does not at present see any need to alter that arrangement.

In the intervening two years the Government has changed its mind without even informing, let alone consulting, the Australian Parliament or the public. Yet again, a momentous decision on the bases has been presented as a fait accompli. This is an abuse of the executive power of government and is blatantly undemocratic. It is well known from public opinion polls that public interest in and concern about the bases are high. Senator Vallentine read out some of the recent poll results. Forty-four per cent of Australians want US bases to be removed; 51 per cent want US nuclear related communications bases removed; and 58 per cent want the ANZUS alliance either scrapped completely or made non-nuclear.

There have been large protests at all three major US bases in the last two years. Even farmers and conservative voters have questioned the value of the alliance, following the US-Europe trade war. The Government's response has been to secretly take the bases off the political agenda. There was no legal need to do so, and the agreements still stood. There was no political advantage in doing so, as many Australians now question the alliance. The Government is acting on behalf of American interests rather than those of its own people. This is government for the people, of the people, by the United States. It is time we became a mature member of the world community rather than being a snivelling, cringing, dependent colony. If we make a noise like a rug, we get walked on. Right now we sound like a very worn carpet indeed. It is time to close the bases. The bases must go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak as part of what I would describe as the conventional peace movement to attempt to balance the contribution to the debate made by the last two speakers, who are part of the unilateral disarmament movement. As I look around I see in the chamber others who I think could fairly be described as part of that conventional peace movement: Senator MacGibbon, Senator Tambling and Senator Crichton-Browne, to name three-people who want peace and security but who do not trust unilateral disarmament and who believe that Australia is better off if we are prepared to support our friends.

SPEECH.PARA: I rose to speak also because I found it fascinating when I read the statement on the bases by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to think that perhaps he was referring to a press release I had issued on 8 April this year, shortly after I led an Opposition parliamentary delegation on a visit to both Pine Gap and Nurrungar. It was a visit by the Opposition's foreign affairs and defence committee, something that I suspect the Government's parliamentary back bench committee has not bothered to undertake. In fact, I know that to be the case, because we were the first parliamentary party delegation to make the effort to go to the bases, to inspect them, and to talk to the people, both Australian and American, who work there. When I came back from that visit I issued a press release, in the first paragraph of which I stated:

If the Hawke Government was more open and frank with the Parliament and the Australian people as to the role and functions of the Australia-US Joint Facilities, it might receive more public support for the bases.

Of course, we now have the Prime Minister's statement claiming the Government is more open and frank and therefore seeking greater public support for the bases. Unfortunately, one does not learn a lot from reading the Prime Minister's statement. That is consistent with his approach some four years ago, in 1984, when he last put down a statement on the bases. At that time he said he would make a ministerial statement that would fulfil the Government's commitment to `inform the public of the general purpose and function of the joint Australia-United States facilities'. As honourable senators would be aware, the Prime Minister's subsequent statement added nothing to what was already on the public record. A somewhat similar situation applied when we visited the bases. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) gave permission, as is necessary, for us to visit the bases, but when we got there we were told by the officials that unfortunately they were not permitted by the Australian Government to tell us more than was already on the public record. I might say that that was somewhat embarrassing to the American officials as they have a somewhat different attitude to these things from the Australian Government. They were prepared to brief more fully but were restrained from doing so by the Australian Government. So the Australian Government restrained American officials from informing Australian parliamentarians of the functions of these bases. That was a truly astonishing situation. It was unusual for the Americans because, as you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, the United States Senate Armed Services Committee and other congressional committees are briefed fully on establishments such as these. We have an illusion of openness by the Australian Government but really it has a continuing mushroom mentality. I do not think that is in the best interests of democracy in this country, because it is still my view that if the Australian people were taken into greater confidence in relation to these bases and were told of their purpose and the part they play in ensuring peace for this country, suspicions would be put to rest and there would be greater community support for the role that they play.

If one reads the books of, say, Dr Desmond Ball and refers to Pine Gap, one finds they say that the base acts as a giant vacuum cleaner, able to draw up telemetry radar, radio and other electronic data from the nations which might pose a threat to the Western alliance. I said in my press release that if that is the case, why not admit it. In actual fact, what the Prime Minister has done in this statement is almost admit that. He does not go quite as far as that detail, although it could hardly be called detail, but he admits the intelligence function of Pine Gap. How dramatic! Clearly, the intelligence function is appreciated by the Australian people. I disagree totally with Senator Vallentine when she says that the Australian community, if brought into the Government's confidence, would not support an intelligence gathering capacity of that nature. Clearly they would. The Australian people would be able to better understand how the facility contributes to verification of arms control agreements and how it contributes to ensuring peace.

The satellite ground station at Nurrungar is described by Dr Ball in his books as principally in early warning installation monitoring the energy emission of missiles. That is what the Prime Minister now tells us, dramatically, is the purpose of the Nurrungar base. Why then in the five years that the Government has been in office have Mr Hawke and his Government not been prepared to take the Australian people into the Government's confidence? In relation to Nurrungar, it is clear that Australians would support anything that Australia might do which acts as a disincentive to a nuclear first strike. Clearly, a base that monitors emissions from missiles, that can record missiles taking off from other places in the world, does act as an early warning installation and, therefore, would be supported by the Australian people.

We came back from that visit, which was informative in some ways but disappointing in others, applauding the people who work on the bases and make a commitment to Australia and the United States. In the case of the United States, men and women work a long way from their families but, nevertheless, they recognise the contribution that they make towards our peace and security as well as the peace and security of their homeland and the peace and security of other friendly nations. We recognised and applauded their work. We recognised the role that the bases can play towards peace and security. We were pleased to have been informed by Dr Ball but were disappointed that the Australian Government was not prepared to let us into its confidence. I look at this statement as a small step forward in the right direction.

In the eyes of the Opposition, the bases are obviously to be supported. In our view they are an important contribution to peace and security. It follows logically, but after the last two contributions it is worth restating it, that the Opposition supports the Western alliance. It supports a recognition that peace and security must be looked at in global terms, that there is no security in isolation, and it recognises these bases as part of our contribution to that wider Western alliance. It is an alliance of like democracies of nations throughout the world that want to protect the sort of freedom and security which we treasure so much in this country. The bases in their intelligence gathering and early warning roles are, in our view, a modest contribution by Australia but nevertheless a contribution that should be supported. We have always said that when a country becomes part of a wider alliance with nuclear powers there are risks associated with that. As you will recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, this Parliament recognised that in its 1982 report on threats to Australia and on other occasions. Nevertheless, I am pleased to say that the Parliament then, and more recently in its important paper on disarmament, generally recognised that there is a greater risk in not being part of an alliance and in trying to go it alone.

Certainly we have immediate defence responsibilities. We must be regionally capable of defending ourselves and regionally capable of providing deterrents. But beyond that it is clear that when we talk about security against nuclear weapon powers and security against superpowers, we need support. That is nothing to be ashamed of. It is simply a fact of our economic position in the world and it is also part of the fact that we have no wish in this country to go down the nuclear weapon path. We in the Opposition support the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. We support efforts that are made to prevent horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons and we support efforts that are made against vertical proliferation of nuclear weapons.

We are debating the statement tonight in what I think can be described as exciting times. I refer to the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty. The treaty seeks to reduce the number of intermediate range nuclear weapons in Europe and the Far East. The Opposition believes that that is a wonderful achievement and looks forward to the process continuing in the much more difficult area of the strategic arms reduction talks. When we can achieve reductions in strategic weapons whilst maintaining deterrents, we believe that we will be in a safer world. Therefore, we support contributions towards that objective.

However, we recognise that the West cannot safely enter into reduction agreements without adequate verification. Even this Government claims to recognise that fact. In other words, we recognise that the West cannot safely reduce the number of nuclear weapons unless adequate strength and commitment are maintained. I am pleased to say that through the leadership of the United States, under President Reagan, which I am happy to acknowledge, that strength has been maintained and, in many ways, increased while at the same time the world has made the first positive contribution to a reduction in the number of nuclear weapons. We want that process to continue, but it can continue only if there is verification. Australia should play its part, can play its part and does play its part through these joint defence facilities.

Not only is this an exciting time in the world in terms of the reduction, and the potential for greater reduction, in nuclear weapons, but also, as someone recently said, there are signs that peace is breaking out all over. We have had a settlement at last of the Iran-Iraq dispute-it is great to see that the United Nations has been so active in that settlement-a dispute settled after eight bloody years. We have seen the Soviet Union prepare for and commence its pull-out of Afghanistan, something that we have no hesitation in applauding and which can provide peace and security eventually for the Afghan people. I acknowledge again the role the United Nations has played in that regard. We are now seeing an agreement between South Africa, Angola and Cuba on Namibia, something that some of us have been looking for for a long time. Whilst we are still a fair way off achieving a total resolution of that dispute, the withdrawal of troops and a position in which to maintain security, there is nevertheless real hope. Perhaps for the first time there is now real hope of a settlement in the 10-year old Kampuchean conflict. We see that the Soviet Union and China are now looking towards their first summit meeting next year since Khrushchev went to Beijing in 1959.

We are living all of a sudden in exciting times when peace seems to be breaking out all over. Our responsibility now is to ensure that Australia continues to do its bit to enable those agreements to be brought home to final fruition and to provide a more secure world for all of us. A safer and more secure world will happen only with deterrents and with verification, but if they can be provided, as Australia is providing them through these bases, there may be, for the first time in a long period, a redirection of resources towards those who are in poverty and who have a real economic need, rather than continually into ever increasing military spending. That is something that we would applaud.

Before I conclude, it would be remiss of me if I did not mention at least three areas in which I feel that the Australian Government, the Hawke Government, is not playing its part in contributing to the type of goals that I have just been putting to the Senate. Firstly, I have made it clear that we have a responsibility to maintain through this period an adequate defence, particularly in relation to regional affairs. What is obvious, again as a result of the report of the bipartisan Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in the last week or two, is the appalling state of Australia's defence forces. Mr Acting Deputy President, this is something which you spoke of in greater detail earlier tonight and it should be repeated over and over again. I am, of course, referring to the report on wastage, the rather frightening level of resignation from our defence forces. That is not consistent with maintaining peace and Australia's regional or wider responsibilities. Regrettably, it is happening primarily, I believe, because of a feeling within the defence forces that their efforts are not appreciated, that they are not recognised by this Government, that they are not regarded with the same pride with which for example, the United States forces are regarded by the United States community at large. The sooner the Australian community-it would be easier if it were led by this Government in the right direction-properly appreciates and recognises the service of Australia's military personnel, men and women, and rewards them accordingly not only in monetary terms but also in the other ways in which we show respect in this country, the better off we will be. As I said, leadership from Government is totally lacking in this area.

The second area I wish to refer to was also mentioned by you, Mr Acting Deputy President; that is, damage to the alliance. Evidence that Australia is not a reliable partner in the alliance undermines our security position and there was no more classic demonstration to our friends of our unreliability than what happened recently when the Australian Government invited our friends' and allies' ships and naval officers to Australia as part of our Bicentenary. When they got here, at least in some Australian ports, the unions refused to allow the ships to dock and refused to allow those sailors, the guests of Australia, onto Australia's shores.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the peace movement spat on the sailors as they walked ashore.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne says, members of the so-called peace movement spat on the sailors as they walked ashore. But what did the Australian Government do to ensure that we behaved as hosts should to those we invite to this country-our allies in the defence of Australia? It said that it could do nothing because otherwise it would offend the unions. That is a national disgrace and it undermines the strength of the alliance. It shows to our partners that we are not reliable and it is perhaps the greatest indictment of all of the Hawke Government for its lack of contribution in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The last concern that I have-I hope that to some extent it will now be put to rest by the agreement for a new 10-year lease on these bases-is the willingness of the Hawke Government, Mr Hawke and his trade Ministers, to use the bases as tools in trade negotiations; in other words, to put Australia's security assets up as bargaining tools in negotiations for access in trade. I hope that that is something that the next Australian government, the coalition, would never do, because it sends to our partners and to our allies totally the wrong message-the message that we do not take security and defence seriously, that we do not recognise the contribution that other nations, our friends and allies, play in our defence-leading to a concern on their part that if the crunch ever comes we will not be prepared to play our part in their defence.

I conclude by reiterating the Opposition's support for the alliance and Australia's contribution to that alliance by hosting the intelligence gathering facilities on our shores. I am pleased that the Government has taken the small step of taking the Australian people into its confidence in explaining the purpose of these bases. I hope that they will long remain, that the alliance will remain strong and that Australia will gain the benefits of peace and security that can come therefrom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dunn Sen I.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) revealed to the people of Australia that the Government had extended for a further 10 years the agreement covering the leases at the so-called joint bases at Pine Gap and Nurrungar and had extended the amount of notice required for termination of these agreements from one year to three years. It is very kind indeed of the Prime Minister to give us the opportunity of debating the subject of the bases after the Government has signed the agreement! That is, it seems to me, akin to shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted. In spite of this debate, of course, these agreements cannot be revoked by Parliament, so I wonder what we are all doing here tonight talking about them. I feel that it is a great pity the Government did not allow the debate to proceed before any decision was made.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke also announced that there would be greater involvement of Australian personnel in the operation of the bases. There could be less, I would suggest, if Mr Hawke wants to call them joint facilities. However, that is probably the only thing in Mr Hawke's announcement that I could commend. This is the latest step in the Government's refusal to consult with people and their elected representatives. It is maintaining the extraordinary secrecy surrounding the installations and what the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, says gives us no hope that the secrecy will be broken down. It is continuing to keep Australian people in the dark about the real functions of the bases and it is continuing to misrepresent the bases as being essential to Australia's security interests and to the broader interests of global security. Nurrungar is officially known as the joint defence space communications station. It is, as the Prime Minister points out, the ground station for the eastern hemisphere early warning satellite of the US defense support program (DSP). The Prime Minister tells us that Nurrungar plays a vital role in helping to prevent nuclear war and that Australians can be glad that we help to operate this vital facility. I would suggest that gladness is not the sentiment Australians should be expressing. Rather, they should be and are concerned and even outraged at the siting of such a facility on Australian soil.

The Prime Minister would have us believe that the DSPs missile launch detection capability continues to have a deterrence function and that the satellite mounted nuclear detonation, or NUDET, sensors, which transmit data through Nurrungar to the United States are also essential for arms verification. Recent commentary has indicated that NUDET sensors no longer play a necessary role in arms control verification. The US is deploying advanced nuclear detonation sensors on its new navigation satellite system (NAVSTAR) which, when fully deployed, will mean that nuclear explosion data will no longer have to be relayed through Nurrungar. Why are we extending the lease for Nurrungar? Furthermore, the development by the United States of satellite to satellite laser cross-link technology in conjunction with a mobile ground terminal (MGT) system will mean that Nurrungar will play a much less critical role in terms of missile early warning.

Given that both NAVSTAR and the cross-link MGT systems are likely to be fully operational within the new few years, thus rendering Nurrungar unnecessary in terms of the Government's justification for its existence, one might question why the Government has extended the leases on this base. I suggest that these capabilities contribute directly to the US nuclear strategy. They clearly play an essential part in American first strike capability, something that the Prime Minister managed to avoid any reference to in his statement yesterday. It is this contribution which the Pentagon views as the most important one Nurrungar can make. As Senator Vallentine has already stated, in 1982 General Rudolph, in testimony to the US Senate Armed Services Committee, said that NUDET was a war-fighting capability. Similarly, General Hartinger, Commander of the US Air Force Space Command which runs the DSP program, has stated flatly that the DSP is tied into the war-fighting structure.

Given that Nurrungar is part of DSP program, we can only assume that it too is tied into this same war-fighting structure. The nuclear war-fighting strategy of the United States, as opposed to a deterrence policy which involves the development of a counterforce attack capability, is considered to be dangerous and destabilising. So, therefore, are the installations which support these capabilities. Yet in 1984 Mr Hawke, in his June speech to the House of Representatives to which he made reference yesterday, said:
The notion of a nuclear first strike . . . would be destabilising were it to gain credence.

He also indicated that his Government's voice would be directed towards supporting doctrines which eschewed moving beyond stable deterrence towards postures more appropriate to waging nuclear war. In 1984 the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bill Hayden, also argued against the doctrine of nuclear war fighting in a much publicised pamphlet entitled Uranium, the Joint Facilities, Disarmament and Peace. He said:
To prepare to fight a limited war . . . is in fact to make nuclear war more thinkable and therefore more possible.

There is, clearly, an inconsistency between the Hawke Government's public opposition to nuclear war-fighting strategies and the joint facilities' involvement with those strategies. Notwithstanding the Government's almost total silence on this issue since then, it would appear that it is tacitly collaborating in a strategy to which it is officially opposed. The Australian people have a right to know the Government's stance on this issue and to what extent they are being unwittingly involved in a globally destabilising strategy. Des Ball's 1987 study on Nurrungar reveals that a massive database on the boost phase characteristics of Soviet missile launchers was handed to the US Strategic Defense Initiative-or Star Wars-Organisation in 1983, and it is almost certainly the case that data is still being collected and being handed to the SDIO. Australia is, therefore, still involved with US SDI research, to which the Prime Minister has publicly expressed his opposition. In 1985 he said that SDI `is not an initiative as far as the Australian Government is concerned that receives our endorsement'. Furthermore, Prime Minister Hawke also said that he had been given an unqualified assurance by Secretary of Defense, Caspar Weinberger, that none of the joint facilities had any role in the research undertaken under SDI.

The Prime Minister has now finally acknowledged Pine Gap as an intelligence data collection facility; in other words, a spy base whose major role is espionage. We in the peace movement have known that for a very long time. The facility is run by the Central Intelligence Agency and successive American officers in charge of Pine Gap have been senior officers of the CIA. Its highly sensitive electronic espionage activities are shrouded in secrecy, and under the present agreement will continue to be shrouded in secrecy. The Prime Minister stated yesterday that the intelligence collected at Pine Gap contributes importantly to the verification of arms control and disarmament agreements, which is vital to the arms control process, through the interception of missile telemetric data-that is, the radio signals transmitted by a rocket during its flight.

However, as other speakers today have noted, it has been estimated that only 40 per cent of Pine Gap's time is spent on verification, and Professor Ball has said that the use of the ryholite signals intelligence (SIGINT) satellites for verification was almost an afterthought. Pine Gap is not the only means available to the United States for the interception of telemetric data. The primary role of Pine Gap is not arms control verification but electronic spying. Pine Gap's most important role is in the processing of information gathered by the SIGINT satellites and transmitting that information to the United States. The facility is able to intercept telephonic and radio-microwave communication from the Soviet Union and China, as well as elsewhere in the world, and is involved in CIA covert satellite communications programs.

Even in respect of this intelligence gathering and claims that Pine Gap is essential to Australia's intelligence, we might ask how much of the intelligence relationship between the United States and Australia is dependent on the joint facilities and how much of the intelligence that comes through the joint facilities is made available to Australia. We do not know. Furthermore, we should ask what control Australia has over the use to which the spy facilities are put. It is reported, for example, that in 1984-85 Pine Gap was used by the Americans to spy on Greece. I am sure that Mr Hawke's luncheon guest of today, Mr Christos Sartzetakis, would not be pleased if this were to happen again. I would certainly concur that verification is an important part of the process of arms control as a first step in the process of disarmament. But Australia has verification specialists of its own and I would argue that, if Pine Gap is an essential verification facility, it should be only that and it should be staffed solely by Australians as part of an international monitoring and verification system. We have scientists here in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and in the universities who are specialists in image and signal processing, aperture synthesis radar and seismological reporting.
The joint facilities increase the likelihood of Australia being a nuclear target. In March 1978 the Director of Scientific and Technical Intelligence of the Joint Intelligence Organisation stated:
We cannot determine the priorities the USSR attaches to targets in Australia, but joint US-Australian facilities would probably rank high.

The situation has not changed since then. In 1984 the Prime Minister admitted in a speech to the House of Representatives that hosting the facilities does bring with it some degree of added risk of nuclear attack. In fact, the Government has assessed this risk as being so high that the Natural Disasters Organisation is already preparing evacuation plans for Pine Gap, North West Cape and Nurrungar. The presence of United States controlled facilities continues to act against the development of an independent and self-reliant foreign policy. They make it difficult for any Australian government to move to extricate Australian policy from association with and dependence upon the United States. Futhermore, it makes more difficult the development of initiatives for regional cooperation when our Pacific and Asian neighbours are reluctant to enter into greater cooperative relationships with us while Australia hosts US ground stations from which the US may spy on the internal affairs of those neighbours. Removal of US installations would not only remove a major obstacle to greater regional cooperation but would also allow Australia to pursue a much more independent foreign policy.

One should ask whether the Australian Government is able to guarantee to the Australian people that it is fully apprised of all the operational, technical and strategic details of each of the facilities to ensure that Australian interests are not compromised. Earlier Prime Ministers admitted that they did not know the full story about the functions of Pine Gap and Nurrungar. Is Mr Hawke able to convince the Australian public that he and his Government are fully aware of all details of these installations and that they have effective political control over their operation and maintenance?

Mr Beazley indicated this morning in a radio interview that the Government had a distinct view that Australian issues of sovereignty were important and that those views were blended with the Government's favourable attitude towards the joint facilities to produce the agreements which we are debating now. I can only say that, if this represents the Government's interpretation of the interests of Australian sovereignty, Mr Beazley should consult his dictionary in a little more depth. The extension of the leases on these facilities perpetuates the derogation of Australian sovereignty to a superpower whose political and strategic interests are not and should not become those of Australia.

In his 1984 speech, the Prime Minister also indicated that the United States Administration had been consulted on his statement about Pine Gap and Nurrungar and had agreed to it being issued. I wonder whether yesterday's statement was also cleared by the US Administration. Surely this brings the United States influence in respect of the so-called joint facilities into the very heart of Australian democracy and sovereignty-the parliamentary system.

In closing, I wish to say that the Australian public has a fundamental right to be told as much as possible about the purposes and functions of these installations. There should be an open and informed debate and we should be told what is involved in the bases, what programs the bases are part of, what sort of information is being provided to the United States, what the consequences of that involvement are to Australia, and what the implications are for the questions of global stability and nuclear war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too rise to speak on the parliamentary statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the joint defence facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar, which was delivered yesterday, 22 November. Mr Hawke said in his statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The changes we are making reflect the commitment of both governments to maintaining and strengthening our long standing partnership of these joint facilities . . . On 6 June 1985 in this place I made the first detailed public statement about the roles of the facilities . . . My remarks today, which will in some respect go beyond that earlier statement, are made with the same conviction.
But in fact very little information is being made available to the Australian public.

Mr Geoff Pryor, a very talented cartoonist for the Canberra Times, said it all this morning in a cartoon captioned `Mr Hawke reveals all'. What we see in that cartoon is a familiar white dome labelled `Pine Gap' that is lifted to reveal underneath yet another white dome. The most interesting revelation is how much obfuscation and disinformation have been provided by Government speakers in earlier debates and in answers to questions. I would like to compare the remarks made by Senator Collins on 21 October 1987 with those of the Prime Minister yesterday. Senator Collins, in talking about the joint facilities, said:
The personnel who run the bases are divided about half and half; there are about 250 Australian personnel and about 250 American personnel . . . It is in truth a joint facility . . .
I would like to compare that with what the Prime Minister said yesterday in his statement. He said:

Whereas only a handful of Australian Government personnel was directly involved in the central work of the facility in the 1970s and early 1980s-contributing less than 10 per cent of the staff there-the proportion is scheduled to rise to about 30 per cent over the next two or three years.

That tells a somewhat different story from that which was told by Senator Collins. In fact, the Prime Minister's statement contains little that was new to informed newspaper readers. It tacitly acknowledges the previous withholding of information. It also acknowledges a lack of Australian control. The Prime Minister said in respect of Nurrungar:

Australians constitute some 40 per cent of the staff in the key operational areas, and will now take a role in management with the appointment of the senior Australian officer there as deputy commander. Like his counterpart at Pine Gap, he will share responsibility with the commander for the management of the station and its physical security.

So increased Australian control is promised and there are to be new Australian deputy commanders at Pine Gap and Nurrungar. These officers will merely share responsibility for the management of the station and its physical security. In fact, that is like being promoted from janitor to night watchman.

The real purpose of the `facilities' is still nothing to do with Australia, unless Australia is to be part of US nuclear war fighting strategies. Only if this is the case are the facilities in any way `joint'. We reject the subordination of Australia to foreign bases, for that is what they are. More importantly, it is foreign domination of our foreign policy. It is dangerous and humiliating for Australia to be forced to accept the nuclear policy of another country. It is interesting to note what John Howard had to say about Mr Hawke in 1976. He said of the Prime Minister:

. . . he signed a joint statement, along with many other people identified with the left wing of politics, in which he warned against foreign military bases on our soil as being detrimental to our safety, and called for an independent and non-aligned Australia.
Why is it that Mr Hawke is now so pleased to see us fundamentally under United States control? The Prime Minister said only yesterday:
The Government intends that honourable members will have an opportunity to debate this statement.

Why then was this new agreement with the US signed last week? The Government has locked Australia into another 10 years of being a nuclear target on behalf of someone else and then it has the gall to permit us to debate it. Why were we not allowed to debate it before the signing of the agreement? Tonight Senator Vallentine made us aware, as have other senators, that polls show an increasing antagonism to bases and ship visits. They show that 58 per cent of young people and 50 per cent of all Australian women oppose these bases.

The Prime Minister claims to have told us all that it is good for us. He has said that everything has been done in the name of `verification'. But there is hardly any mention in the statement of deterrence. Does that mean that deterrence, which was always implausible, is now unfashionable amongst the hawks? What has he told us? He has told us that Nurrungar is a groundstation used for controlling satellites in the United States defence support program. Nurrungar, says the Prime Minister, plays a `quite fundamental role in preventing nuclear war'. He tells us that Pine Gap is a satellite groundstation whose function is to collect intelligence data. He claims that intelligence collected at Pine Gap contributes importantly to the verification of arms control and disarmament agreements. The Prime Minister suggested that this time he was going to reveal to the Australian people the truth about the bases.

I remind the Senate that the Australian Government has a long and dishonourable tradition-in the worst tradition, incidentally, of the United States Government-of telling untruths, half-truths and deliberate distortions of the truth about the bases. In June 1984, Mr Hawke `revealed all'; that is, he told the Parliament the whole truth and nothing but the truth. He said that they were not military bases but that they were there just for the benign purpose of nuclear test ban monitoring and non-proliferation. But let me quote what was said by another Prime Minister of Australia in a speech recorded on pages 1519 to 1523 of Hansard of 4 May 1977. Gough Whitlam said:

There is increasing and profoundly disturbing evidence that foreign espionage and intelligence activities are being practised in Australia on a large scale . . . it cannot be ignored by Parliament. The manipulation of unions, the financing of political parties, the deception over the CIA, and the activities of foreign installations on our soil all affect Australia's independence and sovereignty.

So what has changed? We have one change-we now have a Prime Minister, also from the Australian Labor Party, who does not query the covert activities on Australia's soil and in Australia's skies but makes them welcome and attempts by blandishment and bluster to con the Australian people into believing that all is well.

However, the bases are not benign and they are not primarily concerned with the peace of the world. The bases are part of the nuclear strategy of the United States. There is no need for me to go through the familiar history of the perception of nuclear war and its horrible acronyms: from missile gaps to SDI-strategic defence initiative to MAD-mutual assured destruction. We are now in the dubious and frightening phase of preparation for a winnable nuclear war. No sane person believes that there would be such a thing. Nuclear wars have no winners, yet we know that the strategic planners of the Pentagon and-we do not know but we can guess-the nuclear war planners of the Soviet Union are working on the scenario of a winnable nuclear war. However, the Prime Minister did not mention this in his statement.

We have known since the 1970s that Pine Gap has been a `facility' of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), as Senator Dunn mentioned earlier. The Prime Minister failed to mention that the targets which are observed by the Pine Gap satellites are chosen and approved by the United States National Reconnaissance Office and approved by the National Reconnaissance Executive Committee, which is chaired by the Director of the CIA. None of the Committee members are Australians or have any allegiance or responsibility towards Australia. The personnel involved, the satellites and the bases themselves serve the purposes of United States nuclear strategists.

Like nuclear warships in our harbours the bases are themselves prime nuclear targets, and that is acknowledged. The best security for Australia lies in removing the bases. The bases attract the attention of the very nuclear weapons which the Prime Minister tells us they will protect us from. If the bases are really about verification, we should either run them ourselves or hand them over to, say, the United Nations to be used for international peacekeeping

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement made yesterday in the House of Representatives by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, with regard to the joint facilities that Australia has developed with the United States of America is to be welcomed, even if it represents for the Prime Minister a belated conversion to the correct viewpoint. It is well and truly worth remembering that it was one R. J. L. Hawke who, along with the present Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mrs Child, and the Labor member for Hughes, Mr Tickner, and the Labor member for Sydney, Mr Baldwin, appended signatures to an anti-ANZUS and anti-joint facilities advertisement in the National Times of September 1976. I was hoping that when I participated in this debate this evening Senator Gietzelt would also be present because he also signed that advertisement.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the only member of the Australian Labor Party who has spoken in this chamber on this very important issue was the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, who spoke for 54 seconds at the commencement of the debate this evening. He tabled the Prime Minister's report and he asked that the Prime Minister's speech yesterday in the House of Representatives be incorporated. How pathetic that the Government of this nation, on this issue, which is of paramount importance, has the audacity to take only 54 seconds in this Senate on such a very important issue. I think it shows the commitment of Labor members to such an important issue, and we saw that in the press today where obviously different factions within the Labor Party have taken particular views on this issue.

The position in the statement made by the Prime Minister yesterday is supported by the Opposition and, in particular, the conclusion of the 10-year non-terminable periods for both Pine Gap and Nurrungar, with three-year periods of notice required, is most welcome. The extension plus the lengthy notice period protects these important facilities against the possible lunacy of some future Labor regime which might revert to the traditional anti-American and anti-alliance stance that we have come to expect from much of the Labor Party. Today, most heirs to that position are to be found in the Australian Democrats and the Independent senators Vallentine and Dunn. Doubtlessly, they will, as they have done already, entertain the Senate with their standard `why the bases must go' speeches.

We heard tonight from Senator Vallentine a whole reef of claims that public opinion was shifting, that public opinion had changed and that it was standing solidly behind the viewpoint that she has been peddling around Australia for some five years or so. However, she did not give any data on which to base the claim that there is a shift in public opinion on foreign bases. Where is the basis for her claim? No doubt it is some dubious and specially contextured public opinion that is being put forward by Senator Vallentine and the peace movement, rather like putting out a public opinion poll with questions asked in such a way that the answers that flow are predictable. I am sure that, if we were to put out a similar public opinion poll asking the people of Australia how they would reflect on ANZUS and the relationships and how they felt that Australian and American interests ought to be reconciled, we would have a stable majority well and truly in favour of that particular viewpoint.

The fact is that the bases-more correctly called the joint facilities-are not going anywhere, and Senators Vallentine and Dunn will have to wear that. They are here, they are permanent. I would hope that the fact that there is now a firm contract-a 10-year commitment with a 3-year expiry clause at the end of it-guarantees us at least 13 years without the necessity for this particular argument. It is going to make it very difficult for Senators Vallentine and Dunn to survive politically anywhere for 13 years let alone continue with the trite arguments that they have been putting forward. We are indeed fortunate that the joint facilities are here to stay. They not only provide concrete evidence of our continued commitment to the American alliance but also in their own right play an important part in the maintenance of world peace.

As the Prime Minister, with the consent of our American friends, has now revealed, the Nurrungar facility is an important part of the defence support program early warning satellite system. Early warning of nuclear attack is a vital component of any deterrent strategy, and the objective of American nuclear deterrent strategy is to ensure that a nuclear war is never fought-to deter the Soviets and thereby maintain peace. Thus, Nurrungar helps maintain the world nuclear peace and is deserving of our support.

Pine Gap, for its part, we now know makes a significant contribution to the West's strategic intelligence gathering capabilities. Just as early warning is vital, so the collection of strategic intelligence is necessary to preserve a stable regime of balance between the superpowers. Good intelligence is an important confidence building measure: if the superpowers know what is going on, they are less likely to make errors leading to unintended nuclear exchanges.

It is also important to note the increasing participation of Australians at the senior levels of control in both facilities. There has been an Australian deputy commander at North West Cape since 1974 and now there are to be Australians in equivalent positions both at Nurrungar and Pine Gap. This fact, coupled with the increases in Australian numbers at the upper levels of both facilities, must surely give the lie to those who still claim that these are US bases and not genuinely joint facilities. I am proud to represent the Northern Territory in this place. I am very much aware of the importance of Pine Gap to the town of Alice Springs. The economic and the social interrelationship is genuine and it is appreciated. There are some 460 staff at Pine Gap. I am sure that with the extended families and people working in associated service industries, there are much more than 2,000 people together making this vital contribution to the central Australian community.

The only people that stand out in the crowd are the loonies-the people that drift in and out to demonstrate against Pine Gap. They are the people such as Senator Vallentine who make show cases of themselves by tying themselves to fences and trying to climb into Pine Gap in order to get into the newspapers through the exposure of putting taxpayers to the expense of having to put them in gaol. What an insult to the taxpayers of Australia that we have a representative in this Senate who carries on in such a stupid and idiotic manner to put such a view point across in this community. To have Senators Vallentine and Dunn and a number of Australian Democrat senators come in here and put up pappy, pointless and often stupid arguments annoys most of the people in the Northern Territory. They cannot understand why these people cannot express themselves properly in all of the proper forums.

The statement yesterday by the Prime Minister shows that at the moment his views are in control of the Labor Party's decision making processes, but it would be a foolish person who thought that the Labor Party might not one day come again under left wing control. By contrast, the conservative parties have never wavered in their support for the alliance with America or for the joint facilities. This is something the people should always bear in mind when evaluating the present position of the Labor Party on these important issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak ever so briefly on the parliamentary statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the joint defence facilities. Of course, it comes as no surprise to us that the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine and Senator Dunn condemn the very sensible agreement and negotiations. Their view is that there should be no such bases in Australia at any price. If they had their way they would impose and inflict upon the Australian community unilateral disarmament. From my observations it seems that these people think they have a mortgage on concern for peace in spite of the truth, of course.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two groups. There are those that are essentially opposed to the joint facilities. They believe in unilateral disarmament. They are inevitably anti-American in their outlook and muted in their criticism of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Then there are those other fellow travellers who are seduced, more than anything else I suspect sadly out of ignorance, into the view that the reduction of any facilities means an increase in peace. What enrages me more than anything else is that there are those who claim to be part of the peace movement-whatever the peace movement is, the name in itself is outlandish because it claims a mortgage on a concern for peace.

If one reflects, as Senator Tambling did, upon their conduct in recent times one sees that, in their case, their peace comes at the price of disruption for everybody else. That does not seem to matter to Senator Vallentine who causes the distraction of 30 police officers from their normal functions and duties in Western Australia to have to attend to her misbehaviour at Fremantle wharf and finally arrest her and take her away. It does not seem to worry her that while those 30 policemen were distracted from their normal duties there were five sexual assaults in one day in Western Australia, several hundred break and enters, several embezzlements, hundreds of thefts and probably a number of fatal motor car accidents.

There is no question that there is a shortage of police in Western Australia. The police force is undermanned. But to exacerbate that problem, the police find themselves having to go down to Fremantle wharf to protect ordinary decent Australian citizens who go to that wharf to welcome the Americans, the French, the Italians or the British and to protect those people from the conduct of the demonstrators who then have the cheek to tell us that they are there for peace. They are not for peace; they are for disruption; they are for chaos; they are for breaking the law. The peace they want is a peace that suits them-a peace at any price for them, but nobody else's peace.

What enrages me is that by and large those people know what they are calling for when they call for unilateral disarmament. They know what they are doing when they offer up their glib slogans. The sadness is that they seduce so many other decent people into believing that their cause has some virtue. Of course, from the outset it has no integrity, never mind virtue. It is those people that, for their own perverted causes, their own perverted reasons, perhaps for the primeval arousal of demonstrations, risk and jeopardise the security and safety of ordinary Australian citizens and perhaps all people of the world. I find their conduct hypocritical, sanctimonious and self-righteous. I cannot help but observe that there was deafening silence in this Parliament from these people when the most substantial agreement entered into in modern time in respect to warfare was concluded. The intermediate-range nuclear force agreement for the first time removed one class of nuclear weapons. Had they risen in integrity, they would have been compelled to observe that it was the location of American missiles in Western Europe that caused the Soviet Union to withdraw its SS20 missiles. For the first time the Soviet Union was threatened, and those peace people would have had to acknowledge that the ratbags, the rabble and the deviants that occupied Greenham Common, for instance, for months and months suddenly found themselves to be without a cause.

It was the location of the American missiles at Greenham Common which finally brought the Soviets to the negotiating table, and they had to agree to the intermediate nuclear forces agreement. That was but the beginning of a scaling-down of nuclear weapons in the world. It was the beginning of agreements which would include verification and the resurrection of the strategic arms reduction talks. This was all brought about by the Americans' determination to ensure that peace would be brought about by force and strength-not by weakness, not by capitulation, and least of all by unilateral disarmament, as these peace people would have us undertake. The reason we heard nothing when the most substantial agreement had been entered into was that the people would have had to concede that the very premise of their arguments was wrong. They knew they were wrong. They did not have the decency, integrity or honesty to stand up and say, `We were wrong. Peace comes through strength, not though weakness'. They were absolutely silent on that agreement, and to me that was a statement of their conduct.

Now we have it that these people would have removed from Australian soil Nurrungar, Pine Gap and the North West Cape facilities. It ought to be understood that those facilities are not there to serve the singular interests, the selfish or sectional interests, of the United States. The facilities are there because Australian governments, both past and present, have wanted them there-as they will presumably want them in the future-and because the overwhelming majority of ordinary, decent Australian people want security and certainty for their future, not weakness and unilateral disarmament which totally destabilises the balance of competing forces in this world.

As I have been moved to ask before, why is it that, whenever there is a debate in this Parliament on the question of nuclear forces, the criticisms that invariably come from the Australian Democrats, from Senator Vallentine-if she is here and not in gaol, in New Zealand, in the United States, disrupting the Western Australian State Parliament, or doing other things-and from Senator Dunn are directed exclusively towards the United States? I cannot remember the last time I heard a criticism of the Soviet Union. When have we ever been given a notice of motion condemning the Soviet Union for using the facilities at Cam Ranh Bay? I do not believe that that issue has been raised once in this Parliament, and I suspect that it will not be. These people are essentially anti-American and, in many respects, anti-Australian. They would have these bases removed.

Let us look at what these bases do. I refer to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on disarmament and arms control, of which I was one of the authors. The Democrats were invited to appear before and give evidence to that Committee. However, they were conspicuous by their absence. Senator Chipp, as he then was, then Leader of the Australian Democrats, wrote to the Committee and was invited unanimously to appear before the Committee to give evidence and be questioned by those sitting on the committee as to the veracity of his claims and in search of an understanding of his intentions. He was invited not once but on several occasions, but the Democrats, to use bad English, never showed up. When their integrity was on the line, they could not be found. However, let me refer in part to the description of Pine Gap. The report states:

It has high frequency communications to the American Base at Clarke Field in the Philippines, a communications link to the Australian Department of Defence in Canberra and to satellite ground stations . . . which were installed in 1973 and 1980 respectively and connecting to the U.S. DSCS. It has extensive computing facilities and is manned and operated by American and Australian personnel (there are presently some 230 U.S. personnel on the base) . . . its major role is to operate as a ground station for the signals intelligence satellite program known as Rhyolite. The facility is also thought to be used as a receiving and control station-
and we now know that to be the case-

for orbiting photographic reconnaissance and electronic intelligence satellites that are operated by the Central Intelligence Agency. The functions of these satellites are described in more detail below.

Those details are contained in the report, for those honourable senators who wish to read them. Of course, Nurrungar is operated under the control of the United States Air Force. I think it was Senator Hill who touched on the fact that it is our Government, or at least the Labor Government-I claim no ownership of it-that is so reluctant to provide information to the Australian people, which, by and large, is readily available to the United States. The report indicates:

Recent budget estimates which were provided to the Appropriations Committee of the United States' House of Representatives, and declassified research and development summaries, indicate that Nurrungar is part of the United States Defense Support Program (DSP)--
which, of course, we now know-

or Program Code 647. The DSP is an on-going classified space program consisting of two ground control and readout stations located at Nurrungar and Colorado in the United States that receive data from early warning satellites, process the data and automatically present it to the U.S. National Command Authorities and military commanders for decision-making purposes. The DSP satellites are also thought to carry nuclear detonation detection equipment that can be used to monitor and gather specific data on Soviet, Chinese and French nuclear tests.

In other words, the base has the capacity to gather information on the activities of nations that are involved in nuclear arms. I think that, by any measure, any base or facility that monitors activities and ensures that agreements are complied with, which by any measure is essential to the entering of any agreement, can only be of value to this country and to the Western world and give legitimacy to agreements entered into. I think it was the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who had the sense, with his born-again enlightenment after he managed to discharge some of the bigotry baggage that he brought into this Parliament, to concede that a major justification for retaining the joint facilities in Australia is that they contribute to international stability by helping to deter nuclear war.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator CRICHTON-BROWNE

TALK.START.PARA: —The removal or substantial downgrading of the functions of the bases can only hinder the efforts of the United States to maintain an effective and stable deterrence and it would therefore only increase the risk of nuclear conflict. I ask: how can there be any compelling logic for the removal of a base whose essential function is to provide deterrence? What is the motive, the reason or the commonsense? I have sought to probe the minds of these people to begin to discover if there is any logical sequence in their thinking, but I have failed. There seems to be no logical conclusion. I am even prepared to put aside their prejudices and their bigotry, but still I have to say there is no logic in why they do not want a deterrence, why they do not want stability in agreements. Of course the joint facilities contribute to global stability in a number of ways. Firstly, the signals monitoring and early warning functions of Pine Gap and Nurrungar make it impossible for the Soviet Union to launch a surprise nuclear attack against the United States without risking detection and subsequent retaliation against Soviet cities. I would have thought that would be a reasonable ground for having such a facility. It prevents the Soviet Union from launching a surprise first strike against the United States and its facilities. In other words, the bases provide the United States with a retaliatory capacity which, in itself, is a deterrence to the Soviet Union, and therefore we have stability; quod erat demonstrandum. Yet the Australian Democrats tell us that we ought to be destabilising this agreement. I find that absolutely amazing.

INTERJECT.PARA: The retaliatory forces of the United States include, of course, the submarine launched ballistic missiles, the SLBMs as they are called, which are located in the Pacific and Indian oceans. These forces by and large are almost exclusively immune to a pre-emptive Soviet strike. For that reason only a very limited number of submarines are needed to wreak unacceptable damage on the Soviet Union in the event that it strikes first.

So by providing secure and reliable communications for the ballistic missile equipped nuclear powered submarine fleet, the North West Cape base, for instance, is providing a stabilising contribution to the global balance by enhancing basic deterrence. The satellite surveillance and early warning systems which operate through Pine Gap and Nurrungar also, of course, contribute overall to stability by reducing uncertainty about the Soviet Union's strategic weapons programs and deployments, thereby reducing anxiety about its intentions and alleviating pressures on the part of the United States to maintain its forces at a high alert status. So by having those capacities and having the intelligence and the knowledge of the activities of the Soviet Union, the Americans, our allies-in spite of the protestations of the Democrats-can make a measured and balanced response to the conduct, activities and initiatives of the Soviet Union. It means that it is not required to maintain its forces at a high alert status or perhaps to carry out a pre-emptive strike during a period of tension or crisis. In other words, the intelligence the Americans gather through these bases provides them with an opportunity to have a real understanding of what the Soviets are doing, and ensures in that way that they will not overreact, but nor will they underreact.

It is Nurrungar in particular which plays the key role in providing an early warning of ballistic missile attacks on the United States, and that is its function. I have referred also to the functioning and the purpose of Pine Gap and, whilst it is not necessarily relevant to this statement, to the function of the North West Cape base. So there is an essential and I would have thought logically compelling reason for these three bases, these three facilities, yet as I say the Democrats would have us remove them. The Democrats and Senator Vallentine claim that they are not unilateralists in terms of disarmament, but of course every time we hear their arguments we realise that they are. They are joined by this happy band of people that talks about using these facilities as bargaining chips with the United States in respect of trade matters. That is an absolutely absurd proposition because we all ought to understand, as I said at the outset, that the bases are not in Australia for the exclusive benefit of the Americans; they are here for our benefit, for our protection and to provide certainty and security for us. In so doing they provide security and certainty for the whole world because, as I say, as long as they provide deterrence they prevent the likelihood of a nuclear war and in many respects they reduce the threshold.

I conclude by saying that we support the argeement that has been entered into and the negotiations which have taken place. I am of the view that more can be said by this Government in respect of the facilities. Already a great deal more is known, there is a great deal on the record and there is a great deal contained in the disarmament and arms control document which we wrote. If the Government had the courage to put aside the inhibitions of the bureaucrats about providing further information, I suspect it would create more confidence in the Australian people and more certainty and less doubt in their minds. In that way it would dampen the mystique, the mischief and the trouble that the Democrats and Senator Vallentine are able to cause by arguing behind a fog of confusion. I say to anybody in this alleged peace movement that he or she is doing himself or herself and the Australian people a grave disservice by carrying, as I said earlier, the baggage of bigotry around for whatever purpose.

I find it fascinating that these people call themselves the peace movement. What is the peace movement? These people seem to believe they have a special mortgage on peace. Those in that group who genuinely believe in peace are no different to the vast majority of Australians. In fact when I listen to these people I find their debates the most intellectually barren that we hear in this chamber, because all thinking, sensible and reasonable Australians-of course that culls out some in this chamber-want peace. All we are arguing about is in which direction we go and whether we achieve peace by falling down in an obsequious way, by unilateral disarmament, or whether we achieve peace by strength in the way that Western Europe did not do prior to the Second World War but, as I said before, in the way that the Americans, the British, the Germans and the French did, by agreeing to the location of nuclear weapons on their shores and in their territory, which ultimately caused the Soviets to come to the negotiating table and remove their threatening SS20s and SS22s, which could have struck into the heart of Western Europe in 20 minutes. At that point in time, when there was no threat to them, they refused to move their missiles. The moment they were confronted by missiles from the United States and Western Europe, missiles which they claim could enter their airspace in four minutes flying time, they very quickly found a compelling necessity to enter into negotiations to remove their missiles. As I say, that is peace through strength. That is the direction that this Party supports, and I believe that that has the support of the vast majority of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there has been agreement that we do not interject on each other and call points of order. I must say that I had great difficulty in restraining myself while Senator Crichton-Browne was speaking, because he used a great number of pejorative epithets which certainly do not, and should not, be applied to those people who take a different path to peace. For somebody who, in his own words, professes to be pursuing a path to peace, his time was more than 50 per cent spent on attacking those who take a different point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of things said by Senator Crichton-Browne also do not follow and were misstatements of fact. Had he listened to what Senator Jenkins had to say, he would have realised that she was certainly not advocating unilateral disarmament. What she was advocating-and what I am certainly advocating-is non-nuclear armed neutrality; that is, to dissociate ourselves from any alliance with any country and to be armed in a non-nuclear way so that we are capable of defending ourselves. That is certainly quite different from unilateral disarmament.

Senator Crichton-Browne also said that he saw nothing wrong with bases which could act as early warning devices. I see nothing wrong with bases that can act as early warning devices either, except when they are tied in with one of the major potential superpower protagonists in an all-out nuclear conflict. That is what is wrong with them. There is nothing wrong with the function of the base as such, if it were under Australian control or, as Senator Jenkins pointed out, under the control of the United Nations. However, precisely because it is an early warning device, it becomes a nuclear target in the event of a nuclear exchange when that early warning device is unilaterally linked in with one of the potential major protagonists.
