That is the reason that those of us in the Australian Democrats-and I think I can speak for Senator Vallentine and Senator Dunn-are concerned about that association.

I want to develop the argument as to why we should not support these bases under substantial American control on Australian soil and why we would be much better off, both in terms of peace and in terms of our own defence, if we pursued a policy of armed neutrality based on non-nuclear weapons. Some time ago, when I was first a member of the Senate, I asked a question of Senator Richardson regarding electromagnetic pulse and whether he had any knowledge of this phenomenon. He indicated in his answer that he had no knowledge at all of this phenomenon. If that is extended to other senators, one can assume that perhaps they do not understand one of the basic reasons why a nuclear exchange is likely to escalate into all-out nuclear war extremely rapidly.

When a nuclear weapon is exploded, particularly if that nuclear weapon is exploded high in the atmosphere-perhaps some 200 kilometres above the earth over central Australia-there is a high level pulse of electromagnetic energy which achieves many thousands of volts per metre and which has the effect of knocking out any unprotected communication systems, particularly those which at any point involve the user of transistors. For instance, a single nuclear explosion at about 200 kilometres over Alice Springs would effectively knock out most of the electronic ignition systems in motor cars, would knock out electricity supply systems throughout the whole of Australia, would knock out the telephone system, and would knock out radio and television communications. In fact, it would very rapidly bring the country to a standstill.

For this reason the Americans and, I dare say, the Russians are aware of the fact that one nuclear explosion so placed could effectively prevent communication between the central control facility and the ability to launch retaliatory weapons. It is for that reason, that very clear reason, that at the first warning that a nuclear weapon is on its way the opposite side, whichever that be-whether it be the US or Russia-would tend to want to launch every single nuclear rocket that was available to it simply because, if those weapons were not off the ground, there would be a strong possibility that the retaliatory capability would be lost. In other words, it is a principle of launch on warning. That is the system under which both sides are operating.

In the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and elsewhere we find words to the effect that, because of the enormity of destruction which would follow a nuclear exchange, no nation would sensibly launch a nuclear attack. However, as we all know, the possibility of nuclear attack by accident or the possibility that computers become confused into believing that a nuclear attack is on its way is a far more likely scenario. Therefore, the possibility of a nuclear war becomes considerable. The possibility that that nuclear war would escalate rapidly into wholesale nuclear war is also very considerable. As we all know, the consequences of an all-out exchange would be a nuclear winter in which those who started the interchange would be as badly affected in the long run as those who suffered the immediate attack.

Of course, the facilities that we are discussing this evening are targets, in the event of any threat. Precisely because Pine Gap is an early warning facility and because it is under the control of the Americans, in the event of the Russians getting itchy fingers it would be the first target. Of course, those rockets would not be sent from Russia with a long trajectory; they would be sent from submarines immediately offshore with a very short trajectory. So we can be absolutely assured that, in the event of any suggestion of nuclear exchange, Pine Gap will be a prime target. We can also be assured that contemplated nuclear war is no defence because of nuclear winter.

It is also a fact that the Americans have substantially nuclearised their military forces. It follows from that that for Australia to depend on the US for defence is to depend on a defence which is no defence. In other words, we have a Clayton's defence system because we have come to rely so heavily on the Americans. It is for that reason that Australia would be in a much better position if it were to forgo the American military alliance. That is not to say that the Australian Democrats hate the Americans; that is not the situation at all. It is to say that we can enter into all sorts of relationships with the Americans, other than military ones. It is to say that this country would be better defended with a non-nuclear system which was developed totally within this country; a system of defence only-not a system of offence-a system which would be sufficiently strong to deter any aggressor and one which could not be used to attack any of our neighbours.

I pose for Government and Opposition members the scenario that Indonesia, for instance, might at some stage launch a non-nuclear attack against Australia. What would be the United States's response? I suggest that the US would not come to our aid for two reasons: firstly, because the US is also an ally of Indonesia and, secondly, because the US, if it got into any large scale conflagration eventually, would have to depend on the use of nuclear weapons, which it would not want to do. For that reason it is very unlikely that the presence of these bases poses any reasonable assurance to Australia that we would get any help with our defence in the only way that has any meaning.

Therefore, I believe that these bases should not persist on Australian soil as joint facilities. If they serve a useful function, by all means retain them. But they should be taken over by Australia and the information which they provide in terms of early warnings should be made available to all countries without fear or favour, and certainly not selectively to one side or the other. I would object as much to Russian bases on Australian soil as I do to American, English or any other bases. Contrary to what Senator Crichton-Browne said, if he looks at the record he will see that I have a long history of objecting to the United Kingdom presence in Australia exploding nuclear weapons at Maralinga, which has brought upon this country extremely long term and serious consequences.

In conclusion, the Australian Democrats are certainly not unilateral disarmament protagonists. We believe in a non-nuclear defence system which is based in Australia and on Australia, and which does not link Australia into military alliances with any other country, whether it be on the east or the west of the Iron Curtain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice the lateness of the hour and I do not wish to detain the Senate much longer, but I wish to say at least a few words on this important matter. I listened to the contributions of Senators Tambling, Crichton-Browne and Coulter. While I congratulate my colleagues Senator Tambling and Senator Crichton-Browne on their very good contributions to this debate and the mass of material that they have produced I must say that, listening to Senator Coulter, I was saddened by the fact that he clearly-although I believe him to be a man of goodwill-does not seem to understand the need for Australia to have friendships, alliances. He does not seem to understand that we do not achieve friendships simply by saying, `I am a friend'. There is a job involved in having friendships and friendships are a two-way street.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that Senator Coulter would be perfectly happy to have the benefits of our allies' technology and their abilities to which we currently have access in these joint facilities. In the last moments of his speech he made it quite clear that he would be happy to have these abilities if they were nothing to do with any of our friends and that we had them entirely to ourselves. That is a very selfish way of looking at the protection of the world, I would have thought, and the ability of Western nations to preserve peace, which they have managed to do pretty successfully over the last 40 years without Senator Coulter's help or the help of the peace movement. It has not been by a repetition of the behaviour of the world's nations in the 1930s; it has been by learning from the lessons of those times and by making sure that democracies are well protected from aggression.

I now move on to matters of some substance and record my pleasure at the statement put down in the other House yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. In response to the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Mr Howard said:

I can say without any reservations that support for the joint facilities by the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, formerly in government, now in opposition and in future in government, remains completely undiminished.
He went on to say:
The joint facilities have had our invariable and unwavering support because of the contribution they have made to the world wide Western strategic defence network.

Those are the sentiments of the Opposition, strongly stated and constant. They have not changed. Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the fact that although the Prime Minister of Australia has now seen the light in these matters, he once held very different views. We can all make mistakes and I am very glad to see that he has seen the light. The Opposition, formerly the government, has consistently held the view that we should strongly support and facilitate these joint facilities. I notice that some of our colleagues who represent the peace movement seem committed to calling them bases. It seems to give then some personal inner glow.

The Opposition believes that we cannot be entirely self-reliant. We believe that we need to make a contribution to our friends if we are to get the benefits of their technology. Although aiming for self-reliance, we cannot expect to produce all our own weapons and equipment; nor do we believe that we can rely solely on our own resources for intelligence information. We believe that we cannot command all the technology necessary for our defence. It certainly does not mean that we can abandon cooperation with our friends and allies. We believe that we will always see value for Australia in retaining a commitment to the United States and to allied ship and aircraft visits to Australia, even in circumstances where they may be nuclear powered and armed.
I draw the Senate's attention to the Defence White Paper which the Government brought down last year. Clause 2.9, relating to the joint facilities, stated:

The facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar enhance stability by contributing to verification of arms limitation measures of the United States and the Soviet Union and to timely United States and Australian knowledge of developments that have military significance-including early warning of ballistic missile attack on the United States or its allies. New communications links are being established with the headquarters of the ADF in Canberra to give the Government and its advisers access to data from the facilities immediately.
In other words, it is clearly of immediate benefit to this country. The White Paper also said, in clause 2.11:

The benefits and costs for Australia in co-operating with the United States in the joint defence facilities have been carefully evaluated by the Government. The operations of the joint facilities do not involve derogation from our sovereignty. They serve Australian and US interests.
The White Paper also stated:

Were Australia to cease our co-operation in the joint defence facilities there would only be adverse consequences for international security and higher risk of global war. This would neither serve Australia's interests nor those of the international community generally.

Those are rather awesome words. I am sure that they were not inserted into that document lightly. It is a document which is supported both by the Government and by the Opposition. I think that those who ignore those solemn words do so not only at their own peril but also at the peril of this country.

In the statement put down by the Prime Minister there are a number of matters of some detail. Due to the lateness of the hour I do not intend to canvass them all. I simply draw attention to the increasing involvement of Australians in both the operation and the management of Pine Gap and Nurrungar and the increased opportunity for Australians to take more direct advantage of the capabilities of the facilities for our own purposes than we have been able to do in the past. The ability to have a highly reliable warning of attack in helping to prevent nuclear war by accident is a capability which is, of course, of great importance not just to us but to the world. The Prime Minister also pointed out that Pine Gap's function is to collect intelligence data which supports the national security of both Australia and the United States. The Prime Minister stated:
. . . I think it is clear that nobody seriously committed to peace could argue for their closure.

There is the nub of it. We do have people who claim to be seriously committed to peace arguing not just strenuously but continuously and ad nauseam for their closure. Honourable senators will be aware, as I am, of the long nights we have spent in this place sitting out the adjournment debate while the independent senators who represent the peace movement have given us their views on the need to close these joint facilities. The problem with independent Senators Vallentine and Dunn is that they mouth peace while their policies, if adopted, would leave us vulnerable to aggression. They are false doctrines, in my opinion. They are seductive, they are dangerous and they are attractive, but they are very simplistic. As my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne said, these people have a fixation with things American but, as I mentioned earlier, they are clearly not students of history and they have not learned the lessons of unilateral disarmament. They have not learned that democracies get seduced by attractive doctrines such as theirs where totalitarian states do not. These people, I believe, well meaning though they may be-and I am not always sure of that-in my opinion are a danger to this nation. The monitoring of the arms control and the disarmament agreements is a major contribution to peace: trying to get rid of our friends and diminish Australia's own capabilities is not.
Before I close, I would like to draw attention to the final paragraph of the Prime Minister's statement. He stated:

These agreements confirm my Government's conviction that the joint defence facilities will continue to serve Australia's national interests; that they will continue to reflect the depth and substance of our bilateral strategic relationship with the United States under ANZUS; and that they will continue to play a vital role in preventing nuclear war.

I hope that they will play a vital role in preventing nuclear war, but I draw it to the Senate's attention that it is a great shame that the Government's fine statement relating to the depth and substance of our bilateral strategic relationship with the United States under ANZUS does not extend to other demonstrations of commitment to that relationship.

I refer to the debate on 4 November on my urgency motion relating to the Bicentenary naval visits. Honourable senators will recall that the Government agreed to support my motion on that occasion and Senator Gareth Evans, speaking for the Government, said that the Government was prepared to take all the measures necessary and appropriate to solve future problems relating to such ship visits. I then asked of Senator Evans, `Well then, will you adopt my private member's Bill relating to the visit of nuclear-powered warships?'. Senator Evans said no, he would not do that. I asked him what legislative base he was prepared to have and he said that he believed that an approach based on necessary logistic support for such visits, rather than legislation, was the effective way of preventing a recurrence of the problem which we faced in Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth with our visiting friends from the United States and the United Kingdom. Senator Evans said:
We believe that that approach, rather than legislation, is the effective way of preventing a recurrence of the problem.
When I asked him why, he said:
The reason, as Senator Newman ought to appreciate, is that legislation designed to compel workers to berth ships would be a recipe for confrontation.

In other words, the Government of this country is not prepared to legislate to prevent unions from hijacking our defence and foreign affairs policy; it is not prepared to stop them hijacking the maintenance of our alliances. So while I welcome the statement by the Prime Minister in relation to the joint facilities, I draw the Senate's attention to the Government's inconsistency when it needs to keep our ports open to our allies and it fails to do so. In other words, our allies are welcome in our joint facilities but not in our ports if our left wing unions disapprove of the visits. I conclude by saying that the Opposition is pleased to support the statement put down by the Prime Minister relating to the extension of the agreement on the joint facilities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.07 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 20 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What information is currently obtained by the Federal Government from universities and colleges of advanced education relating to students and staff.
(2) What are the exact questions being asked of universities and colleges relating to students and staff.
(3) What questions were asked of universities and colleges relating to students and staff in: (a) 1984; (b) 1985; (c) 1986; and (d) 1987.
(4) Are extra questions to be asked of institutions of higher education regarding students and staff in 1989; If so, what extra information is to be gathered.
(5) Do institutions of higher education have any choice in supplying information regarding staff and students.
(6) How is the information stored by the Department.
(7) Are identifier numbers tagged on to individual student and staff records.
(8) What use is currently made of the statistics on students and staff gathered by the Department.
(9) What safeguards exist to protect data collected on students and staff.
(10) Are any extra safeguards planned.

(11) Is it true that extra information is being gathered in anticipation of proposals outlined in the Government's `Higher Education' Green Paper; if so, what use is to be made of the information gathered.
(12) What provisions in the Green Paper make it necessary for the Department to gather increased information.

(13) Is it now possible for officers of the Australian Taxation Office or the Department of Finance to gain access to any information on students or staff held by the Department of Employment, Education and Training; if so, what information are they able to gain access to.
(14) What officers in the Department of Employment, Education and Training can gain access to information on students and staff gathered from institutions of higher education.
(15) How many officers does this represent.
(16) What safeguards prevent officers of other Commonwealth departments or bodies from accessing this information.
(17) Is it technically possible for files on individual students and staff to be linked to their actual names.
(18) Is it technically possible to match information on individual students and staff with other records held by the Commonwealth, so as to identify the name of the individuals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth currently collects the following data from higher education institutions in respect of students and staff via the higher education student data collection and the higher education staff statistics collection respectively:
date of birth, sex, student's postcode both for the semester and the permanent home location;
courses in which students are enrolled, basis for admission to such courses, and pattern of attendance (i.e. full-time/part-time and internal/external);
details about prior courses undertaken by students;
information on overseas students and whether the student is a fee-paying student.

As part of the educational profile process institutions have also provided aggregated data in respect of courses offered or to be offered at the institution, details on projected commencements and completions and estimates of student load.
The following information is obtained in respect of full-time and fractional full-time staff.
profile data covering date of birth, sex, classification and term of appointment;

resources data covering details about their current duties, where they are working within the institution, what they are doing in terms of teaching or research or other, together with a measure of the proportion of time devoted to such functions; and
Some aggregated data in respect of groups of staff are also collected. The following types of aggregated data are collected:
resources data in respect of casual staff;
data relating to release for participation in a Professional Experience Program or Outside Studies Program;
commencement and separation data in relation to full-time tenured academic staff; and
data relating to the outside funding of staff resources.

(2) As the collections are computer based, the exact questions relating to students and staff are in the form of data elements. Copies of the Data Element Dictionary for each of the collections referred to above have been provided to Senator Teague.

(3) Students-Prior to 1987 the data for colleges was provided in aggregate on forms. To enable institutions to provide accurate aggregated data it was necessary for institutions to collect the majority of the data detailed in the Data Element Dictionary for 1987 and 1988. For universities, unit record data i.e. data in respect of individual students, has been collected since 1977. Again the majority of the data collected has remained the same over this period although it has been necessary to refine the data specifications to ensure comparable data was collected across the higher education sector.
Prior to 1988 staff data for both universities and colleges was also collected in aggregate on forms.

Although the forms collection only provided aggregated data the scope of the data collected was similar to that collected in the current higher education staff statistics collection. Copies of the documentation provided to institutions in respect of the years 1984, 1985, 1986 and 1987 have been provided to Senator Teague.

(4) Students-Following its introduction in 1987 a number of enhancements have been identified for the higher education student data collection. These enhancements have been identified by institutions and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. As a result of these identified enhancements and the introduction of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme changes are to be made to the collection in 1989.
For 1989 institutions will be required to provide additional information as follows:
more detailed data on citizenship/residential status;
additional data on extent and year of prior participation in various types of education;
details of exemption granted for prior studies at the first time of enrolment in the current course;
tertiary entrance score for students commencing undergraduate courses direct from secondary education;
student load by unit of study;
completion status for individual units of study; and
information on the liability of students under the Higher Education Contribution Scheme which is to be introduced from 1 January 1989.
Institutions will not be required to provide any additional data relating to staff in 1989.
(6) The information is stored in aggregated and unit record datasets on a stand alone computer.

(7) A unique identifier code is included on data records relating to individual students and staff when the data is provided to the Commonwealth. This code provides a means for the Commonwealth of validating the data according to previously determined specifications. This code also enables the Commonwealth to undertake longitudinal studies. The identifier and how it is allocated is strictly confidential to each institution.
While the code is provided to the Commonwealth with the data records it is not maintained on either the unit record or aggregated datasets.

(8) The date collected by the Commonwealth is used as a basis for funding decisions for higher education institutions and in undertaking policy analysis associated with the Government's role in higher education.

(9) A unique identifier code is used to identify students rather than personal information such as name and address. This protects the confidentiality of students and staff. When data is received in the Department it is loaded into datasets in an aggregated form i.e. individual students or staff members are not able to be identified. While a unit record data set is maintained for students and staff the code is removed after data has been validated. Access to the unit record data sets is limited to a small number of staff within the Tertiary Statistics and Operations Branch on a need to know basis. General access, on a need to know basis within the Department, is provided to the aggregated datasets only.
Institutions are advised to use commercial couriers when sending magnetic data to the Department.

(11) The Government's Policy discussion paper on higher education highlighted a number of significant deficiencies in the existing higher education database. The additional information being collected will be used by the Government in its monitoring and funding roles in higher education.
(12) As indicated in the Green Paper there are significant deficiencies in the higher education database which necessitate an urgent upgrading of the data provided by institutions.
(13) It is not possible for officers in the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Finance to have access to other than published aggregated data.

(14) Certain departmental staff, on a need to know basis only, have access to datasets of aggregated data. The designated processing staff in the Tertiary Statistics and Operations Branch are the only officers of the Department who have access to the unit record data supplied by institutions.
(15) Including ADP and statistical processing staff (Tertiary Statistics Section) a total of 13 officers currently have access to the unit record data collection.

(16) The data is provided to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training as a condition of Commonwealth funding. As such the information is not available except in aggregated form to other Commonwealth department or bodies except the Affirmative Action Agency. It has been agreed with institutions that the Department will provide the Agency with the unit record data on staff as a means of reducing demands on institutions for the same or similar data.
(17) Not by the Commonwealth. This facility is only available to the institution which supplied the data.
(18) No. The data collected by the Department does not contain the name and address of the student to which the identifier could be attached to identify students.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 23 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the technical requirements for the installation of an Integrated Service Digital Network (ISDN) network.
(2) What is the anticipated cost of the installation of ISDN: (a) in capital cities; (b) in provincial cities; and (c) in rural and remote areas.
(3) What is the average cost per installation of ISDN in: (a) capital cities; (b) provincial cities; and (c) rural and remote areas.
(4) To what extent is ISDN already in place in any and what parts of Australia.
(5) What is the total cost to date of ISDN installation.
(6) By what methods are the installation costs of ISDN calculated.
(7) What is the likely future demand for ISDN services and on what basis has it been determined.
(8) What is the likely cost to customers of the ISDN network.
(9) To what extent is ISDN in place or being put in place in the United Kingdom, Japan, Canada and the United States?
(10) When was the decision to instal an ISDN network in Australia taken and by what means and when was such decision made public?
(11) What are the specific types of ISDN services which it is anticipated will be used by: (a) residential; and (b) business-users.

(12) (a) Prior (b) Subsequent-upon the decision being taken to proceed with the installation of an ISDN network in Australia was any, and if so what, internal or external study undertaken by any, and if so what, person(s) or organisation(s) as to the feasibility and/or desirability and/or the costs and benefits of the installation of such a network.

(13) Of the approximately 618 000 new telephone installations in the financial year 1986-87: (a) how many were installed on premises with an existing telephone system; (b) how many were installed on farm properties; (c) how many were installed on non-city or metropolitan properties as part of the establishment of a new business venture; (d) how many farming properties presently do not have an installed telephone system; and (e) what is the extent of the present waiting list and average waiting time for farming properties seeking new telephone installations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from Telecom Australia:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom advises that ISDN requires a network with a capability for 64K bit/s digital connectivity end-to-end, with new telephone exchanges capable of handling the powerful new signalling protocol.

(2) and (3) Telecom estimates that by June 1990 it will have spent between $30 and $40 million on new capital and labour in addition to normal plant expansion in order to provide this service. This estimated figure is broadly based with no expenditure break-downs for capital cities, provincial cities or rural and remote areas being currently available.

(4) ISDN is not currently in service. Telecom plans to launch the service commercially in 1989. An ISDN exchange has been installed in both Sydney and Melbourne, and these are currently in the test phase.
(6) Telecom advises ISDN installation costs are calculated, by taking into account capital, labour, research, testing and provision of other interface equipment together with other normal overheads.
(7) Telecom advises the likely demand for ISDN services is estimated at 10% of business lines by 1995. Estimates are based on Telecom's expectations of needs of the corporate sector.
(8) Telecom expects to announce access and usage tariffs for ISDN by mid October 1988.
(9) Telecom has advised me that the extent to which ISDN is in place in the UK, Japan, Canada and USA is:
UK-No announcement reported on ISDN so far. British Telecom has a pre-ISDN service called (Integrated Digital Access).
Japan-NTT introduced an ISDN service in April 1988. The service consists of two 64K/s information channels and one 16K bit/s signalling channel.
Canada-It is reported that Bell Canada will commence ISDN customer trials in November 1988 with a commercial service expected late 1989.
USA-Earlier this year, Southern Bell introduced the first commercially available ISDN service in the world. It is reported that AT&T plans to introduce ISDN in 1988 in 18 cities across the USA.
(10) ISDN is an evolutionary development which has been under consideration by Telecom for a number of years. Telecom announced its ISDN plans in a press release dated 11 October 1985.

(11) ISDN is directed at large corporate business users and is not aimed at residential users at this stage. It is anticipated that the business user will use ISDN for both data and voice telecommunications in the switched and dedicated mode at transmission speeds of 64K bit/s for fast facsimile transmissions, enhanced videotex applications, computer based business transactions, corporate data and voice communication, and development and use of new value-added network applications.
(12) Telecom has conducted a number of internal and external studies. Organisations external to Telecom involved in various aspects of ISDN considerations were:
(13) This information is unavailable from Telecom's management information systems.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Local Government, upon notice, on 28 September 1988:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I do not intend proposing the re-establishment of the Advisory Council of Inter-Government Relations. A review of that organisation in 1986 found that it had had limited success in improving inter-governmental relations and recommended its abolition. There was little support for its continuation amongst State Governments and the recommendation of the review was accepted.

I will continue the very successful policy of using the Local Government Ministers' Conference as the major forum for discussion between the three spheres of government. Since the creation of the first federal Ministry for Local Government in 1983, leading to a more active Commonwealth involvement in the Conference, it has become a much more effective instrument for building constructive inter-government relations.

In addition I am proposing to hold special discussions between representatives of national local government organisations and senior Commonwealth Ministers within the next few months. These discussions will cover major matters of mutual concern and will be designed to strengthen relations between local government and the Commonwealth.

I will also continue the Government's policy of using the Local Government Development Program to facilitate improved dialogue between the three spheres of government by providing grants to finance ways of working together on particular issues of concern. In fact I have made the strengthening of inter-governmental relations my priority for funding projects under this year's Local Government Development Program.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 May 1988 (Hansard page 3076), Senator Puplick asked me as the Minister representing the Attorney-General the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Was advice sought by the Minister responsible for the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill from the Australian Electoral Commission in relation to the compatibility of the Government's proposed electoral system for the Australian Capital Territory with its proposed referendum requirements and the impact which those constitutional changes might have on State voting systems? If no advice was sought from the Australian Electoral Commission why was the Government's alleged electoral expertise in that Commission ignored? If the Electoral Commission was consulted what advice did it give the Government?

Can he say whether any advice has been sought from the Australian Electoral Commission now that it has been revealed that the legislation before the Parliament is defective and the Government has taken a decision to proceed with amendment, or has the expertise of the Australian Electoral Commission been ignored again?
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
There was no direct consultation with the Australian Electoral Commission on the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988 before the Bill was introduced into the Parliament.

The Bill retained the basic principles of the draft Bill prepared by the Constitutional Commission that the number of electors in electoral divisions should not be more than 10% above or below the average and that the right to vote should be guaranteed.

However, the Government Bill differed from the Constitutional Commission Bill because of a number of problems in the Commission Bill. In particular, in providing an assurance that all elections conducted in an electorate at large would be fair elections, the Bill broke new ground in order to solve a problem not resolved by the Constitutional Commission (or in the 1987 Macklin Bill). It provided a workable scheme.

The Commission Bill included separate provisions dealing with one vote/one value and the right to vote for each of the House of Representatives, State Parliaments and Territory legislatures. Chapter VIA of the Government Bill consisted of general provisions applicable in respect of all elections. The simpler format of the Bill avoided the repetitions in the Commission Bill by locating the `fair election' provisions in one place, instead of having them scattered through the Constitution.

The Commission Bill could have been interpreted as imposing a requirement that electoral divisions continuously comply with the one vote/one value principle. Such a requirement would have been unduly burdensome and probably impractical. The Government Bill required that there be a redistribution at least every 7 years. There was also to be a redistribution if, on the last day of any 2 successive months since the last redistribution, more than 1/3 of the electorates exceeded the +- 10% tolerance.
The Government Bill also dealt with the failure of the Commission Bill to provide a one vote/one value formula covering multi-member divisions in federal and territorial elections.

The Government Bill applied to voting after 1 year whereas the Commission Bill proposed a 2 year period. The 1 year period of grace in the Bill provided a reasonable opportunity for the Commonwealth, States and mainland Territories to make any necessary amendments to their electoral laws. The Government Bill extended only to mainland Territories, whereas the Commission Bill applied to all Territories, it included a strengthened provision dealing with standing and made explicit the power of the courts to enforce its provisions.

Following the concern expressed over the effect the Government Bill might have on the electoral systems for the New South Wales and South Australia Upper Houses and the proposed d'Hondt system for the Australian Capital Territory, my Department consulted extensively with the Australian Electoral Commission on the amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats to the Bill in the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 June 1988 (Hansard page 3343), Senator Peter Baume asked me a question without notice concerning the distribution to students of material relating to the report of the Committee on Higher Education Funding (the Wran Report). Arrangements were made for the institutions to forward the material direct to students, on the understanding that distribution costs would be reimbursed by my Department.

Five hundred thousand copies of the Overview and Recommendations were printed at a cost of $67,723. The cost of bulk distribution to the institutions from Canberra was $42,046. As at 19 September 1988, 44 institutions had been reimbursed for the cost of the distribution, to the amount of $187,043.01.

The decision to give wide publicity to the Wran Committee's report enabled an informed discussion of its proposals. The Government was particularly concerned to ensure that those most affected by the proposed reforms-higher education students-were accurately informed and given the opportunity to comment on the proposals.
I have forwarded to Senator Baume under separate cover, a copy of the material provided to students.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 24 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the recent tragic triple fatality in Brisbane when a missile from a construction site accidentally crashed through the roof of a safety barrier, could the Minister advise: (a) is a safety code to cover such disastrous eventualities in place between the Federal Government and the States and Territories; if not, why not, and are any measures envisaged to bring such uniform legislation into place; and (b) what code or legislation is in place in the Territories under the administration of the Federal Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The factors which led to the construction site tragedy in Queen Street Brisbane will be considered at a coronial inquiry. The Queensland Government has already taken action to ensure that chains as well as slings are used to secure loads. With regard to a standard or safety code to cover such events, it is the responsibility of respective States/Territories to introduce construction safety regulations.

The role of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Worksafe Australia) with regard to occupational health and safety standards is to encourage a national approach through the issue of specific standards and codes of practices which the States and Territories can adopt in legislation and regulations. The National Commission through representation of the States/Territories, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry aims to achieve national agreement on standards.

The Employment Bill 1988 provides for Codes of Practice to ensure safe working environments. The Norfolk Island Government also has a policy of not allowing building structures greater than two storeys.
Ashmore and Cartier Islands are uninhabited. The Ashmore Reef is a declared National Nature Reserve and Cartier Island is a gazetted bombing range.
The laws of Christmas Island are basically those of the Colony of Singapore at the time the Island was transferred to Australia in 1958, as amended from time to time by Commonwealth ordinances.

Some industrial safety legislation is in place, such as the Machinery Ordinance (an ordinance of the Colony of Singapore which remains in force in the Territory of Christmas Island), and the Explosives (Storage and Use) Ordinance 1979. The former regulates the use of machinery in building work, the latter the use of explosives. The legal regime of the Island, however, is deficient in some respects and steps are being taken to update legislation.

Very little building work has been undertaken in recent years on the Island and few buildings are of greater than two storeys. There are currently proposals for private redevelopment of some accommodation blocks, mostly of one or two storeys. Leases for such developments under the Christmas Island Lands Ordinance 1987 will provide that plans and specifications must be approved by the Commonwealth in accordance with Australian Capital Territory (ACT) standards as if the building was situated in the ACT.
The agreement between the Commonwealth and the proposed resort/casino developer also requires that specifications be in accordance with the ACT standards.

Private phosphate mining is likely to commence on the Island in 1989 making use of existing machinery, plant and infrastructure. A Mining Ordinance is currently in preparation and will be based on relevant Western Australian legislation including the Machinery Safety Act 1978.

The laws of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are basically those of the Colony of Singapore at the time the Island was transferred to Australia in 1955, as amended from time to time by Commonwealth Ordinances. Generally, the state of industrial, building and safety legislation is as described for Christmas Island.
There are few buildings in the Territory of greater than one storey, and no building work of greater than two storeys is currently contemplated.

A tourist resort development is proposed for Direction Island in the Cocos group. The Resort will reflect a Malaysian theme in its construction and appearance being generally a one-storey construction. The parties to the project acknowledge that the consent of the Commonwealth is required before construction can commence and that consent will be partly conditional on agreement to use of mainland building standards and safety procedures.

In the ACT, the Scaffolding and Lifts Ordinance 1957 covers the lifting and handling of materials and the safety of building sites, and the Building Ordinance 1972 covers the design of protective hoardings.
The ACT provisions also apply to Jervis Bay, the Coral Sea Islands Territory, the Australian Antarctic Territory of Heard Island and the McDonald Islands.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 27 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Primary Industries and Energy closely monitor funding by the United States (US) Congress for the Export Enhancement Program (EEP).
(2) How has funding for the EEP been increased since its announcement by the US Department of Agriculture.
(3) When were the increases in expenditure made and what was the amount allocated to the EEP.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) When it was introduced on 15 May 1985 the EEP had a funding of US$2b in the form of Commodity Credit Corporation (CCC) owned commodities and was to apply until 30 September 1988. Expenditure under the program was at the discretion of the Secretary of Agriculture.

The Food Security Act, 1985, which was signed into law on 23 December 1985, mandated expenditure under the EEP of not less than US$2b in the form of CCC owned commodities over the period October 1985-September 1988.

On 20 March 1986 President Reagan signed the Food Security Improvements Act 1986 which provided for, inter alia, a reduction in mandatory expenditure under the EEP from US$2b to US$1b and provided for discretionary funding of up to US$500m, giving a total funding of up to US$1.5b in CCC owned commodities.

The US Department of Agriculture announced on 30 July 1987 that it would continue to fund the EEP beyond the US$1.5b specified in the Food Security Improvements Act, under the CCC Charter Act 1948. Additional funds of some US$700m were provided under this legislation.

The Agricultural Competitiveness and Trade Act of 1988 (part of the Trade legislation which was signed by President Reagan on 23 August 1988) increased funding for the EEP to US$2.5b and extends the program to September 1990. This Act also provides that in January-February 1990 the President must report to Congress on progress in the Uruguay Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations. If the President certified that there has been no significant progress he must instruct the Secretary of Agriculture to implement a marketing loan for the 1990 wheat crop or extend the EEP. Under this provision the EEP funding would be increased by US$2b during US fiscal years 1990 to 1992.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 27 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department of Primary Industries and Energy quantified the cost to Australia of the United States Export Enhancement Program; if so, what has been the cost to the Australian agricultural sector for the years 1985-86, 1986-87 and 1987-88.
(2) What has been the cost to the Australian wheat industry for each of those years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has not quantified the cost of the Export Enhancement Program (EEP). It is difficult to accurately quantify the costs of a specific subsidy program, such as the EEP, in isolation from other factors operating in world grains markets.

Export subsidy programs are, in fact, only one example of a number of subsidy programs which impact negatively on world grains prices. US and EC farm support programs, which encourage production in excess of reasonable market demand, are major factors contributing to the disruption of world grains markets. Excess production is either disposed of on world markets with the assistance of export subsidies or put into stocks which overhang the market-both of which act to depress world prices.

It is competition between the subsidies of the US and the EC which determine sales prices and this is another reason why it is difficult to isolate the effects of the EEP. There is little doubt, however, that the effect of export subsidies, for grains, on the Australian agricultural sector is substantial.
Australia's approach to trade reform is to seek the elimination of all trade distorting measures encompassing both domestic support and export subsidy programs.
(2) Not available. See response to question 1.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Education Services, upon notice, on 11 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Noting that an average 52 per cent of unemployed people who have been part of the Community Volunteer Program (CVP) move from it into full-time paid work (a higher success rate than the Commonwealth Employment Service): (a) is volunteerism part of the labour-market; and (b) is funding for the CVP ceasing in December 1988; if so, what training opportunities will be available to the long-term disadvantaged unemployed who are incapable of undertaking the structured skills training courses within `SkillShare'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Education Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Volunteering is usually defined as a situation where an individual, under no duress whatsoever, provides his or her labour to an organisation without promise or expectation of remuneration. For this reason volunteering is not considered part of the labour market or labour force, a term which normally relates to persons in employment or persons available for and actively seeking paid employment.

(b) The Government announced in the context of the 1987-88 Budget its decision to form SkillShare by integrating the CVP and the Community Youth Support Scheme (CYSS) and the Community Training Program (CTP) to achieve a more effective use of available funds and to ensure that community-based assistance is provided for structured training and employment related support for the most disadvantaged job-seekers. SkillShare will commence on 1 January 1989 with existing projects being funded under current arrangements until the end of 1988.

While there is a focus on structured skills training in the new program, the SkillShare guidelines make specific provision for projects to offer a broad range of open access activities including volunteering, employment-related personal support services and personal effectiveness training to complement structured skills training.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Naval Armament Facilities: Environmental Impact Statement

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the maximum allowable period for the completion of the Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for the shift of naval facilities from Sydney to Jervis Bay governed by the Government's plan to shift the Newington Armament Depot to Jervis Bay.

(2) Does the Minister agree that the draft EIS should be released for public review for a period of no less than 90 days to ensure that the diverse and complex issues addressed by the EIS can be adequately responded to by the public; if so, will the Minister ensure that a 90 day public review period is ordered; if not, what public review period will the Minister be ordering.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. However in view of the evident need to transfer ammunitioning activities from Sydney Harbour as soon as is practicable, the Department of Defence is seeking to progress the proposal to construct an armament depot at Jervis Bay to an extent consistent with full and proper compliance with requirements under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.

(2) Considerations relating to the length of the public review period for a Draft Environmental Impact Statement fall within the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.
